HEADLINE: Elevator Technology: Inspiring Many Everyday Leaps of Faith

BYLINE: By ERIC A. TAUB 

 BODY:
BLEARY-EYED and coffee-saturated, you wait for the commuter train in the morning, then the subway, then for 4,000 people to cross 53d Street. By the time you force yourself through the revolving doors at 9 to get to work, the last thing you want to do is wait for a crowded elevator to haul you up to your office.
We could all take a lesson from the Three Stooges, for they knew how to get an elevator pronto: a simple yank on the floor indicator stick above the door inevitably brought the car to them instantaneously -- along with a jumble of bewildered passengers picking themselves up off the floor. 
 That technique doesn't work that well today. After all, when was the last time you even saw a mechanical floor indicator? In the last 50 years -- with the banishment of human operators and starters, individuals who stood outside elevator banks and, with the flick of their metal clickers, told the operators to start moving -- elevator management has become a computer-controlled science, where improvements are measured in fractions of a second.
The Holy Grail, according to Bruce A. Powell, perhaps the industry's only certified elevator scholar, is to make elevator operation seem effortless from the point of view of passengers.
As sole possessor of the title "technical fellow" at Otis Elevator Company in Farmington, Conn., the industry leader, Mr. Powell directs a team of people trying to figure out how to move as many people as possible as quickly as possible in an elevator.
Mechanically, elevators use the same basic design they did when Elisha Otis invented the safety version in the 19th century (the first modern elevator is said to have been built in 1743 in France as a way for Louis XV to slink around the Palace of Versailles undetected -- or, in an alternate version, to allow his mistress to arrive clandestinely). Cars ride up and down a vertical track, raised by either a hydraulic system or a counterweight. A series of cables and ratchets stop the cab from falling; if a cab falls, a safety brake kicks in to slow and stop it.
Today's high-speed elevators have redundant safety systems. The world's fastest elevator, in Osaka, Japan, can move at 2,600 feet per minute (nearly 30 miles per hour), compared with the elevators at the World Trade Center in New York, which can travel at 1,600 feet per minute. Greater speed does not mean greater danger. The last time an elevator may have entered free fall was in 1945, Otis officials say. That was when a B-25 bomber hit the Empire State Building between the 78th and 79th floors, severing lift cables. A cab dropped 75 stories, but the two women inside survived.
In the 1950's, automatic elevators went to floors in the order the call buttons were pushed. Like an emotionally dependent golden retriever, a car would go to the floor that issued the first call, leaving other would-be passengers stranded. Elevators would arrive at lobbies in packs, often empty, rivaling only Manhattan buses as hallmarks of inefficiency.
By the beginning of the next decade, mechanical elevator dispatchers had been programmed to send cars all the way up and all the way down, stopping for passengers along the way -- great if you were the one on or off first, but frustrating if you were along for the long ride. With zoned dispatching strategies, introduced in the mid-1960's, elevators were designated as expresses, serving just lower or higher floors, or as locals. Zone system technology is still in use.
One impetus for smarter elevators came from Asia's economic boom. The growth of heavily populated skyscrapers created an ideal market for better elevators. To make elevators more efficient, the industry developed fuzzy logic, which allows a system to keep several objectives in mind as it juggles elevator routes. If someone on the eighth floor calls for the elevator, the electronic controller is told, in effect: "Hey, stupid, don't just send the closest cab. Send the one a few floors farther away if it's empty because it'll actually get there faster."
First used in a building in Osaka in 1993, fuzzy logic came to our shores two years ago in an Otis retrofit of the elevator systems in the TransAmerica building in San Francisco. This is fuzzy logic with a twist: not only did TransAmerica workers save time in their vertical journeys, but they also found out which elevator they would be taking the moment they asked because of Otis's early car announcement technology. When a passenger asks for an elevator, the system determines which car the passenger should take and directs the passenger to that elevator door immediately by flashing a light over that door -- instead of indicating the car shortly before its arrival. To make sure that 20 embarking passengers do not collide into 15 exiting workers, the system directs riders to one or more empty cars that will leave more quickly instead of to full ones.
Yet the system can be misunderstood. After it was installed at TransAmerica, an angry executive, misunderstanding the advance signal, complained to the building manager that the elevators must be broken because "the elevator light came on and no car came for a long time." Lunch-time lectures were quickly held to explain the new system.
The next big thing in the industry is perfecting neural networks, computer programs that mimic, to some extent, the kind of complex information processing done by neurons in the brain. A neural network system not only learns from the past in directing elevators but also tries to predict future behavior. The technique is becoming possible only now, thanks to more powerful microprocessors.
"These systems will be like computer chess programs," Mr. Powell said. "They'll look at a building's traffic flow and posit 'what ifs.' " For example, elevator systems today can learn to adjust the way they deploy their cars based on changes in passenger traffic in the past few days. With a neural network, "we'll be able to ask what will happen to traffic and car availability a few minutes after I send car A out and to instruct the system not to do so if certain other conditions occur," Mr. Powell said.
People should not have to modify their behavior to adapt to elevators' needs, he said, adding: "We'll need very speedy computer chips. We want elevators to act more like us."

Installed in high-rise buildings where speeds of 500-plus feet per minute are needed. It provides the smoothest acceleration and deceleration.
 
Governor
Trips safety devices if a problem occurs.
 
Primary position sensor
Measures car's position in hoistway.
 
Hoisting machine
Drive pulley wheel connects directly to motor shaft.
 
Counterweight
 
Hoisting cables
Each elevator has 5 to 10 steel cables -- each capable of holding a full elevator.
 
The next generation?
The Odyssey system, an Otis Elevator concept, combines vertical and horizontal movement, allowing many elevator cars to share the same hoistway.
 
Controlled by fuzzy logic
Every time a hall button is pushed, the elevator system's software is set in motion, performing split-second calculations, based on 21 variables, to dispatch the best car. The system can respond to demand based on what it has learned about traffic patterns.
 
The building manager monitors the system's operation on a personal computer. Animations show which cars are moving in which direction, whether doors are open, how many calls are pending and the average waiting time for passengers.
 
Operations are constantly monitored by Otis's remote elevator maintenance system. If problems appear imminent, a technician is dispatched, ideally before breakdowns occur.
 
After weighing this car, which is traveling light, the system tells it to stop on the 8th floor.
 
The system determines that the closest car should not stop on the 8th floor because, based on the weight of the car, it is near its passenger limit.
 
A person on the 8th floor pushes the Up button, seeking to go to the 9th floor.
The system decides that an empty car is the best one to send to the ground floor, even though it is farther away than others.
 
Early car announcement system instructs the light outside the door of the arriving car to illuminate immediately. That allows passengers ample time to get to the doors, lessening the loading time and allowing the car to leave more quickly. By walking to the elevator before it arrives, passengers have the feeling that the waiting time is shorter than it really is.
 
People enter the office building and push the Up elevator button. The system determines which elevator can arrive most quickly, based on how many other stops it is making to pick up and discharge passengers. If the elevator is due to arrive at the ground floor with a large load, waiting passengers may be directed to an empty car instead to decrease congestion.

Door operator
 
Load-weighing sensors
Measure car's load.
 
Car safety devices
Grab guide rails if programmed speed is exceeded, preventing car from falling.
 
Traveling cable
Connects car to electrical systems.
 
Compensation cables
Keep the system in balance, no matter where the car is positioned.
 
Buffer
Stops car if it passes lowest doorway.
 
HYDRAULIC ELEVATOR
Used in low-rise buildings needing speeds of up to 150 feet per minute. The car is connected to the top of a piston, which moves up and down in a cylinder. Movement is controlled by a hydraulic valve. As fluid is pumped into the cylinder, the car rises; as fluid returns to the reservoir, the car lowers.
 
GEARED ELEVATOR
For medium-height buildings requiring speeds of up to 500 feet per minute. The drive is connected to the motor shaft through gears in a gear box.
 
Entrance protection
Fifty-six infrared beams create an invisible net across the elevator entrance. If any beam is interrupted, the system reopens the door instantly -- without touching passengers. Additional beams project into the hallway to detect passengers as they enter or exit the elevator. That helps avoid a potential collision between slow-moving passengers and the door.

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
A Simpatico Connection for Two Genres

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF

 BODY:
It would be hard to find two choreographers as different as Ann Reinking of Broadway fame and Ramon Oller of the avant-garde precincts of Barcelona, Spain.
Ballet Hispanico placed their works on the same program on Tuesday night; it was, depending upon your point of view, an exercise in incongruity or eclecticism.
Nonetheless, this opening of a two-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street in Chelsea) was typical. Tina Ramirez, the company's founder, has never been dogmatic about seeking out new works or new choreographers, asking only for a Hispanic connection in theme or music. More than most artistic directors, she has consistently given exposure to fresh talent. 
 As a choreographer, Ms. Reinking is still a relative novice despite her career as a musical-comedy star and her brilliant recension of Bob Fosse's dances in the current production of "Chicago." Mr. Oller was known on the experimental modern-dance scene in Europe (he was part of the 1992 Lyons Dance Biennial), but it was Ms. Ramirez who introduced his work to the United States a few years ago.
On Tuesday, Ballet Hispanico presented the world premiere of his "Bury Me Standing," inspired by the life of Gypsies, and "Una Mujer Llorando," a recent duet that was added to the program.
To move from the Oller pieces to Ms. Reinking's "Ritmo y Ruido" (1997) requires a psychological shift by the audience. "Ritmo" is a sleek, jazz-tinged crowd pleaser, while Mr. Oller's works generally have a dark side, expressed in a passionate use of energy.
"Bury Me Standing" gets off to a murky start, but its impressionistic images of Gypsy mores eventually achieve a cumulative power. Mr. Oller has borrowed his title from a study of Balkan Gypsies by the American writer Isabel Fonseca. In her book, a Gypsy asks to be buried standing because, he says, he has been on his knees all his life.
Nonetheless, Mr. Oller's piece lacks some coherence and only his final image, of an ensemble running in place, reveals where his sympathies lie. Anyone who has seen the anti-Gypsy code words (No vagabonds allowed) on signposts in Europe will understand this symbol of an entire people on the run as perennial outsiders.
Eugene Lee's decor sets the scene with admirable economy under Roger Morgan's lighting. There is no picturesqueness to this modern Gypsy community site with its wire fence, clotheslines and doorways defined by lighted bulbs. Suits and hats for the men as well as dresses and head scarves for the women come across in Willa Kim's costumes dyed in vibrant hues of red and blue. These are not necessarily Spanish Gypsies, although some of the taped music is flamenco. But other songs are in Romany, reminiscent of those recorded by great Russian Gypsy artists.
In this generic yet specific world, Mr. Oller begins with a cart, a symbol of Gypsy wandering. Wrist-rotating women make way for a male dancer, Pedro Ruiz. Despite the fleeting references to flamenco dance or to a bullfighter's stance in Mr. Ruiz's solo, the choreography throughout the piece is not folkloric but in Mr. Oller's highly physical modern-dance style.
When Alessandra Corona and Yael Levitin tumble off the cart and later explore shifts of weight and support in duets with male partners, the dancing has the look of 1990's experimental dance, full of athletic tensions and released energy. After Arleane Lopez gives the right amplitude to a solo with open shapes, ballet steps and little stamps, Ms. Levitin and Carlos R. Sierra Lopez have a tender duet. He lies on the ground and supports her on the soles of his feet as she changes position. When both dancers rise, shoot their arms forward and freeze in a stylized embrace, their passion is a shock. Then, like the abducted brides of Gypsy lore, Ms. Corona finds herself often carried on Mr. Ruiz's back.
The context for these set pieces is provided by the ensemble, which includes Hector Montero, Aydmara Cabrera, Lisa Nafegar, Terry Fox and Rochelle Aytes. Mr. Oller gives them a collage of motifs from Gypsy customs (a cluster of votive candles) and dances (women slapping their thighs). The piece needs some tightening, but then perhaps its atmosphere would not seep in so persuasively.
"Una Mujer Llorando" ("A Crying Woman") actually begins with Ms. Cabrera sobbing and bent over, with Mr. Montero behind her. As they tumble out of an embrace to guitar music (credited to Peteneras), the kind of expressive physicality that Mr. Oller's company, Metros Dansa Contemporania, executes so fearlessly comes into play. On this occasion the mechanics of the choreography, with its many lifts, was too evident and the devotional ending was obscure.
There was nothing puzzling about "Ritmo y Ruido" ("Rhythm and Ruckus"), and the dancers took energetically to the slink and swivel of Ms. Reinking's choreography. The vocals and percussion score by Philip Hamilton and Tobias Ralph provided the Afro-Cuban beat.

HEADLINE: SCREEN GRAB;
Images of a Bleak Era

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
In the Great Depression, the Federal Government hired a corps of photographers to capture the searing poverty of beleaguered farmers and other workers and, not incidentally, to provide work for unemployed photographers. Now these pictures, some of the most memorable photographs of that era, have been made available over the Internet to anyone with a computer.
One of those great photographers could not be more pleased. 
"I think it's important because otherwise an important part of history is sitting dead in files," said the photographer, Gordon Parks, who went from being a $48-a-week Government photographer to having a long career that also brought him acclaim as a movie director.
The Internet project includes well-known pictures like Mr. Parks's image of a black charwoman holding a broom and a mop in front of an American flag in Washington, which was segregated then, in an ironic homage to Grant Wood's "American Gothic."
"It should be profitable to many people," Mr. Parks said. "The photographs are indictments of what the Government was doing wrong."
The Library of Congress has put on line 52,000 black-and-white pictures, plus 1,600 color ones. They are from the collections of the Farm Security Administration and a successor agency, the Office of War Information, and were selected from 164,000 photographs taken from 1935 to 1945. Eventually, all the pictures in the collection, "America From the Great Depression to World War II," will be put on the Internet.
The Web site for the photos is memory.loc.gov/ammem/fsahtml/ fahome.html.
Besides Mr. Parks, who has 227 pictures on the Web site, other photographers represented include Walker Evans, who has 517 photographs on the site, including the simply titled "Sharecropper's Grave" from 1936.
Dorothea Lange has 759 images, including "Migrant Mother: Destitute Pea Pickers in California." The photograph, from 1936, is of a defeated woman with two children, their backs to the camera, burying their faces on her shoulders as she stares ahead.
There are 1,430 photos by Ben Shahn, some showing people trying to eke out livings as as cotton pickers, miners and masons. An itinerant street photographer stands in front of a restaurant in Columbus, Ohio, in August 1938, his eyes asking that passers-by pose and buy the photograph from him.
Beverly Brannan, a curator of photography at the Library of Congress, said that the Internet program had its roots in a preservation project that started seven years ago, when positive prints and digital versions were made from the library's collection of negatives. The Internet site started becoming available to the public in September. "It is part of a preservation project for the negatives, and at the same time makes it more accessible," Ms. Brannan said.
Mr. Parks and the other photographers still alive will not make any money from the distribution of their pictures because they were made while the photographers were working for the Federal agencies.
Carl Fleischauer, technical coordinator for the project, said that the resolution of the pictures on the Internet was similar to that found in daily newspapers but not so clear as for photographs in magazines. But no matter how good the computer and printer, the Internet pictures are still not near the quality of the photographic prints. These can be ordered from the Library of Congress for $18 and up.

HEADLINE: Toil and Trouble In Plexi-Land

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

 BODY:
MODERNISM can be dangerous. Just ask Cremilda Conceicao, whose forehead and sweat pants bear the battle scars of 14 years of cleaning the see-through elevator, transparent sinks and 17 levels of Plexiglas walkways and mirrored I-beams that snake bewilderingly through the late architect Paul Rudolph's Beekman Place triplex, perhaps the city's most stunning apartment.
"It's a crazy place, very accidental," she was explaining this week, spritzing Windex as she recounted how she almost fell off a balcony while trying to clean a Plexiglas platform that serves as head-grazing ceiling for one level and the floor for the level above. "You're always cleaning back and forth, back and forth. It's never ending." 
 The never-ending possibilities of space was a concept held dear by the modernist architect, who died at age 78 last summer. He left behind a mysterious infinity-box of an apartment -- the building is now on the market for $5.65 million, reduced from $6.25 million -- in which every detail was the product of his singular, some might say obsessive vision, from a built-in television set encased in chrome-plated Formica to steel staircases without banisters, whose dagger edges continue to wreak havoc on Miss Conceicao's sweat pants.
The latest occasion for Windex was a party given by Nest magazine last week, a dizzying affair that drew nearly 200 people, some of whom found themselves drinking white wine and listening to performance artists while trying to forget they were standing in a cantilevered bathtub. Never mind the transparent sink through which you could see into the bedroom below. The most sought-after accessory may not have been a Prada waist pouch, but a scopolamine patch for seasickness tucked surreptitiously behind the ear.
The apartment, a tectonic collision of abstract-mirrored and transparent forms that occupies the top three and a half floors of the nine-floor building, may ultimately be looked upon as a poignant piece of modernist folk art. Like the Rev. Howard Finster's "Paradise Garden," it is a fiercely personal, handmade, never-finished laboratory of one man's ideas. And like the Finster environment, it is in jeopardy. The creator of this passionate spatial fantasy, a rare, intact artifact from the Plexi-Baroque period, was a celebrated Harvard-educated architect, who served as dean of the Yale University School of Architecture from 1958 to 1965, and during his lifetime was described by Mildred F. Schmertz, the former editor of Architectural Record, as the "world's most eminent diehard late modernist."
Though he studied with Walter Gropius and was steeped in Bauhaus, Mr. Rudolph's spaces were "emotionally decorative," observed Donald Luckenbill, who served as Mr. Rudolph's project architect from 1969 to 1982 and oversaw the apartment's construction (though the Mr. Rudolph tinkered with it practically daily until his death from asbestos-related cancer -- "He could never leave it alone," Mr. Luckenbill said). He loved making turns; for example, entering the apartment is a Rod Serling experience in which floors feel tenuous and corners seem to dematerialize in reflections. "He wanted to reorient you to the inside, to debrief you and then capture you in a new world," Mr. Luckenbill said. "He wanted to overwhelm, bedazzle you with what he could do."
The apartment is indeed bedazzling. It was conceived as a sequence of pinwheeling planes, the concept of split-level taken to extremes. It is a piece of spatial choreography, composed of mirrored steel beams and translucent acrylic bridges, that do not form rooms so much as interpenetrate, changing elevations and seemingly defying gravity.
Mr. Rudolph was constantly experimenting with materials, once sheathing the apartment with Plexiglas floors, lighted from beneath. He was not a big fan of furniture, so he invented built-ins, like a daybed in which beige suede pillows are attached with metal rings to steel springs, like a spiral notebook.
In some ways, the apartment might be interpreted as the rebellious act of a minister's son who pushed the limits of conventional notions of space and home. "It's not a normal home," Peter Blake, an architectural critic and close friend, said. "It's a dream house, completely mad and uninhabitable in many ways, but beautiful to be in."
The most uninhabitable spaces may be the bathrooms (mercifully, a see-through Jacuzzi is now boarded up). But one bathroom has no privacy, despite Plexiglas shutters. "He was interested in translucency," Ms. Schmertz said. "Perhaps too interested." The apartment also contains precipitous drops, modernist crevasses, which, a close friend said, resulted in the loss of a pet cat. "People tried not to drink too much when they were at Paul's," she said, "but that poor cat. . . ."
Nevertheless, the idiosyncratic space abounds in human touches, like a spear from New Guinea that projects out defiantly from a kitchen equipped with see-through shelves and see-through glasses. Mr. Rudolph invented ingenious ways to organize his treasures, like tiny Mexican milagros, marching single file along ribbons of Mylar embedded in Plexiglas.
Mr. Rudolph's spirit seems to permeate the place even now, accentuated by a small memorial surrounded by votive candles containing his ashes. It is a shrine to modernism, one that is betraying its age in scuffed chrome, buckling carpeting and fraying Plexiglas.
The fate of Mr. Rudolph's daring creation is of deep concern to his friends and to those who envision the space as an architectural and urban think tank. The Landmarks Preservation Commission does not designate residential interiors unless they are open to the public, though at 30 years old, the Rudolph design could qualify. Ernst Wagner, the estate's co-executor and a longtime friend, says there had been an attempt to contact potential modernist-loving white knights and former clients like Sid Bass, the Texas industrialist. Sotheby's International Realty, the property's agent, has placed ads in Malaysia, Singapore and other outposts where Mr. Rudolph worked in his later years, marketing it as contemporary. "But the Asian economy is not exactly at the point where many are able to make this kind of purchase," Frederick J. Williams, an associate broker, said.
To Mr. Wagner, "preservation is a key issue, because this was a very, very personal piece of work." Thomas Heckman, an attorney and the estate's co-executor with Mr. Wagner, said net proceeds from the building's sale will go to the Library of Congress, home to 1,493 tightly packed tubes of renderings extricated over a two-day period from the apartment. Meantime, the space is being rented out for fashion shoots.
"It's unlike any place in New York," Mr. Blake said. "I'm buying lottery tickets myself."

HEADLINE: The Pop Life;
Cartoons Dare To Mock Icons

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The discipline of pop-music cartoon strips is a small and sad one, but one of the best has always been "Great Pop Things." Running for 10 years in alternative weekly newspapers, this pen-and-ink history of rock-and-roll has informed readers that Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones ate so much candy that "his entire body rotted away from the teeth downwards," Madonna "tried to change organized religion" by "wearing her underwear outside her clothes," Bob Dylan's music opened the way for new singer-songwriters who "were usually discovered feeling sorry for themselves on the stairs at parties" and Bono of U2 "retired from music to make LP's."
For those who don't live in the cities where the comic strip is regularly published (Los Angeles and Chicago, mainly), this smart, skewed, pun-filled and just plain inaccurate history of rock-and-roll has always been out of reach. This month, its best strips have been anthologized for the first time in the United States as a book, "Great Pop Things: The Real History of Rock-and-Roll From Elvis to Oasis" by Verse Chorus Press. (In 1992, Penguin in England released a hard-to-find anthology that the creators weren't happy with, then retained the rights to the comics until last year.) 
 Steve Connell, who runs Verse Chorus Press and is a publisher of the music magazine "Puncture," said he was attracted to the comic strip by "the attitude of complete irreverence to things that are normally approached with great reverence -- phenomena like U2 especially, which begs to be made fun of."
The strip is drawn by Jon Langford (of the 20-year-old rock group the Mekons) under the pseudonym Chuck Death. A friend from his hometown of Newport, Wales, Colin B. Morton, writes the text.
"Some people have a problem with the comic strip," Mr. Langford said. "Morrissey picked up a copy and threw it across the room and said his chin was too big. He was quite angry. But others, especially less popular bands, have used the comic as a T-shirt and view being included in it as an honor."
The criteria for being included in "Great Pop Things" are usually arrogance, a lack of self-awareness and being a pop-culture phenomenon, which has made for lots of comics about Morrissey, Madonna and U2. Unlike Morrissey, U2 has never responded to the barbed, mocking insults the comic has hurled at them. "That's one of the things that gall me," Mr. Langford said. "We relentlessly pillory them for being one of the most obnoxious and pompous of rock bands. But they've never gotten back to us. I'm sure they could break our legs if they wanted to."
The strip originally ran in Record Mirror in England in 1988 and, according to Mr. Langford, his inspiration has never ebbed. "Just when we think we've run out of ideas, David Bowie will say he's going to relaunch 'Ziggy Stardust,' " he said. "Or the Sex Pistols will reform and we'll go, 'Wow, we can get five strips out of that; that's like 500 bucks.' There's no bounds to the ridiculousness of pop people."
But does Mr. Langford feel hypocritical in making fun of all these popular and semipopular musicians when he is one himself? "They've got more money than me, but they're not as good-looking or talented, so I should ridicule them," he explained, not without sarcasm. "So it was partially inspired out of greed and hatred."
 
R-and-B Awards
The Rhythm-and-Blues Foundation announced the recipients of its annual Pioneer Awards yesterday. They include Johnny Adams, the New Orleans singer who died this year; Garnet Mimms, the leader of the Enchanters whose songs have been most famously interpreted by Janis Joplin; Mickey Baker, the prolific session guitarist; Brenda Holloway, the Motown singer; Dee Dee Warwick, the sister of Dionne; Patti LaBelle and the Bluetones, whose original lineup will be reunited at the awards ceremony for the first time since 1967; the Manhattans and members of the Drifters. In addition, John Lee Hooker, now in his 50th year recording music, will receive a lifetime achievement award.
The awards ceremony and performances will be at Sony Studios here, with Smokey Robinson as host, on Feb. 25, a date strategically planned for the day after the Grammy Awards. This way, rhythm-and-blues music can borrow some of the fanfare from the popular music that has borrowed so much from it. Unlike the Grammys, however, recipients of the Pioneer Award receive not just recognition and a piece of molded metal but also a fat check: $15,000 for individuals, $20,000 for groups. This year, the foundation is giving away $260,000, a sum that Janis Hazel, the foundation's new executive director, describes as "an all-time whopper."
Over the last year, she said, the foundation has focused on its education project, creating a 26-part radio series on rhythm-and-blues planned to run on National Public Radio next year and working on bringing music education programs to schools. The foundation has also continued its drive to make sure music pioneers with a legacy but little money to show for it (thanks chiefly to bad record deals) have what they need. It helped pay medical and, ultimately, funeral expenses for one of this year's honorees, Mr. Adams.
The foundation started 10 years ago with seed money from Ahmet Ertegun of Atlantic Records, but recently it has been forced to get more creative in its search for funds, which may be one reason Ronald Perelman, the chairman of Revlon and a rhythm-and-blues fan, will be presiding over this year's ceremony. "The economy has shrunk, the music industry is tightening its belt," Ms. Hazel said. "We need to seriously fund-raise in order to continue with our programs so we have been looking at other industries like automobile and major appliance manufacturers that use R-and-B in their advertisements."

HEADLINE: Essay;
You Bet Your Life

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Let me lay before you a modest proposal that will enable us to double aid to education, insure everybody's health, put a million new cops on the streets and install an impenetrable missile defense -- all while cutting taxes across the board.
Here's the big idea: a national lottery with the world's first billion-dollar jackpot. 
 Radical, you say? Smacks of a banana republic, unbefitting the only global superduperpower? You are out of step with the people; you have missed the great something-for-nothing cultural shift.
Gambling is now far more American than apple pie. Annual U.S. sales of apple pie (35 percent of the total pie market) can be estimated at a mere $150 million; the gaming profession (formerly the casino industry, and before that the gambling racket) turns over bets of at least $50 billion a year.
Politicians oppose gambling's political juggernaut at their peril. The Republican Governors of South Carolina and Alabama, old-fashionably trying to resist the tide of lotteries and video poker games in their states, were overwhelmed by candidates advised by the Cajun Clintonian, James Carville, to advocate letting the good dice roll.
And not just in the swingin' South did the bingo brigades triumph in the '98 elections. Missouri showed us the way in an initiative legalizing "boat in the moat" casinos on riverboats that sit in man-made basins.
Arizonans voted 2 to 1 to continue their troubled lottery. Californians by the same margin gave Indian tribes the right to build glitzy casinos to snatch back high-rolling palefaces from Las Vegas, in the highest-spending statewide campaign in U.S. history. Only in Maryland did the gambling fever fail to infect the populace. Gov. Parris Glendening, a Democrat, standing in the racetrack gate to bar slot machines, turned back a conservative candidate backed by gambling interests.
The people have spoken. Morality, shmorality. Those of us fuddy-duddies who hold that state-sponsored gambling is a perversion of public policy have been routed. Time not just to move on, but to move up to the Age of the Crapshooter.
Who can be expected to support my Billion-Dollar National Lottery (BDNL)?
Democratic intellectuals should seize on it. First, it would put the Federal Government in direct competition with private casino operators, always a desirable matchup. Second, a national lottery, with its publicizable billion-dollar jackpot, would undermine the burgeoning state lottery system and concentrate power in Washington, always better equipped to allocate resources fairly.
Republican fat cats should be supportive. Everyone in the 38 percent bracket knows that it is in the nature of lotteries to soak the poor, who have been getting away with economic murder since the imposition of progressive taxation. Under the BDNL, the sure losers -- those poor suckers happy to contribute a high percentage of their earnings to a lottery -- make it possible to reduce the heavy tax burden of life's winners.
Campaign strategists of both parties will set up their dissembly lines. All know that with the siren call of money "earmarked for education," lottery income soon substitutes for general revenues formerly spent on education. Thus, in the hands of persuasive focus groupies, a surreptitious sin tax can masquerade as a virtuous, pain-free non-tax.
Opposition is likely to come from newly affluent Indian tribes now snatching bread from the mouths of Bugsy Siegel's successors. Senator Richard (Slots for Tots) Bryant of Nevada induced the General Accounting Office to launch a $70,000 harassment of the Federal commission finding rampant compulsive gambling. Instead, his contributor-constituents should get him to induce tax-free tribal profiteers to reduce the $1.7 billion budget of Interior's Bureau of Indian Affairs.
The most serious challenge to the BDNL will come from the cyberbettors. Government-sponsored gambling will whet the next generation's appetite for ever-greater ripoffs of indigent thrill-seekers. Our great national bet would ultimately be covered and raised: On the Internet, helping squeeze a few hundred million taka out of Bangladesh, millennial gamblers can foresee the Trillion-Dollar Global Jackpot.

HEADLINE: Unions Turn Chilly, Too, By Striking In France

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
French train conductors say they're lonely and overworked, so they have been on strike since last Thursday, disrupting long-distance rail service in many regions.
French journalists say their paychecks don't buy as much as they used to, so they went on strike this week, too -- not against their newspapers and television and radio stations, but against a Government plan to do away with a special tax deduction of up to 50,000 francs, or $8,850, that they have enjoyed since 1934. 
 The long-term unemployed, who closed state job offices last Christmas and demanded higher benefits, occupied an unemployment office on Monday in Marseilles, where the movement began, demanding a Christmas bonus of 3000 francs, or $530, like the one they received last year.
The French have been taking to the streets since the Revolution, usually to demand something from the state. Not surprisingly, because Government spending amounts to 56 percent of the gross domestic product, compared with 41 percent in the United States.
The end of the year, when the days become short, cold and gray, usually brings a spate of labor disputes and visions of paralyzing national shutdowns like the three-week transportation strike in 1995 that sealed the fate of a conservative Government that had tried to reduce pension benefits.
The latest strike on the state railroad is not anywhere near that big. But its 11,000 conductors have kept up steady pressure to try to force the network to hire additional conductors. A union conductor in Bordeaux, Sauveur Ventura, told Agence France-Presse on Monday that it was sometimes a lonely job with many responsibilities but nobody to talk to except passengers. "We're also attacked by customers who complain about fares' being raised," Mr. Ventura said.
Then Agence France-Presse shut down for most of Tuesday because of the journalists' strike.
The 182,000 railway workers run some of the fastest, cleanest and sleekest trains in the world. These days they work, indirectly, for a Communist, Transport Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot, under a Socialist Government that promises to reduce the workweek for all of them to 35 hours starting next year, as some have had for years. But the conductors are also striking to make sure the workweek reductions are negotiated seriously.
The former aerospace executive in charge of the railroad, Louis Gallois, said last week that railroad employees accounted for 20 to 30 percent of all workdays lost to strikes in France.
"It's the way the enterprise resolves its internal conflicts," Mr. Gallois said. "Everybody lives off strikes: the hierarchy, the administration, the staff and the labor unions."
Even though fewer than 10 percent of workers in France belong to unions, polls show that the public generally sympathizes with them.

HEADLINE: U.S. Home Sales Were Strong in October

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Americans snapped up new homes at a rapid pace in October, keeping sales on course for a very strong year and highlighting the resilience of the United States economy.
Sales of single-family homes rose eight-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 851,000 units, the Commerce Department said today. It was the 14th consecutive month the sales pace has topped 800,000 -- the longest such period on record. 
 "We will easily see an all-time high for sales in 1998," said David Seiders, the chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders, who predicted sales of new homes would total 865,000 this year, breaking the previous record of 819,000 set in 1977.
Analysts said the housing figures signaled remarkable resilience in the United States economy, despite an economic slump overseas that has taken a bite out of the manufacturing sector.
The October home sales rate was well above Wall Street economists' forecasts for 844,000.
The pickup in October was attributable entirely to a large increase in the West. Other regions had declines. In the South, sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent. They dropped 5.4 percent in the Midwest and plummeted 11 percent in the Northeast.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Losses Trimmed in Afternoon Rebound; Dow Falls by 69

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Stocks weakened yesterday after Boeing and Sears, Roebuck warned of lower 1999 profits, but all major averages rebounded smartly during the afternoon to finish with losses well under 1 percent.
"There was pressure coming in, only to be met by strong institutional demand," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, investment policy chairman at Gruntal & Company. 
 He said some of this buying reflected "window dressing" by portfolio managers eager to be seen holding winners in year-end statements.
Boeing's disclosure late Tuesday that it expected profits to be as much as 25 percent less than the company projected in July sent its shares plunging 6 11/16 , to 33 11/16 , accounting for 40 percent of the loss in the Dow Jones industrial average.
The blue-chip gauge closed 69 points lower after having skidded more than 178 points at midday.
But the aircraft maker's swoon, which also prompted selling in United Technologies, down 4 13/16 , to 101 5/8, and other of its suppliers, was said to be more a reflection of disappointment with Boeing's erratic response to Asian economic problems than to fears that Asian orders will shrink further.
As for Sears, which now predicts an earnings rise of 1 percent to 3 percent instead of the 5.2 percent that Wall Street expected, fell 1 9/16 , to 43, as most department stores and discounters lost ground.
Although most Internet stocks and other speculative favorites lost ground, buyers gave the latest initial public offering a warm reception. E-Tek Dynamics offered 5 million shares at 12 and the fiber optics company traded as high as 29 7/8 before closing at 26 3/4.
The recent frenzied buying of almost every company with an Internet tie brought a strong expression of concern from John H. Laporte, a specialist in small-capitalization companies at T. Rowe Price.
"It clearly represents a speculative bubble," not unlike tulip mania centuries ago in the Netherlands, he told an investment seminar in New York. "I think it's quite worrisome."
A report of stepped-up insider selling at Excite and other Internet companies apparently dampened enthusiasm yesterday.
Another sign that the market may be growing less exuberant, observed Richard E. Cripps, chief strategist at Legg Mason, is a survey showing less bullishness among Wall Street traders. The latest reading found 60 percent optimistic, down from 78 percent last week.
Exxon, which said it retained the ability to call off its acquisition of Mobil if demands of antitrust enforcers were judged too onerous, eased 3/8, to 71 1/4.
Drug stocks were among the afternoon's recovery pacesetters. Schering-Plough gained 4 3/8, Bristol-Myers 3 7/16 , Pfizer 2 1/16and Merck, American Home Products and Abbott a point or more each.
Tomorrow, Citigroup will begin trading under the ticker symbol C, the designation for Chrysler before the auto maker merged with Daimler-Benz.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 34/100ths of 1 percent yesterday while the Nasdaq composite was down 43-hundredths of 1 percent. The Russell 2000 fell 31-hundredths of 1 percent.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by 1,737 to 1,348, with 74 making new highs for the year and 56 new lows. Volume was a moderate 727.4 million.
Shares were mostly lower overseas -- 1.12 percent in Brazil, 1.36 percent in Germany, 1.04 percent in France and 55-hundredths of 1 percent in Britain. Prices rose, however, in Japan and Hong Kong, by 1.02 percent and eight-tenths of 1 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bonds Rally for 6th Day
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bonds rose yesterday for the sixth consecutive trading session, the longest contiguous gain in more than a year, as weakened stock prices led investors to the safety of Treasury issues.
The benchmark 30-year bond rose 11/32, to 103 19/32 , cutting its yield 2 basis points, to 5.02 percent, the lowest since Oct. 19.
Bonds have climbed every day since Nov. 23 -- with trading halted Nov. 26 in the United States for Thanksgiving -- for gains of some 2 3/8 points, a streak not seen since November 1997. The 30-year yield has fallen almost a quarter percentage point in that time, as United States stocks retreated from record highs, falling oil prices raised expectations for scant inflation and reports suggested the economy is slowing.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with John Tierney, Marcelle S. Fischler and Corey Kilgannon 

 BODY:

A Softball Question For Mr. Microsoft
 It was a friendly crowd and a friendly question, but WILLIAM H. GATES resisted the temptation to speak too frankly.
Mr. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft and star witness at the Government's antitrust trial, was addressing a luncheon yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel organized by the Manhattan Institute, a public-policy group more sympathetic to entrepreneurs than Government attorneys. 
 Sure enough, one person in the audience raised a question about the antitrust case: Was it based on a genuine misunderstanding of the law and the marketplace, or was it class warfare inspired by jealousy of Mr. Gates?
No doubt Mr. Gates could give an answer that would fill a nice long E-mail. But not this time.
"I can't delve into their mental processes," he said, smiling. "There are many paths to making a mistake."
 
No Hard Feelings
The financier GEORGE SOROS is not an unqualified admirer of the International Monetary Fund, and said so at the New York Public Library on Tuesday night. "The I.M.F. system of raising interest rates in a crisis is rather counterproductive," he declared.
At which point his microphone died.
"The I.M.F. just turned it off," quipped the economist JEFFREY MADRICK, who was moderating the session.
The 550 or so tip-hunting listeners did not find out where Mr. Soros thinks the stock markets will go, but once the public-address system was revived, he was asked about his famous bet on the British pound, the one that netted him $1 billion in a single week in 1992. He called it morally defensible.
The financier LEON LEVY went further.
Noting that the British had to devalue the pound and lower interest rates, Mr. Levy said: "George should be honored. They should make him Lord Soros."
 
Reverse Commute
It was camp-reunion time for the Hamptons crowd on Tuesday night. Artists, filmmakers and writers who seem to have been spending at least as much time on eastern Long Island as in Manhattan were sipping cocktails at the Plaza Hotel.
"I didn't know all these people had places to live in the city," said the actor ALAN ALDA, looking over the black-tie crowd at the Guild Hall Academy of the Arts awards dinner, an annual event for the theater-and-museum complex in East Hampton. Mr. Alda -- like at least two other guests, PETER STONE and BARRY SONNENFELD -- lives in the Hamptons year round and ventures into Manhattan only when he has to.
Others in the crowd come and go, but often spend much of the workweek wishing they could stay out east.
"Being outside New York City tends to leaven people somewhat," said the ABC News anchor PETER JENNINGS, who is himself a Hamptons homeowner. "I was talking to Julian Schnabel, who under normal circumstances is a giant, but under Hamptons circumstances is a neighbor. It makes a difference."
 
A Pet Project
 EARTHA KITT arrived with her two miniature poodles, Abba and Mutzi. They are dogs-about-town: she takes them along when she performs at the Carlyle Hotel.
But this was a lunch for the Harmony Institute, a nonprofit group that studies the relationships between people and animals and was unveiling plans for a "luxury pet residence" in Orlando, Fla. It will have concierges for pets and outdoor doggie showers.
"I don't have two-legged kids, I have four-legged kids," MARTHA E. LENTZ, the Harmony Institute's chairwoman, said as she reached for a cigarette after the lunch. "I try to smoke around my pets as little as possible, but I'm sure they have the same amount of lung disease as I do."

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: TALKS ON ECONOMIC CRISIS -- The head of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, met again with Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov and praised Russia's "pragmatic" course in dealing with its economic crisis. But Mr. Camdessus said a team from the Fund would have to return next month for further negotiations on releasing the frozen loans that Russia badly needs. (AP)
 
RUSSIA: STATUE TO RISE AGAIN -- The Communist- dominated lower house voted overwhelmingly to resurrect a statue of Felix Dzerzhinsky, left, the first chief of the Soviet Union's secret police, in the center of Moscow. The towering bronze statue of "Iron Felix," a landmark during the Soviet era, was toppled by pro-democracy protesters in 1991 and has since languished in a city park. (AP) 

GERMANY: CHANGE URGED FOR EUROPEAN UNION -- Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer said new members should be admitted to the European Union only if Germany's financial contributions to the were reduced. Germany, the largest net contributor, has long lobbied for reform of the group's finances. (NYT)
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: BLAIR RETURNS TO BELFAST -- Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew to Belfast for the second time in a week to meet with political leaders in an effort to break the deadlock in the peace effort. Catholic and Protestant parties are feuding over the makeup of the new legislature's executive and the responsibilities to be given new cross-border councils with the Republic of Ireland. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: SCOTTISH UPSURGE IS REPORTED -- The creation of a semiautonomous Scottish parliament next year could lead to complete independence for the region, according to a British parliamentary report. Instead of containing secessionist ambitions, as intended by Prime Minister Tony Blair, the House of Commons's Scottish affairs committee said, the new entity could provide a focus for them. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
HONG KONG: U.S. AND CHINA CONDUCT DRILL -- For the first time since Hong Kong's handover to Chinese rule in July 1997, China's military units joined 220 United States Air Force and Coast Guard personnel there in a search-and-rescue exercise. Previous joint exercises involved units from Hong Kong when it was a British colony. China and the United States agreed to conduct joint exercises when President Clinton visited Beijing in July. (AP)
 
CHINA: CALL TO OPEN COURTROOMS -- Court trial procedures throughout China must be opened to the public starting next year, its top judicial official, Xiao Yang, said in a report by the New China News Agency. But the Government has indicated that it will still hold closed trials for people accused under the vague state secrets law used to prosecute dissidents. (AP)
 
JAPAN: JUMP IN DEFICIT PREDICTED -- Japan's budget deficit will rise to 9.8 percent of its gross domestic product by the end of the current fiscal year as the Government is forced to sell new bonds to pay for stimulus measures to revive the moribund economy, the Finance Ministry said. The deficit was 6.3 percent in March 1998, the end of the last fiscal year. (Bloomberg News)
 
INDONESIA: PROTESTERS MARCH ON PALACE -- Ignoring an appeal by President B. J. Habibie to stay off the capital's streets, about 1,000 students marched on the Presidential Palace to present a petition demanding democratic reforms. Student protesters have kept an almost daily vigil in central Jakarta since Nov. 13, when soldiers fired on crowds, setting off a series of confrontations that left 16 dead. (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: NETANYAHU VOWS TO STAY IN LEBANON -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, left, took members of his Cabinet to Israel's northern border and reaffirmed that Israel would not withdraw from the buffer zone it occupies in neighboring Lebanon without a prior security agreement with officials in Beirut. "We will stay in Lebanon whatever the cost," Mr. Netanyahu said, in his clearest rejection of calls from the Israeli public for a unilateral withdrawal.
 (Agence France-Presse)
 
LIBYA: ANNAN TO PRESS FOR TRIAL -- United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan will go to Libya this weekend to discuss with Muammar Qaddafi the impasse over a trial for two Libyans suspected of bombing Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988. Without an assurance of success, the trip could be politically risky for Mr. Annan, since Libya is under United Nations sanctions for refusing to hand over the suspects for trial in the Netherlands. Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
CONGO: REFUGEES CROSSING BORDER -- A total of 16,487 refugees from Congo have fled into Tanzania since early August, said Anthony Moga, an official of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
 (Agence France-Presse)
 
UGANDA: WAR DRAINS BEER SUPPLY --The war in neighboring Congo increased beer production in Uganda to record levels last month. Uganda Breweries Ltd. sold 10 million bottles in November, much of which was taken to areas held by rebels, who are backed by Uganda and Rwanda. (Agence France-Presse)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: MINIMUM WAGE INCREASED -- A Government panel increased Mexico's three-tiered minimum wage by 14 percent. The increase, which raises the daily minimum wage to as high as $3.50, was supported by representatives of President Ernesto Zedillo and the business sector on a three-member panel. But because the increase is below the 16 percent inflation rate, labor's representative voted against it. The increase takes effect today. Sam Dillon (NYT)

HEADLINE: Boeing Plan for Job Cutbacks Is Bitter Pill for Seattle Area

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: EVERETT, Wash., Dec. 2

 BODY:
For all the talk of Microsoft's exercising global dominance from the empire's capital here in the Seattle area, most residents know that the big engine for jobs in the region remains the Boeing Company, the nation's largest exporter, whose 100,000-strong local work force is eight times the size of Microsoft's.
The airplane behemoth is the region's biggest employer, providing good jobs for tens of thousands of blue-collar workers, whose strong union has secured the kinds of wages that enable many workers to afford fishing boats and second homes in the Pacific Northwest mountains. 
 So when the company announced on Tuesday that it was cutting 20 percent of its worldwide work force over the next two years -- 20,000 jobs in addition to the 28,000 it had announced in July -- with many of those cuts planned for the Seattle area, the news hit like a chill winter wind. Boeing, one of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, fell 16.7 percent, or by $6.6875, to $33.6875 today in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The Dow was down 69 points for the day. Page C1.
The chief factor cited by Boeing for the company's downturn, the Asian recession, continues to hammer at the local economy in other ways as well: exports of all non-aircraft products from this heavily trade-dependent state are down more than 30 percent in the last year, state economists say. And while exporters here see signs that Asia's problems may be easing, those projections seem to provide little consolation for Boeing workers.
"I can't see any quick turnaround," Thomas Plummer, a 49-year-old aircraft test technician on the production line for the 747 jumbo jet, said as he finished the graveyard shift early this morning. "I mean, even if things get better over there, I can't see Asian airlines rushing out and saying, 'Hey, let's buy a lot of big planes to celebrate.' You're talking $180 million or so for a fully loaded 747. That's a serious chunk of change."
Kevin Moe, 35, a wing mechanic who was laid off for four years in the early 1990's and fears a similar fate now, agreed. "You've got to think, how many planes do we already have sitting in the desert with no customers," Mr. Moe said, referring to a collection of sparkling new wide-bodied jets that are indeed parked there because various airlines, most from Asia, have not been able to pay for their orders.
"You'd like to think there was something you could do, work harder, whatever" to stem the company's problems, he added. "But what can you do? It's out of your hands."
The job cuts represent a potentially serious blow to the region's economy, especially because the rough rule of thumb is that every job at Boeing creates about three other jobs, directly, in related businesses like suppliers, or indirectly, in stores and restaurants. No one here seems to think that things will be anywhere near as dire as the 1970's, when the company cut nearly two-thirds of its work force amid a global recession and a notorious sign directed the last person leaving Seattle to turn off all the lights. But they are a worrying sign.
"If you look at the last Boeing slump, in '91-93, the state economy held up pretty well, because of other areas, obviously the high-tech area, but also timber and agriculture as well," said Charles Hill, a professor at the University of Washington's school of business administration. "The problem now, of course, is that timber and agriculture are Asian-dependent. Go figure. I think it'll hurt us."
Professor Hill and others noted that the Boeing announcement seemed almost strangely late.
"I'm not surprised, I'm surprised that people are surprised," he said. "I think this has been in the cards for 12 months.
"The moment those economies hit the skids," he added, referring to Asia, "this was in the cards."
Bill Whitlow, an analyst with Safeco Asset Management who follows Boeing and who serves on Gov. Gary Locke's Council of Economic Advisers, said the company "seems to be the last one to figure out how bad it would be" in Asia. Even with the signs that the economies are bouncing back, Mr. Whitlow said, there is no short-term good news for Boeing.
"I think it just takes time," he said. "It will be three or four years before you see much of an improvement in deliveries to Asia."
Not everyone thinks that all of Boeing's problems can be traced to Asia. From Seattle to Wall Street, many investors in Boeing have grown frustrated with what they view as the management's persistent failure to forecast the market for its planes accurately.
Boeing officials said today that they had renegotiated many contracts with major suppliers and were taking other cost-saving measures, which they portrayed as helping to ease the problems caused by the fall-off in Asian demand.
"There are things that we can't control, like the Asian crisis," said Bob Jorgensen, a Boeing spokesman. "We work on things we can control, and because of those savings those cuts won't be as deep."
Some of the unionized workers coming off their shift early this morning also said they were suspicious that the cutbacks represent a bargaining threat for the upcoming battle between the company and the aerospace workers union over a new contract. The current one is scheduled to expire next September.
Three years ago, when the current contract was ratified after a 69-day strike, workers claimed a major victory for organized labor, including wage increases of about 10 percent and protection of many health benefits. The bitterness over the negotiations quickly subsided, as the nation and the company enjoyed a huge economic boom. With a surge in demand for Boeing planes, the company made big payments for overtime work, hired more workers (21,000 people in 1996 and 17,000 last year), and pleaded with some retirees to come back to the plants.
Now, of course, the fear is that the boom times are over. And while no specific individuals have yet received layoff notices, everyone knows they're coming.
"You live in this bubble, waiting for the news," said Rolf Vitous, a 34-year-old electrical systems installer who has been with the company for two and a half years. "You don't go out and buy a new car, you don't buy a lot of Christmas presents, you definitely don't go and buy a new house. You lie in the bubble and wait. "
Boeing has jobs in more than half the states in the country, including about 42,000 in Southern California, making it one of the largest single private employers in that region. But its presence in Seattle and its environs is huge, and because this is the production site for most of the wide-bodied jets for which Asian airlines have reduced orders, everyone knows there will be significant job cutbacks here.
"This is a boom-and-bust business, and Boeing people understand the cyclical nature of it," said Mr. Plummer, the test technician. "But that doesn't help when you go home and your spouse says, 'Honey, are you going to have a job tomorrow?' "
While distressed about the job cuts, workers here did not seem particularly angry at Boeing management, nor did they blame the Asian airlines.
"It's not really their fault," said Mr. Vitous. "If you order up a shiny new pick-up truck and then you lose your job, you don't still go out and buy the truck. Well, it's sort of the same thing for them, though we're talking about wide-bodied jets."

(Jay Drowns/Associated Press)(pg. A22)

HEADLINE: BIG OIL: THE DEALERS;
Consolidations Give Jitters to Station Operators

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Dec. 2

 BODY:
Art Barbuto's credit-card printer spat out a terse message this morning: "Dear Mobil dealers," it said, "A letter has been sent to you today with information on the Exxon Mobil merger."
Like thousands of other gasoline dealers across the country with Mobil franchises, Mr. Barbuto now must wait for answers to the questions that keep popping into his head like the pangs of an oncoming migraine. 
 Will he have to pay more in rent for his filling station? Will the combined entity of Exxon Mobil eliminate the rebates that provide half of his profits? Will he still be able to send his son to college in two years?
In fact, Mr. Barbuto, 42, is in a particularly precarious position. His station, along the eastbound side of the Long Island Expressway, is in direct competition with an Exxon station on the westbound side. Will one of the two stations be shuttered or sold -- either by corporate strategists or by order of the Government's antitrust lawyers?
"There's an awful lot of I don't knows," he said.
Exxon's $80 billion acquisition of Mobil is expected to result in a loss of at least 9,000 jobs for refinery workers and white-collar employees. Consumers could be unaffected, some industry analysts said, if the combined company can bolster profits by cutting costs rather than by raising prices.
Caught in the middle, though -- facing neither the certainty of a swift demise nor the slightest reassurance about the future -- are gasoline dealers like Mr. Barbuto, who leases his shop from Mobil and buys Mobil's gasoline.
There are 8,500 Exxon stations in the country, and 7,400 Mobil stations, according to National Petroleum News, an industry publication. Self-employed dealers account for most of those stations, industry analysts said.
These dealers, who have struggled with shrinking profit margins, are left wondering how many will survive the industry's consolidation and at what price.
The recent combination of the refining and retail operations of Shell and Texaco, which took effect on Aug. 1, suggests the dealers may not escape unscathed. Mike M. Madani, a former Exxon dealer in Redondo Beach, Calif., said the combined Shell and Texaco quickly raised wholesale prices and eliminated the cash rebates they had paid to dealers based on the amount of gasoline they sold -- rebates that frequently meant the difference between profit and loss.
At Mr. Madani's station, now under the Texaco flag, monthly operating profits have fallen sharply. He said he competes with a nearby Mobil, where the operator pays $2,440 a month in rent, and a Shell, where the rent has been raised to $6,000. Since August, he said, the Shell station's pump prices have risen and its sales volume has declined.
Financially distressed Shell and Texaco station operators in 12 states are considering lawsuits over what they consider contract violations resulting from the merger, said Jim Daskal, a lawyer who represents several groups of gasoline dealers.
Dave McKinney, a spokesman for the Shell-Texaco joint venture, said he could not immediately respond to complaints raised by unhappy dealers.
With profits on gasoline shrinking nationwide, service stations have broadened their businesses wherever possible. They have moved from tiny retail counters with cigarettes and candy to ever-larger convenience stores, with drive-up windows for sandwiches and walk-in beer refrigerators.
On this stretch of Long Island's prosperous North Shore, Mr. Barbuto wonders what will become of his hopes to raze his old cinder-block garage, with its three rarely used car lifts, and build a bigger convenience store. "The repair business is dead today, with the advent of leased cars and five-year warranties," he said. "All we get is an oil change here and there, maybe a brake job or a tune-up. I only have one mechanic now. I used to have four."
Mr. Barbuto clearly does not relish the idea of big change. Since he bought the 35-year-old Mobil station from his father in 1983, Mobil has overhauled its fee structure three times, he said. In one instance about six years ago, Mobil charged Mr. Barbuto 20 percent of gross profits -- including sales of gasoline and proceeds from auto repairs. Then, he said, it started charging its costs on the property, plus a markup. Overnight, Mr. Barbuto said, his costs jumped from $3,000 to $8,000 a month.
These days, his Mobil has been locked in fairly stiff competition with the Exxon across the expressway. The cheapest grade of gas at each station was priced at $1.09 today, only 3 cents above what Mr. Barbuto said was his cost. His station sells about 250,000 gallons of gasoline a month from its three pumps, and he believes he has the better location since his is one of the first service stations for drivers leaving New York City, where fuel costs more. But Mr. Barbuto said he still feared what would happen if the merged companies ended up selling or closing some stations.
Federal law gives gasoline dealers the right of first refusal to buy their stations when oil companies decide to pull out of a given area, according to C. Fred Weil, the general counsel for the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association. If an oil company instead sells a group of those franchised stations to an independent company, the new owner is required to offer dealers a chance to stay on. "I don't think any dealer is going to find himself out on the street," Mr. Weil said.
But Mr. Barbuto remains uneasy. While representatives of Exxon and Mobil did not return calls yesterday about their pricing structure for dealers, Mr. Barbuto said all he had heard about Exxon was that it charges gasoline dealers more in rent than Mobil does.
"That's what gets me nervous about the merger," he said. "With Exxon, if they raised my rent another $8,000, I could be facing a $100,000 cost differential. That goes right to my bottom line."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Art Barbuto worries that his Mobil franchise in Roslyn Heights, N.Y., which competes directly with an Exxon outlet, will become one of the economies of scale that result from the proposed union of the oil giants. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

Two French Drug Makers In $10.4 Billion Merger
Two French drug makers, Sanofi and Synthelabo, agreed to merge for $10.4 billion, the second alliance between two European pharmaceutical companies announced this week. 
 The new company, Sanofi-Synthelabo, will have $6.3 billion in annual sales -- about one-fourth the size of Merck -- but will have considerable product strength in the industry. While analysts largely dismissed the partial merger between Rhone-Poulenc and Hoechst on Tuesday, the union of Sanofi and Synthelabo won considerable praise. Page C24.
 
Gates Professes Java Ignorance
In excerpts from a videotaped deposition played in Federal court, William H. Gates, chairman of Microsoft, professed general ignorance of his company's legal battles with Sun Microsystems over the Java computer language. C5.
 
Mr. Gates appeared at a luncheon in New York, serving up equal measures of playful scorn for his prosecutors and rivals. C4.
 
3Com announced an $800 wireless version of its popular Palm Pilot that offers limited Internet access. C5.
 
Head of BMW's Rover Unit Resigns
Walter Haselkuss, the chairman of Rover Group, a subsidiary of Germany's BMW, stepped down, saying he felt "quite strongly that somebody has to be prepared to stand up and be counted" for the company's failure to make a profit. The British auto maker also disclosed proposals for job cuts, flexible working hours, Government aid and new investment intended to propel the company into profitability. C24.
 
Boeing, Sears Lead Stocks Lower
Stocks weakened after Boeing and Sears, Roebuck warned of lower 1999 profits, but the main gauges rebounded during the afternoon and finished with losses of less than 1 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 69 points, to 9,064.54. The S.& P. 500 fell 4.03 points, to 1,171.25, and Nasdaq fell 8.54 points, to 1,995.21. C9.
 
The Securities and Exchange Commission approved rules to give small investors access to the best available stock quotes on electronic trading networks. C9.
 
Sales of New Homes Remain Solid
Americans snapped up new homes rapidly in October, keeping sales on course for a very strong year and highlighting the resilience of the United States economy. Sales of single-family homes rose eight-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 851,000 units, the Commerce Department said. C10.
 
Required Social Security Reading
When the Clinton Administration begins a two-day conference next week at the White House on fixing Social Security, the most radical option on the table will be the one that would allow individuals to deposit part of their payroll taxes into private retirement accounts. The issues are complex, but conference participants might do well if they first read a lucid study by an expert panel of the National Academy of Social Insurance, a nonpartisan research group. Michael M. Weinstein: Economic Scene. C4.
 
Sears Says Earnings Could Be Hurt
Shares of Sears, Roebuck fell as much as 7 percent after the nation's largest department store retailer said weak apparel sales hurt revenue in November and could result in lower-than-expected earnings for the year. Several Wall Street analysts cautioned that the slump in clothing sales could hurt other major department store retailers as well. C8.
 
Philip Morris to Battle Smoking
In what appears to be the most elaborate and costly effort of its kind by a tobacco company, Philip Morris U.S.A., the nation's largest cigarette maker, plans to spend at least $100 million a year to discourage children and teen-agers from smoking. Advertising. C2.

Cathay Pacific Airways has pulled out of talks to buy a stake in the ailing Philippine Airlines, making the uncertain future at Philippine Airlines even cloudier. C4.

HEADLINE: BIG OIL: THE PRODUCER AXIS;
For OPEC's Richest, Natural Allies of Size

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

 BODY:
With their planned merger, the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation are expected to gain considerably more leverage in their dealings with members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, reversing OPEC's quarter-century of primacy in this relationship, oil-industry experts said yesterday.
The Exxon-Mobil deal, as well as the planned acquisition of Amoco by British Petroleum, sets the stage for a new partnership with large oil-producing countries that could help stabilize prices, but could also curtail the search for oil in countries outside OPEC, where production is more expensive. 
 In essence, these mergers and acquisitions may restore to the international oil companies some of the power they had in the 1950's and 60's, when they were firmly in charge of each facet of the industry, from prospecting for oil to refining it into consumer products.
Now, according to these experts, the consolidating giants will regain control with the willing cooperation of some big OPEC members, which have been financially squeezed by the collapse of oil prices. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and several other countries are now actively seeking the help of the big international companies to keep their energy industries going.
"At the margin, these mergers are not good news for OPEC, or at least all of OPEC's members," said Lawrence Goldstein, president of the New York-based Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "They force everyone to be a player. They increase the relative power of buyers against those who sell oil, and they create room for even more savings and more cash to play with by the oil companies. Exxon and Mobil together will need less inventories, less gas stations, less pipelines and less people."
Of course, the lower prices are a potent force behind the mergers. Oil prices have plunged about 40 percent this year, reaching a 12-year low this week around $11 a barrel for American crude oil because of the Asian economic crisis, ample supplies and a succession of mild winters.
So the oil companies are consolidating in part to gain further savings in order to keep operating profitably in the face of such low prices.
"Between OPEC and the oil giants, everybody is running around like a chicken with its head cut off, trying to survive in the low-price environment of today," said Amy Myers Jaffe, an energy expert at the James A. Baker Institute for Public Policy in Houston.
"This is a radical shift from the 70's, which saw the ascendancy of OPEC and oil prices that at times zoomed up close to $40 a barrel -- at a time when Big Oil was kicked out of many oil-producing countries and saw its operations nationalized in places like Libya, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Kuwait."
Now, with OPEC unable to stop the fall in prices, big oil-producing countries are asking the giant multinationals to come in and look for oil, inviting joint ventures that only a few years ago they avoided.
Over the last few years Iran, Algeria and the United Arab Emirates have initiated joint ventures with international companies. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait say they are now ready, and Iraq continues to seek the lifting of a United Nations embargo to invite the oil companies to come in as partners.
Yesterday, Texaco's chairman and chief executive, Peter I. Bijur, said he would go to Saudi Arabia tomorrow to explore new business opportunities.
"I'm encouraged by the opening of the mind-set of the Saudis," he said.
Roger Diwan, director of global oil markets for the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting group in Washington, said the growing collaboration between multinational companies and OPEC nations was likely to dampen the companies' interest in developing production in remote, landlocked regions like Central Asia, where crude oil is relatively expensive to produce and transport.
"It would be absurd," Mr. Diwan said, "for American oil companies to spend huge capital trying to get oil or gas from Central Asia, building pipelines to transport it and shipping it at costs ranging from $6 to $12 a barrel when they can move huge volumes of oil from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iran on tankers at costs of $2 to $5 a barrel."
For OPEC's 11 members, the picture will be mixed, Mr. Diwan noted. The big producing nations, with billions of barrels in reserves, are seeing the advantages of using the distribution and marketing resources of the international companies to move large volumes of oil. And countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are attractive to the companies because the oil there can be cheaply produced in great quantities.
As such, the beneficiaries will include Saudi Arabia, which is exporting eight million barrels a day, as well as Iran, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and, in time perhaps, Iraq -- all of which are capable of exporting at least two million barrels a day. All but Iraq have invited large companies to come in and discuss joint ventures.
The losers are likely to be producers like Venezuela, Indonesia, Nigeria and Mexico, which have relatively less in reserve and more expensive oil or, in the case of Mexico, have resisted the idea of joint ventures in favor of building up their own national oil companies as world operators.
Other big losers are likely to be smaller oil companies that emerged in the last two decades to prospect for oil when it was expensive enough to make money.
Many of them are likely to retrench or even go out of business, leaving oil in the ground that has become too expensive to be worth the effort of extracting it. This is particularly so in an environment where oil prices have fallen as steeply as in half over the last two years.
Mr. Diwan estimates that in the last year, the use of drilling rigs in the United States has dropped to less than 55 percent today from 100 percent, suggesting that fewer companies are looking for oil.
This decline in exploration and production is good for OPEC as a whole, Mr. Diwan declared. For years now, the smaller companies have brought more oil onto the market, competing with OPEC production.
Of all the OPEC countries, Saudi Arabia stands by far as the biggest possible beneficiary from the Exxon-Mobil and British Petroleum-Amoco deals. The Saudis have long had close and friendly relationships with large United States oil companies -- ties that have repeatedly paid off.
"We always like our friends to flourish in the oil business," said Hassan Yassin, a Saudi businessman with oil interests. "Exxon, Texaco, Chevron and Mobil have been good friends of Saudi Arabia for decades. It is natural they will be first in line and the bigger they are, the better it is for us."
Abdelsamad al-Awadi, European marketing director for the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation in London, agreed.
"There is no question consolidation of the oil industry is a good thing for most of us," he said in an interview. "Our area in the gulf region has been neglected. The big companies will have the money, and we have the oil."
The emerging relationship between the multinational companies and OPEC is different in important ways from the one the companies had in the 50's, 60's and 70's. Now, commercial needs are the primary motivation, whereas in the past relationships were driven by geopolitics.
The change is important to OPEC, an organization that also came to power out of nationalistic concerns.
"We are now open to joint ventures," said Nordine Ait-Laoussine, former oil minister of Algeria who played the major role in 1993 and 1994 in opening the door to foreign oil companies to Algeria.
