HEADLINE: BIG OIL: THE WORKERS;
Despite Prospect of Job Cuts, Mobil Workers Are Largely Unfazed

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The lights are not going out at the Mobil Corporation's headquarters now that the Exxon Corporation has agreed to buy the company. They have just become more colorful. 
 At Mobil's corporate headquarters in the Washington suburb of Fairfax, Va., today, the day after the largest corporate merger in history was announced, employees were greeted by the company's 21-foot Christmas tree blazing with the sort of large lights that were popular in the 1950's.
Even though 9,000 jobs, about 7 percent of Exxon and Mobil's combined work force of 122,700, are expected to be cut as a result of the merger, the mood of Mobil employees was not gloomy.
Workers seemed festive at the company cafeteria, where Wiener schnitzel was the lunch special. One employee even joked to a colleague: "Where's your tiger shirt?" referring to Exxon's mascot.
The 2,000-plus people working at Mobil's Fairfax campus are not too worried about losing their jobs. One reason is that if the merger is approved by regulators, the Mobil campus would become the headquarters for the combined company's global "downstream" operations, which covers retail gasoline and lubricant sales, as well as refining.
That means overseeing 48,500 gasoline stations and 50 refineries producing 6.1 million barrels of petroleum products a day, said Bob Cummings, a Mobil spokesman.
Workers who do lose their jobs will get four weeks of pay for every year worked at Mobil, double the company's normal severance package.
A lot of that extra pay would go to Mobil's high-level employees of "upstream" operations, involving oil exploration and production, who would not be needed in Fairfax, Mr. Cummings said.
They could be offered jobs at the merged company's office in Houston, which will oversee upstream operations or relocated to international offices, or they could get severance packages.
Mobil's president, Eugene Renna, held two forums with employees on Tuesday to discuss the merger. He said that while there would be job cuts, he did not know where they would occur. "It's total speculation at this point," Mr. Cummings said.
At other locations around the world where Mobil has large numbers of employees, including London, Tokyo, Singapore and Calgary, Alberta, Mobil executives flew in from company headquarters with similar messages.
Workers also saw an eight-minute message from Mobil's chairman and chief executive, Lucio A. Noto, which was taped early Sunday morning, in which he announced that Exxon and Mobil had agreed to the terms of a merger. (Mr. Noto and Exxon's chairman and chief executive, Lee R. Raymond did not actually sign the $80 billion deal until 8:45 A.M. E.S.T. on Monday.)
In his taped message, Mr. Noto, who wore a sweater and slacks instead of a business suit, said the merger would not be without pain but that he would seek to minimize the impact on employees.

HEADLINE: A Call to Unite Arms For Europe;
But Efforts to Consolidate Run Into French Resistance

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Even as global pressures drive Europe to a tighter single market and a new single currency, similar pressures are forcing a consolidation of the weapons and aviation industries.
European leaders recognize that with the fall of Communism, their military needs are radically different. And the emergence of American giants like Boeing, Raytheon and Lockheed Martin creates a new competitive landscape. So these leaders envision the arms and aircraft industries from each nation uniting in a single, highly efficient, all-purpose conglomerate. 
 Progress toward this goal has been glacial, but it is still creating tremendous strains, especially in France. Aerospatiale, France's aerospace and arms group, is about to be transformed from a state company to a private one for the sole purpose of qualifying to join this Continent-wide behemoth, but Yves Michot, its chairman and chief executive, is not entirely happy with how the process is unfolding.
"If we want to merge together, we need to have each other's full confidence," he said. And Mr. Michot has not found that comfort level. Like many in France, he objected to the way foreign business leaders, notably those at British Aerospace and DaimlerChrysler Aerospace, a unit of the German industrial giant DaimlerChrysler, had threatened to snub the French if they did not cooperate.
And even if Europe pulls off the creation of the conglomerate, tentatively known as the European Aerospace and Defense Company, some experts, fearing a monopoly that would stifle competition, wonder whether it should.
"I do not like a world in which you have three large United States integrated contractors -- Boeing, Raytheon and Lockheed -- and one in Europe," said John M. Deutsch, a former United States Under Secretary of Defense. A single European contractor, he said, would "essentially not be competitive."
Far from fighting off antitrust regulators, though, Europe's military industries are getting encouragement from their governments. Competition is assured, the companies argue, given the huge American presence in the European arms and aviation market.
American companies have always done a booming military business in Europe. During the cold war, many European countries, particularly smaller nations like the Netherlands and Belgium, bought United States fighter aircraft and weapons systems. European industry leaders, including the French, deny they want anything like a Fortress Europe now.
American arms companies, of course, went through a similar, though less extreme, consolidation. European executives like to talk about the "Last Supper," a 1993 gathering at which Les Aspin, then the United States Defense Secretary, sketched out for industry leaders the Pentagon's view of the future, one in which a few contractors would divide a curtailed Pentagon budget.
Yet in Europe, the process has been reversed, with executives at British Aerospace and DaimlerChrysler pushing their agenda on often reluctant governments.
Nowhere has that reluctance been more evident than in France. The prospect of marring the prestige of a French national industry, not to mention losing jobs, is creating a fierce conflict that pits French traditions against the harsh realities of a globalizing world.
But the process has most definitely begun. In November, Dassault Aviation Group announced that it would transfer the Government's stake, 46 percent, to Aerospatiale. The plan involving Dassault, a maker of Mirage and Rafale military jets and Falcon business jets, was announced in July, but it took months to get the approval of Serge Dassault, the company's 73-year-old chief executive and controlling shareholder.
This follows a decision in July by the Government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, after months of debate, to push the Government's stake in Aerospatiale below 50 percent and bring in the big weapons and publishing group Lagardere as the leading private shareholder.
By this week, after separate French-German and French-British Government consultations about recasting the military industry, Paris appeared to have dropped its fundamental insistence on a simultaneous three-way merger, clearing the path for a gradual two-by-two process, including some form of union between British Aerospace and DaimlerChrysler, to be followed by a link with Aerospatiale and Lagardere's Matra military business.
Aerospatiale has excellent products and advanced technology, though past Government largess produced a company rich in technology but inefficient and unaccustomed to the notion of shareholder value. "Ten years ago, the Government told Aerospatiale not to make profits but to make products," said Philippe Gossard of Credit Lyonnais Securities in Paris. The numbers show that productivity has sagged. Last year, each of Aerospatiale's 37,000 employees generated $297,000 of revenue, against $326,000 for British Aerospace's 46,000 employees.
For France's partners at British Aerospace and DaimlerChrysler, both owned by shareholders, getting government out of the business is an essential first step.
"Our demand is that future shareholders be of the same sort and share the same goals," said Wolfgang Piller, a strategy chief at DaimlerChrysler. Sir Richard Evans, chairman of British Aerospace, agrees. The group should feature a highly fragmented shareholder base, he said recently, adding that for the Germans and British, there should be no government ownership.
Industry leaders are also urging European governments to end centuries of fragmentation and form common military and security policies, including weapons procurement. "Combine your purchasing power," Mr. Piller said, "and you will have all the influence necessary."
Mr. Michot readily acknowledges that the changes at Aerospatiale must go forward. "It's not a problem of whether big is beautiful or small is beautiful," he said in an interview, "but projects are more and more sophisticated, and bigger and bigger companies are needed."
What he acknowledges less readily is that Aerospatiale needs reorganizing. It is, after all, no slouch. It has a 37.9 percent stake in Airbus Industrie, the efficient, profitable consortium that despite bitter competition from Boeing grabbed half the worldwide orders this year for commercial jets. The Ariane rocket program, a joint European undertaking in which Aerospatiale is the primary contractor, controls 50 percent of the market for satellite launchings, a business expected to be worth $60 billion over the next decade.
Yet some activities, like missiles, lose money, while others, like a stake in ATR, a maker of turboprop aircraft, face an uncertain future. Ariane itself may prove to be a white elephant, as smaller and cheaper satellite launchers enter the market.
Some experts even question whether Mr. Michot, 57, an aeronautical engineer with decades of experience as a Government adviser on weapons programs, is the man to do the reorganizing. Indeed, part of the reason for bringing in Lagardere was to tap the group's thick-skinned managers, like Philippe Camus, its 50-year-old chief executive. The challenges facing the merger appear not to have escaped Lagardere's investors, about 40 percent of whom are American and British investment funds: after the July announcement, the shares lost nearly half their value, though they have since recovered much of that.
Yet the French willingness to accept private solutions by bringing in Lagardere and Dassault shows their flexibility. And Mr. Michot says it can go further. Mr. Jospin's Government, he said, which originally insisted on a permanent Government minority stake in Aerospatiale, and hence in the new European arms company, is now pragmatic. "If I go back with a good idea, the consequence of which is a new decrease in the Government stake," he said, "they are ready to examine it."
Such French pragmatism, experts say, illustrates how even rigid political positions are yielding to the realities of international competition.
Meanwhile, discussion of a common European security policy is reviving, and the process is expected to accelerate when the euro, the European single currency, begins in January. Finance ministers from the 11 countries that will adopt the euro meet regularly to formulate common economic policies, and this month the 15 military ministers of the European Union began similar meetings.
"If we have common grounds for our prosperity," said Holger H. Mey, director of the Institute for Strategic Analyses in Bonn, "then shouldn't we have a common security policy?"
But if that is the long-term goal, what drives the current change is the onslaught of the American giants -- Boeing, Raytheon and Lockheed Martin. In 1987, the United States had 22 percent of the $85 billion world arms market; by this year, the market had shrunk to $40 billion, but the United States share had climbed to 55 percent, though in dollar terms it had risen only from $19 billion, to $22 billion.
Late last year, Governments in France, Britain and Germany endorsed the idea for a unified company; the plan has since been supported by Spain, Italy and Sweden.
Yet some experts caution that seeking to merge the industries of three or even six countries at once will be almost impossible. Nor has the global economic slowdown made the task easier. This week, Boeing said the downturn in Asia would force it to trim production of commercial jets beginning next year and to cut as many as 20,000 more jobs in the next two years than it had earlier indicated.
Speaking recently to British industrialists, Sir Richard of British Aerospace checked off just some of the thornier choices facing such a company, including where production sites should be and where to put groupwide units, like finance and central management.
Moreover, as industries are merged, jobs will disappear. Deciding who remains will be particularly difficult, since Europe's unemployment rate remains at least double that of the United States.
"Where there are two partners, it is difficult, but just achievable," said John Dowdy of McKinsey & Company's military industry group in London. He described the American industry consolidation, with its two-by-two mergers, as the "Noah's Ark formation." But "when you add three or four or more, it becomes exponentially more difficult," he said.
John Weston, British Aerospace's chief executive, said the Pentagon's decision earlier this year to block Lockheed Martin's bid for Northrop Grumman might have signaled the start of an American search for trans-Atlantic partnerships.
Mr. Michot agreed, adding that Europe must be prepared for such alliances. Europe's goal, he said, is not to circle the wagons but "to create conditions in which we are on a level field with the United States."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
AS EXPECTED, KELLOGG WILL CUT 765 JOBS IN NORTH AMERICA

 BODY:
In a widely expected move intended to help revive its ailing cereal business, the Kellogg Company said yesterday that it would dismiss 525 salaried employees from its North American operations and would eliminate 240 of about 600 contracted positions. Kellogg, the maker of Rice Krispies and Frosted Flakes, said it would take a one-time charge against fourth-quarter profits of $45 million, or 11 cents a share, to pay for the job cuts, which the company expects will reduce annual expenses by about $105 million. Those savings would help offset increased spending on product development and promotions. Kellogg said most of the jobs to be eliminated would come from its headquarters in Battle Creek, Mich. The company's stock fell 93.75 cents, to $36.375.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Clemens Demands To Be Traded

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
When Roger Clemens was a free agent two years ago, he shunned two teams that had been, and would continue to be, legitimate contenders, the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians. Now, after winning his fourth and unprecedented fifth Cy Young awards but no championships with the Toronto Blue Jays, Clemens wants to be traded to a contender.
The 36-year-old pitcher made that request yesterday through his agent, and the Blue Jays, adhering to a verbal commitment made two years ago, said they would comply. Gord Ash, the team's general manager, said he wanted to move as quickly as possible, in the next week to 10 days. 
 "I'd say I'm on a fast track with this," Ash said by telephone from Toronto. "There are so many other things going on with free agents and other deals, we need to have this clarified before we move on."
After speaking with Clemens's agent, Randy Hendricks, Ash wasted no time. He immediately contacted the Yankees, Cleveland, Texas and Houston, teams, he said, that had shown the strongest interest in the pitcher, dating to last July. He said he expected to talk to other teams as soon as the news spread.
Ash said that Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, told him that he would have to talk to George Steinbrenner and would get back to him.
"They were very interested at the trade deadline, so one could assume they still are," Ash said.
The Indians, Rangers and Astros, he added, all said they were very interested and would be in touch with him.
Cashman said the Yankees would discuss a possible offer for Clemens.
"You're always interested in a guy like Roger Clemens," Cashman said last night. "Whether it's a realistic and viable option is another story. We've had conversations about Rocket during the season and the early part of the winter, but they weren't sure what they were doing. We'll talk about it."
Now the Blue Jays know what they're doing. "We'll be looking for players who could help us at the major league level now," Ash said. "Prospects aren't going to work. We're going to need at least some pitching back, but I want to be open-minded about this. I don't want to predetermine what it will take. I want to see what the offers are."
Given that the Rangers, Astros and Indians have all been seeking pitching to bolster their staffs, the Yankees would seem to be in the best position to include a starting pitcher because they have six. But would the Blue Jays really trade Clemens to a team in their division?
"We've debated that," Ash said. "I don't see that as a roadblock. What we have to concentrate on is getting the best possible deal. If that presents itself from within the division, that would be unusual, but you have to do what you have to do both short and long term."
Clemens has two years left on the contract he signed in January 1997, after Paul Beeston, then the club's president, convinced him that the Blue Jays would be a contender. Clemens, whom the Boston Red Sox let leave as a free agent because they viewed him as an aging pitcher, accepted the Toronto offer because he felt the environment there would be best for his family.
Ash and his two assistants, Tim McCleary and Dave Stewart, visited Clemens at his home in the Houston area recently to discuss the Blue Jays' economic and competitive circumstances, and his decision stemmed from that discussion. "We laid out our game plan, why we think we're competitive," Ash related. "Dave laid out the San Diego situation, how they won without having a huge payroll."
The Blue Jays, owned by a Belgian brewery, Interbrew, had a $34 million payroll last season, and expect to reach the mid-40's for next season. Clemens has been outspoken about Toronto's refusal to offer a lucrative contract to Jose Canseco, who hit 46 home runs for the team last year.
"Roger is driven by the one thing he's not accomplished in this game, a ring," Ash said, referring to a World Series ring. "And if he can't get a ring, he wants to play close to home."
Clemens has an $8 million salary for next season and $8,125,000 for 2000, salaries that seem quite reasonable by current standards.
The right-hander had only a 40-39 record in his last four seasons with the Red Sox, but he has been the American League's best pitcher with the Blue Jays. He won his fifth Cy Young award this year after compiling a 20-6 record, producing the league's lowest earned run average, 2.65, and leading the league in strikeouts with 271, the third-highest total of his career. He won his last 15 decisions after losing on May 29.

HEADLINE: The Latin Arms Explosion That Fizzled

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: CARTAGENA, Colombia, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Sixteen months ago, the Clinton Administration lifted a de facto ban on sales of the most advanced American weapons to countries in Latin America, and many feared the change would unleash a flood of fighter jets and other sophisticated weaponry into a region still haunted by rivalries and political instability.
But nothing happened. 
 The wave of arms sales that many predicted -- for better (more exports for American arms makers) or worse (a dangerous arms race) -- has not materialized. And with the economic slowdown that hit Asia last year still rippling around the world, there are few signs that any country in South or Central America will soon be able to afford the sophisticated weapons.
Chile, whose interest in buying as many as 24 F-16 fighter jets in large part prompted the Administration to reverse the prohibitions, has now put off its purchase indefinitely. Chile's Defense Minister, Jose Florencio Guzman, today placed the blame squarely on "the international financial crisis."
"Until that situation is clear, we are not going to be in a position to make a decision," Mr. Guzman said in an interview on the closing day of a conference of defense ministers from the Americas in this Caribbean city.
Only one other country, Ecuador, has even expressed an interest in purchases. But the State Department, which controls foreign sales of military equipment, made it clear late last year that Ecuador would not be considered until it resolved its border dispute with Peru. It did so this year, but since then neither Ecuador nor any other country has applied to the State Department and none are expected to do so soon, officials said.
In fact, in three days of meetings, cocktail parties and other functions at this week's conference, the issue was never seriously discussed, American officials said. Chile's thwarted plans did not even come up at a meeting today between Mr. Guzman and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen.
"It's not something on my agenda," Mr. Cohen said on the eve of the meetings.
Pentagon and Administration officials portray what has happened as a vindication of President Clinton's decision to lift the ban, which was imposed by President Carter in 1978 to deny modern weaponry to the military dictatorships that then held sway in most of the region.
Mr. Clinton reversed the policy at the urging of the Pentagon, which viewed arms sales as a way to shore up American manufacturers and help Latin American countries make their militaries more modern and professional. Officials argued that the reawakening democracies in Latin America had matured enough to be treated like other countries around the world by resolving their territorial disputes and establishing civilian control over their militaries.
"There was all this controversy" about the impact of the change, said Peter Romero, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, who attended the conference. "It hasn't panned out. That has to do with a couple of things. One, there's peace in the region, and two, these militaries are looking at this in the long term, as part of their modernization plans."
Others, however, point to hard economic realities, which have depressed sales globally, especially for aircraft manufacturers like Boeing and Lockheed Martin.
Over the last year, a number of Latin American countries, including Brazil, have had to rethink plans to modernize their forces because of the economic crises. Chile has seen a debilitating drop in the price of copper, one of its leading sources of revenue.
"The fact that there's no major sale is as much a result of economics as a result of policy," said Richard F. Grimmett, an analyst for the Congressional Research Service who monitors the international arms trade. "Despite the window shopping that a lot of them do, they don't have the resources."
The executive order that President Carter signed in 1978 did not represent an absolute ban on sales of advanced weaponry but required the State Department to consider prospective sales with "a presumption of denial." Still, the United States granted approval for only one major sale during the whole time the restrictions were in effect: President Reagan let Venezuela buy two dozen F-16's in 1981, citing a threat from Communist Cuba.
As a region, Latin America spends less on the military than any other part of the world, and the market for high-tech sales has always been viewed as relatively modest, ranging from $500 million to $2 billion a year at most.
But arms manufacturers lobbied for the change in policy since several countries, including Chile, Argentina, Brazil and Peru, were in the market for weapons and, increasingly, looking to European makers.
Byron Callan, an aerospace analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, said militaries in Latin America often face internal threats not easily attacked with supersonic fighters and air-to-air missiles.
In the years ahead, he said, these countries are more likely to want more mundane equipment, like trucks and transport helicopters, which were never covered by the ban.
"The most pressing problems they seem to have are internal rebel movements and drug traffickers," Mr. Callan said. "They may not necessarily need multirole combat aircraft."

HEADLINE: Remove Threat of Prosecuting the President

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Safire ("King of Chutzpah," column, Nov. 30) implies that the American people are in no mood to impeach the President because "the market is booming" but that in "two years hence, we could be in a recession, with people finding fault. A missile from a rogue nation could remind us who opposed a missile defense." 
 The American people are smart enough to recognize that there is such a thing as over-insurance, that a degree of protection against a missile attack has its price: economic ruin for the country.
 
ATILLA BEKTORE
Flushing, Queens, Nov. 30, 1998

INTERNATIONAL A3-20
 
Bosnian Serb General Is Seized by U.S. Forces
American and allied forces in Bosnia arrested a Bosnian Serb general, Radislav Krstic, who was recently charged with genocide by the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal. The general, the highest-ranking official to be seized, was arrested in the American sector in Bosnia. He is accused of directing the attack on Srebrenica in 1995, in which some 7,000 Bosnian Muslim men were marched off, presumably to their deaths, as a Dutch contingent of United Nations peacekeeping forces stood by. HEADLINE: GIULIANI STIRS UP BORDER TENSIONS WITH TRASH PLAN

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN and DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani triumphantly unveiled a proposal yesterday to ship most of the city's residential garbage to transfer stations in New Jersey, but the administration's glee was quickly muted by an embarrassing lapse in political tact: It did not tell New Jersey of the plan until yesterday morning, and then only in sketchy detail.
At the same time that Mr. Giuliani was proudly discussing how his administration had possibly resolved one of the city's most vexing problems -- the future disposal of its millions of tons of trash -- New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, was issuing a news release that included the headline, "Whitman to New York's Garbage Plan: Drop Dead." 
 "The proposal being promoted by the City of New York is a direct assault on the beaches of New Jersey and a very real threat to our quality of life, especially to the residents of Hudson, Union, Essex and Middlesex Counties," Mrs. Whitman said. She added that she would do everything in her power to block any plan that might harm the state's environment.
The stakes are high for New York City, which must find an alternative to dumping its trash at the largest landfill in the world, Fresh Kills on Staten Island. But Fresh Kills is scheduled to close by the end of 2001, and Mayor Giuliani expressed fears that Federal environmental authorities could shut it down at any time, creating an immediate crisis.
Under the city's plan, it would send nearly 5,900 tons a day of Manhattan and Queens garbage to transfer stations to be built by private contractors in Newark and Carteret, N.J. In addition, a transfer station would be built at the Port of Red Hook in Brooklyn to handle that borough's 3,900 tons of daily trash. Then, after being compacted in air-tight containers at these transfer stations, the garbage would be shipped to privately owned landfills in Virginia, Pennsylvania and other states.
"This plan is a very fair one and a very equitable one," the Mayor said. But by last night, other New Jersey officials had joined the "drop dead" chorus, placing his Deputy Mayor for Operations, Joseph J. Lhota, in the position of defending the plan as environmentally sound but apologizing for its delivery. Mr. Lhota had informed an aide to Mrs. Whitman of the city's plans just hours before the Mayor's announcement.
"It is our fault, and not Governor Whitman's, that she did not understand New York City's environmentally sound plan for long-term solid waste management," Mr. Lhota said in a statement. "The Governor and her staff were not adequately briefed in a complete manner."
In a brief interview last night, Mr. Lhota said he felt contrition. "No one likes to be surprised, and in this case, the Governor was surprised," he said. "It's my job to make the Governor fully apprised."
The sensitivity of the matter goes beyond the traditional rivalry between New York and New Jersey. Though both are moderate Republicans, Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Whitman have quarreled in the past over several issues, from the rights to Ellis Island to the management of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. And recent history made the city's plan sting all the more; the complaints of Mrs. Whitman in early 1997 forced Mr. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki to postpone a city plan to dump 560 million gallons of raw sewage into New York Harbor.
At his news conference, Mr. Giuliani and his aides had engaged in a little New Jersey humor while detailing where the city's garbage would go. "Does any go to the Meadowlands?" the Mayor joked. When told no, he said: "Too bad. Well, we ought to get even, right? I mean for the Giants and the Jets." The two professional football teams left New York to play in the Meadowlands in New Jersey years ago.
The New Jersey jokes had ended by evening as state, county and local officials in New Jersey criticized the plan. "We will not be the dumping ground for any entity," Mayor Sharpe James of Newark said, "especially since their plans call for bringing this solid waste to a site that is near an area that is undergoing extensive revitalization."
Mrs. Whitman and her aides said their principal worry was that garbage might spill from the city barges on the way to the stations in New Jersey, causing pollution of her state's beaches. She characterized the garbage shipping as "an environmental disaster waiting to happen."
Mr. Giuliani acknowledged that he expected the plan to meet opposition; foes will have forums in numerous environmental and land-use reviews in both states, as well as before the City Council, whose approval is needed for the city's overall waste management plan. But the Mayor emphasized that he intended to meet the legal deadline for the closing of Fresh Kills, a deadline stipulated by the state in 1996.
Mr. Lhota said he hoped the proposed New Jersey stations would come to be seen as an economic blessing, particularly considering that a large incinerator in Essex County was underused and could handle some of the trash intended for Newark under the plan. "It's our hope the Governor would look at this as an economic development project," he said. "We're not dumping garbage in New Jersey."
Jim Tripp, general counsel for the Environmental Defense Fund, said it would be "inexcusable" for any garbage to fall from the barges. But he said New Jersey must regard waste policy as a common interest of the entire region and remember that New Yorkers live with air and water pollution emanating from that state.
But if yesterday's proposals do not work out, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Lhota said, other proposals would be reconsidered, including one to use a Bay Ridge pier that sparked fierce opposition from that Brooklyn neighborhood. "There are numerous backup plans, but this is the one we're proposing today," the Mayor said. "There are other places that are interested in getting our trash."
The other part of the city's two-pronged strategy for dealing with the shutdown of Fresh Kills is to truck garbage out of the city in ever greater amounts until none is going to Staten Island. City officials hope that this interim approach will end in late 2001 or early 2002, the earliest they expect to get their long-term plan working.
Under the city's long-term plans, its fleet of 900 white sanitation trucks would still deliver their garbage to seven marine transfer stations surrounding the city, where it would be put in the same barges that now go to Fresh Kills. But instead of going to Fresh Kills, the barges would take the garbage to the private transfer stations announced yesterday.
The one in Carteret would take 3,900 tons of garbage a day from Queens and the East Side of Manhattan to a station to be built by Browning Ferris Industries on land it has acquired. The waste would be put in containers and exported from Carteret by rail and truck to permitted disposal sites in New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Illinois. Manhattan's remaining 2,000 tons of waste a day would go to a giant transfer station to be built by Eastern Environmental in Newark on land owned by the Port Authority. It would then be shipped by truck and rail to disposal sites in Virginia and New Jersey.
It was unclear last night what steps Governor Whitman might take to oppose the trash sites, including whether she could block the planned Newark station under her powers over the Port Authority. She did say that she would "do everything I can to assure that no permits are granted for facilities" that would imperil New Jersey's environment.
Some initial reaction from New York officials was positive. Stanley E. Michels, chairman of the Council's Environmental Protection Committee, said: "I think it makes a lot of sense. This seems a feasible plan"

HEADLINE: Decisions by U.S. and I.M.F. Worsened Asia's Problems, the World Bank Finds

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The decision last year by the International Monetary Fund and the United States Treasury to push Asian nations to send their interest rates soaring was a crucial blunder that worsened the world financial crisis, the World Bank concluded today in its first history of how the trouble started.
A 200-page report by the bank deliberately omitted any direct reference to the fund or to the Treasury, which has a major voice in fund decisions. The omission, bank officials said, was a conciliatory gesture to both institutions, which have often disagreed with the bank on how to repair the crisis since it began 18 months ago. 
 The bank's blow-by-blow account of a series of cascading misjudgments places much of the blame on global investors who lent money to developing nations with abandon, and on Asian officials who were eager to absorb the cash.
But the study left little doubt that in the bank's judgment the fund and the Clinton Administration shared responsibility for mishandling the initial response to the crisis. The higher interest rates were among many conditions set to permit the countries to get billions of dollars of aid from the I.M.F.
The bank argues that it would have been less harmful to let the currencies fall but keep interest rates low in an effort to revive the economies as quickly as possible. But that choice would have created other difficulties, worsening inflation and perhaps discouraging foreign investors from returning to those markets for years, other economists argue.
The primary responsibility of the World Bank is tending to the poor, with development programs to help them fight poverty and disease. The fund focuses chiefly on economic and monetary policy.
The report predicts that most of the countries involved will probably begin climbing out of their recessions next year, with growth continuing in 2000. But it warns that a rebound is not certain and that "there is still a substantial risk that the world economy will plunge into recession in 1999," particularly if Japan is unable to end its recession.
The report reflects a broader debate among economists and policymakers about whether decisions by the fund and the United States Treasury deepened the crisis and whether the movement in recent years to liberalize financial markets around the world should be dramatically slowed.
It argues that some system should be developed to limit the rush of short-term investments into developing countries that do not have the systems to monitor spending.
"The heart of this current crisis," the chief economist of the bank, Joseph Stiglitz, said today, "is the surge of capital flows. The surge is followed by a precipitous flow out. Few countries, no matter how strong their financial institutions, could have withstood such a turnaround. But clearly the fact that the financial institutions were weak and their firms highly leveraged made these countries particularly vulnerable."
Neither the I.M.F. nor the Treasury, both of which saw the report before it was published, issued comment. There are parts that the agencies agree with. Officials of the fund and the Treasury have often faulted the huge volume of private investment into developing countries, as well as investors' refusal to heed the risks associated with investing in countries with few regulatory safeguards, for creating the conditions that led to the bust. And the officials say no one foresaw the extent of the crisis.
But they continue to defend their initial strategy of urging Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea to raise interest rates, a classic economic solution intended to reassure investors and stabilize currencies. In Thailand and South Korea, interest rates have declined, to about 7 percent, and the currencies have stabilized, developments that fund officials say vindicate their approach.
The bank report argues that the strategy backfired, stabilizing the currencies at the cost of plunging the countries into deep recessions, with substantial unemployment.
The higher interest rate, the study says, spread the economic pain far beyond the banks, investment funds and real estate companies that got the countries into trouble to begin with, sending thousands of small businesses in to bankruptcy.
"Some estimates are that levels of bankruptcy in Indonesia now are 75 percent," Mr. Stiglitz said. "And, you know, you cannot have a country perform with 75 percent of its firms in bankruptcy."
The report was published on the day when the board of the fund formally began its review of the latest bailout, a $41.5 billion aid package to Brazil. It agreed to provide the first installment of an $18.1 billion, three-year loan.
Although the World Bank is a major participant in that bailout, it warned today against the risk of what it termed "rescue creep" as aid packages grow larger and larger. "No reasonable amount of public money can stop a justified speculative attack" on a currency, the World Bank said. "Larger packages worsen moral hazard problems," the risk that investors will expect governments to bail them out, "and may lead to excessively tough conditions, defeating the end objectives."
Their differing mandates have often led the World Bank and the I.M.F. to disagreements. Two months ago Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin warned both institutions that the time had come to put aside their differences. One of the many proposals here Washington to reform the institutions would merge their governing boards, but that would require a marriage of two extremely different cultures.
The fund continues to insist that it made the best judgments it could at a time of tremendous chaos last year, when the Governments of Thailand and South Korea were going through elections and seemed unable to make decisions.
The fund also argues that its program in Indonesia was undermined by the refusal of President Suharto's Government to stick to its economic agreements and then by the chaos that resulted in Mr. Suharto's resignation and continues on the streets.
Yet, at a seminar this week, a senior fund official conceded that the fund had made some judgments "too quickly" and had mistakenly thought that it was seeing a repeat of past currency crises, particularly the one that Mexico had in 1995.
Internally the fund has debated over the last year whether it erred when it loaned Russia $4.8 billion in July, money that was wasted, and whether it unintentionally contributed to a bank panic in Indonesia last year.
Several months ago the first deputy managing director of the fund, Stanley Fischer, said, "In most cases governments call us in only after they discover they are in a mess, usually because they didn't do things they needed to do long ago."
"If the problems were easy to solve," Mr. Fischer said, "they'd do it themselves."
Many of the conclusions in the report are likely to fuel the debate over what to do next. The bank calls for a major slowdown in the movement to deregulate financial markets in developing countries, a reversal of the policy that the fund advocated as late as April 1997, three months before the troubles in Thailand touched off the crisis.
"Financial-sector liberalization," the report adds, "which can significantly boost the risk of crisis, should proceed with care -- fully and in step with the capacity to design and enforce tighter regulation and supervision."
In the last year the fund and the Treasury have begun to take the same stance, stressing the need to build regulatory institutions before opening economies to huge capital flows. The bank praised fund programs in several countries, including their focus on reorganizing corporations and compelling countries, in return for aid, to overhaul bankruptcy systems and inject public money into weak banking systems.
The bank also credited the I.M.F. for loosening the conditions on the bailouts to ease the pain on the poor. But it noted that 17 million more Indonesians are expected to fall below that country's poverty line.

HEADLINE: Grim Assessment by U.N. of Asia Crisis

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The social costs of the Asian economic crisis are far higher than initial estimates and are "dramatically worsening," according to a report here on Tuesday by the International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency.
The I.L.O. said the economic collapse had resulted in a combustible mixture of soaring unemployment, spreading poverty and dashed expectations. The lack of social welfare programs made the hardest-hit countries, like Indonesia, "fertile ground for breeding social unrest." 
 "I would veer to the pessimistic side," said Eddy Lee, an I.L.O. economist, who wrote the report. "The unrest in Indonesia is spilling over into Malaysia. And even where you don't have street riots, there is a tremendous amount of social instability just beneath the surface."
Indonesia has seen violent clashes between soldiers and students and between Christians and Muslims. In Malaysia demonstrators are protesting against Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad for ousting and imprisoning his Deputy Prime Minister.
The report called on governments to increase spending on social programs, particularly unemployment insurance, which is largely unknown in Asia. It likened the current crisis to the Great Depression of the 1930's, which galvanized the United States to weave a social safety net.
"The question we asked was, 'What could people in these countries expect?' " Mr. Lee said. "The answer was, 'Very little.' "
In its bleak tone, the report is starkly at odds with both Asia's resurgent financial markets and other international agencies like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which have focused on the prospects for a rebound.
Mr. Lee said a swift recovery is unlikely, given the deeper than expected recessions in Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea. In Indonesia, the report estimates, economic output will decline 15 percent in 1998, while in Thailand and South Korea it will shrink by 6.5 percent and 5 percent, respectively.
Along with the abrupt loss of commercial activity has come rapidly accelerating unemployment. The report estimates that the crisis has wiped out one-fifth of non-farm jobs in Indonesia this year, a loss that will drive 40 million people, or 20 percent of the population, into poverty.
In Thailand, the report predicts, the unemployment rate will triple, to 6 percent, this year. Even in South Korea, which is perceived as being on the road to recovery, unemployment is expected to jump to 8.2 percent, from 2.3 percent, while 12 percent of Koreans will sink under the poverty line.
"What the crisis has driven home is the consequence of not having stronger social policies," Mr. Lee said.
He noted that of these countries, only South Korea offers even rudimentary unemployment benefits.
Mr. Lee conceded that financially strapped Asian governments did not have the resources to subsidize unemployment insurance on a mass scale. But he said such benefits could be financed with a payroll tax.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show. 

Museums
 
 * "DANCING AT THE LOUVRE: FAITH RINGGOLD'S FRENCH COLLECTION AND OTHER STORY QUILTS," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 3). Faith Ringgold's story quilts are an enchanting blend of fictional tales and paintings, done on stitched canvas bordered by patchwork and, except for recent ones, written narrative. Works from her French Collection depict the fantastical adventures of a young black woman who was an artist in Paris in the 1920's; works from her American Collection deal in a visionary way with the lives of blacks in America. Also on view are earlier quilts, like "Tar Beach" (1988), which portrays a homey nighttime family picnic on a Harlem roof, with a daughter of the family flying over the George Washington Bridge in the background. A vivid sense of history, an audacious imagination and an irrepressible joie de vivre find voice in this lively show. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 P.M.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3 for artists, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
 * "FROM VAN EYCK TO BRUEGEL: EARLY NETHERLANDISH PAINTINGS AT THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 17). A patch of heaven has touched down in Manhattan. This dream of a show is exactly what it says it is: a display of more than a hundred 15th- and 16th-century Flemish paintings representing the bulk of the Met's impressive holdings. Long-hidden pieces have been pulled from storage, and familiar works have been brought together from throughout the museum. And the big news is also old news: the unrivaled genius of the Netherlandish artists and the inventive vitality of a culture that saw the natural and the supernatural worlds as mirror images. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Admission: $8; $4, students and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 * "HEROIC ARMOR OF THE ITALIAN RENAISSANCE: FILIPPO NEGROLI AND HIS CONTEMPORARIES," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 17). Negroli (1510-1579) may not be a household name today, but as the most innovative and celebrated Italian armor maker of his era, he was sought after by aristocrats with a yen for the magnificent suits of steel he fabricated. In this, the first large-scale arms and armor exhibition ever held at the Met, the work of Negroli, members of his sprawling family and fellow armorers in Italy makes a dazzling display. These intricately worked helmets, cuirasses, shields and other showpieces were intended more for parade than battle use. Among the knockout regalia here is an armored equestrian mounted on an armored horse, the only surviving example of Roman-style armor for man and beast. It's a visual feast. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).
 
 * "INSIDE OUT: NEW CHINESE ART," Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742, and P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Jan. 3). Art in China has changed dramatically in the last few decades, and this big, stimulating show gives a sense of vanguard developments on the post-Mao mainland and in Hong Kong and Taiwan and among expatriate Chinese artists in the West. The work ranges from video to Western-inspired Pop painting, from spectacular, room-filling installations to ink scrolls. The messages are complex and contradictory: myth, humor, pessimism and nostalgia rub shoulders, often in a single work. There are ups and downs in this tip-of-the-iceberg showcase, but it's a benchmark event. Asia Society: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays to 8 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. P.S. 1: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $4 to Asia Society, $5 to P.S. 1; $2, students and the elderly, at both (Cotter).
 
 * ROBERT IRWIN: "PART 2: EXCURSUS: HOMAGE TO THE SQUARE 3 ," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 13). The magic of this maze of 18 cubicles, made by dividing Dia's third-floor gallery, lies in its intense distillation of light, color and space. The walls of each room are translucent scrim; each wall bears a double fluorescent bulb whose color is enhanced by white and silvery tones. The bulbs change color from room to room, subtly modulating your perception of the space; at the north and south sides of the building they are augmented by natural light coming in through windows. As you walk through this eloquent labyrinth, which seems to have no end and no beginning, the light shifts and slips from bright, almost full-day illumination to a lovely quiet gloom. Despite Mr. Irwin's declared disinterest in making art as imagery, the installation can't help evoking such environments as a chapel, a Quaker meeting house and a noir film set. However you see it, it's an affecting experience. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $4; $2, students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
 * "JAPONISM AND FASHION: JAPAN DRESSES THE WEST," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 1000 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Feb. 14). This beautiful show is the first to isolate the influence of Japanese culture on European and American fashion. As with most shows devoted to Japonism, it has the feeling of a love affair, of one culture becoming infatuated with, seduced by and then profoundly altered by another. It includes lavish 19th-century evening gowns made in Paris and London from the densely embroidered silks of Japanese kimonos; quilted silk dressing gowns made in Japan for export, and a fascinating range of pieces by 20th-century designers. These run from Madeleine Vionnet, whose influential garments made innovative use of the simple structure of Japanese garments, to Japanese designers like Issey Miyake and Rei Kawakubo, whose fusion of Eastern and Western clothing conventions took international fashion by storm in the early 1980's. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. (until 11 P.M. on the first Saturday of the month); Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $4; $2, students; $1.50, the elderly; free, children under 12 (Roberta Smith).
 
 SHIRIN NESHAT, "Turbulence," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue at 42d Street, (917) 663-2550 (through Jan. 15). For this installation by the Iranian-born Shirin Neshat, two short films are projected on opposite walls. In one a man sings a Sufi devotional hymn for an all-male audience; in the other a veiled woman sings a passionate wordless chant in an empty hall as the camera circles her. The installation refers to the fact that women in Iran, because of Islamic law, are forbidden to perform music in public. But it is really about a wealth of male-female contrasts, suggested through body language, setting, camera work and the music, which is thrilling. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays to 7:30 P.M. Free (Cotter).
 
 * JACKSON POLLOCK, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Feb. 2). A landmark. If you care about art, you live for exhibitions like this, in which an artist, against the heavy odds of his skewed talent and unhinged personality, pursued something so wild, untested and mysterious that its full meaning was unclear even to him, yet who, briefly, wrung from his peculiar system of painting one variation after another. Pollock was a quintessential American because of his aspiration to make something from what seemed like nothing. Sometimes he botched the results, but this was intrinsic to a process that consciously flirted with incoherence: accidents, on which his art depended, had to be held in tension with acts of extreme control, and the exhibition is instructive, among other reasons, for letting you see some of his failures, which by contrast clarify his successes. His biggest triumphs, the classic paintings from 1950, "Autumn Rhythm," "No. 32" and "One," are hung together here so that you can scan them by swiveling your head 180 degrees. It's an amazing sight. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:30 P.M. Admission; $12.50; $9.50 students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
 * "RENDEZVOUS: MASTERPIECES FROM THE CENTRE GEORGES POMPIDOU AND THE GUGGENHEIM MUSEUMS," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 24). With its landmark Paris home under renovation, the cream of the Pompidou collection has hit the road, joining forces with the Guggenheim's in an unusual, perhaps unprecedented exhibition that fills the Fifth Avenue building to the brim. The familiar story of modernism is told, but in contrasting voices and with a cornucopia of unfamiliar works and telling juxtapositions. Not to be missed. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $12; $7, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * "ROYAL PERSIAN PAINTINGS: THE QAJAR EPOCH, 1785-1925," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 24). Think "Persian painting" and what comes to mind? Small illuminated miniatures with diminutive landscapes and teensy figures. But the Qajar emperors thought big. They liked their portraits life-size, their battle scenes Cinemascopic. Even their collectibles -- lacquered boxes, gilded enamels -- have a trumpeting, clear-the-way flair, like props in a Handel opera. This extraordinary show is the first major Western survey of a self-promotional dynastic art of almost hallucinatory strangeness and brilliance. It holds many surprises, none more mesmerizing than the power portraits of the ruler Fath Ali Shah: with his dainty, high-heeled slippers, extravagant beard and Napoleonic hauteur, he projects a preposterous, inimitable glamour. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
 * "SACRED ARTS OF HAITIAN VODOU," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through Jan. 3). The 500 objects in this exhibition -- shimmering, sequined flags, plaster Madonnas, medicine packets wrapped like Christmas gifts, miniature coffins, carved wooden drums -- weave African, European and indigenous New World influences together in an art of visceral excitement and disquieting beauty. The installation is expertly organized. It begins with paintings depicting the growth of Vodou among African slaves in the Caribbean. (The show avoids the Anglicized voodoo, with its history of racist associations, in favor of the Creole Vodou.) And it concludes with three big, glamorous, assemblage-style altars that catch the essence of what this religion is: a magnificent, spiritual tour de force. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Admission: $8; $6, students and the elderly; $4.50, children (Cotter).
 
 * "SACRED VISIONS: EARLY PAINTINGS FROM CENTRAL TIBET," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 17). Bringing together well-known and little-seen masterpieces, many newly cleaned, this stunning exhibition of 60 thankas, or paintings on cloth, is the first attempt to trace the blossoming of one of the world's great medieval painting styles as it emerged between 1150 and 1450 in central Tibet. Images of beatific Buddhas and extravagantly wrathful deities abound, as do portraits of monks and abbots, most of them accompanied by extensive entourages of smaller figures and set in elaborate architectural compositions. With its smoldering colors, exquisite rendering and religious fervor, this exhibition lies at the center of the museum like the molten core of a blast furnace and is one of the must-see events of the season. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 BOB THOMPSON, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Jan. 3). This radiant exhibition of 100 works from 1959 to 1966 traces the brief headlong career of Thompson (1937-1966), a black American artist and one of the rising stars of the early 1960's. He lived hard and died young, and was also tremendously productive. Trips to Europe fired his enthusiasm for the Old Masters, whose religious and mythological themes and compositions he modernized with flat, bright color. These reds, blues and yellows also functioned metaphorically, implying a multiracial world alternately pastoral and violent in mood. Thompson died too early to achieve greatness, and as the middle of the exhibition demonstrates, his paintings could be simultaneously formulaic and hesitant. But there are several remarkable works here, especially his small paintings and studies. And the biggest painting, "Garden of Music" (1960), may be his masterpiece. Hours: Wednesdays, and Fridays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $9; $7, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
 * ARSHILE GORKY, "Paintings and Drawings 1929-1942," Gagosian, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Jan. 9). This small, museum-quality show makes an excellent companion to the Pollock retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Here we see Gorky still working mostly in Picasso's shadow but beginning to discover -- in "Garden in Sochi," for example, a delicate, surrealistic mindscape from 1942 -- the gravitationally liberated space and elegant line that characterize his great works of the mid-1940's (Ken Johnson).
 
 * HENRI MATISSE, C&M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020 (through Dec. 12). Celebrated as one of the 20th century's greatest painters, Matisse (1869-1954) also produced some daringly innovative sculpture. Breaking with centuries of European tradition, he viewed sculpture not in pictorial terms but as self-referential, i.e., it should not express anything but its substance, existing as a process rather than a representation. Paring down heads to their essence, shaping bodies by means of rhythmic forms, incorporating stylized elements of African art, he freed his work from the traditional European emphasis on anatomical credibility, exerting a crucial influence on 20th-century sculpture (Glueck).
 
 * SIGMAR POLKE, "New Paintings, Printing Mistakes," Michael Werner Gallery, 21 East 67th Street, (212) 988-1623 (through Jan. 16). This German painter is a major artist who has never really taken off in the United States. He's an antimastery master who produces a post-epiphany, post-ego painting, an impure hybrid that mixes ideas and formal ploys like so many chemical additives. His works preserve a tradition, and they also turn it into something else. That something else can be sampled in this show of two dozen strange, beautiful, sort-of-abstract new paintings based partly on newspaper misprints (Cotter).
 
 * ED RUSCHA, Richard Gray, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 472-8787 (through Dec. 12). No one confounded the verbal and the visual with more economically inventive wit during the 1960's and 70's than Ed Ruscha. This show gives a good account of that period. "Eye Infection" (1967) is spelled out in illusionistic ribbon; the medium is gunpowder. In "Faith" (1972), modernistic letters are cut in white out of a dark red, Rothko-esque space, setting up an understated collision between Romanticism and irony (Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
 ROSS BLECKNER, Mary Boone, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 752-2929 (through Dec. 19). The uptown segment of a two-gallery exhibition shows the artist continuing to cultivate a dazzling new painting technique that is responsible for the relatively impressive paintings in the show's downtown half in SoHo. Here, he seems to have shifted into overproduction, adding pleasing color and a surface slickness that pushes the abstract toward the Photo Realist (Smith).
 
 JAMES DE LA VEGA, Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street, (212) 307-7420 (through Dec. 23). For his first New York solo, this young artist has brought indoors the tape drawing technique (figures outlined in strips of masking tape and spray painted) that he executes on the streets of East Harlem, and they look good. St. Lazarus leaps from one wall; a Last Supper of chattering skeletons fills another. More of Mr. de la Vega's work can be seen outdoors in the neighborhood around East 103d Street and Lexington Avenue (Cotter)
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
 ROSS BLECKNER, Lehmann Maupin, 39 Greene Street, (212) 965-0753 (through Dec. 19). The downtown segment of a two-gallery exhibition includes big, beautiful grisaille abstractions whose strikingly optical cell-like patterns (a result of careful use of an airbrush) count as some of the most convincing images Mr. Bleckner has made. The artist's political conscience has been relegated to a series of high-minded photo appropriations that seem about 20 years too late (Smith).
 
 * "WILLEM DE KOONING: DRAWING SEEING/SEEING DRAWING," the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166; "Willem de Kooning: Drawings and Sculpture," Matthew Marks Gallery, 523 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 243-0200, and Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 79th Street, (212) 744-7400 (all through Dec. 19). These three shows don't pretend to add up to a survey of de Kooning's drawings, but they have fine stuff and lots of it: high-spirited warm-ups for paintings, ultra-refined finished pieces, all manner of glorious doodles. The Drawing Center show is thematically the most coherent and includes a series of fascinating Crucifixions. The other shows highlight links between drawings and sculptures, of which several are on view. It's great to have all this coincide with the Pollock retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art (Cotter).
 
 KIM DINGLE, Sperone Westwater, 142 Greene Street, (212) 431-6835 (through Dec. 19). This Los Angeles artist, known for paintings and sculptures featuring malevolent schoolgirls and toddlers called Prisses, is making her subjects behave themselves, and the shift from truly nasty to just naughty indicates that her work is formally pallid and unadventurous. Best is an installation in which two Prisses break through a plaster wall like Supergirl-cherub, but even that wouldn't be out of place in a Christmas store window on Fifth Avenue (Smith).
 
 JACKIE FERRARA, "Red Arches," Frederieke Taylor/TZ'Art Gallery, 470 Broome Street, (212) 966-9059 (through Dec. 24). Known for her site sculptures and large public commissions, Ms. Ferrara uses an austere vocabulary of Minimalist forms to build architectural structures. They can be useful or purely sculptural, but are in any case admirable for their subtle geometries. For this show she has redone the gallery's walls in a design of large, repetitive arches, made entirely of flat segments of birch plywood and rounded off at the top by stepping back the plywood segments in ziggurat fashion. Arches and wall are of one flatness, but the arches also stand out by virtue of their pinkish staining against the walls' lighter tones. Like the walls of a Moorish harem, they bestow a soft, sensuous effect on the entire space (Glueck).
 
 * KAHN/SELESNICK, "The Circular River: Panoramic Photographs, Siberian Expeditions, 1944-1946," Monique Knowlton, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-2625 (through Jan. 9). Nicholas Kahn and Richard Selesnick produce elaborately staged, faux antique photographs. Each of the 59 pictures from their most recent project is a sepia-toned, six-foot-long panoramic print that purports to document an expedition to Siberia undertaken in the mid-1940's. Together with its lengthy journalistic text, it's a funny, Monty Python-esque parody of the generic scientific adventure narrative (Johnson).
 
 "MOUSE: AN AMERICAN ICON," Alternative Museum, 594 Broadway, at Houston Street, (212) 966-4444 (through Dec. 19). This selection of works by 24 artists, every one featuring a more or less politicized image of Mickey Mouse, has a few good things in it. In Luis Camnitzer's "Reality Check," a real stuffed mouse has been absurdly equipped with round Mickey ears; John Fawcett's drawn and collaged mixes of pop culture and hallucinogenic Mickeys are dizzyingly complicated; Jaune Quick-to-See Smith's "McFlag," which sports big, round, earlike speakers at each upper corner, is a strident takeoff on Jasper Johns's iconic "Flag" (Johnson).
 
 "PSYCHOARCHITECTURE," Richard Prince and Martin Kippenberger, Anton Kern Gallery, 558 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 965-1706 (through Dec. 19). Kippenberger, a German jack-of-all-media artist who died in 1997, favored found materials; Mr. Prince, an American appropriationist fascinated by this country's obsessions, preferred the pre-existing image. This oddly personal display of their photographs reveals a shared interest in what might be called the architectural unconscious, the frayed edges where modernity's failed dream is especially visible. Mr. Kippenberger tended toward details of decaying concrete buildings that resemble his sculpture; Mr. Prince, toward upstate yards and driveways populated only by forlorn basketball hoops and infused with the desolation and dysfunction so familiar to his art (Smith).
 
 SAM REVELES, CRG, 93 Grand Street, (212) 966-4360 (through Dec. 19). Paintings in which Old Masterism and new abstraction are dissonantly layered. Mr. Reveles begins each work with a pale, unfinished pastiche of Italian Primitive, Renaissance or Indian painting, over which he paints dense, scribbly passages that almost completely obliterate the underlying imagery. At this point, the relationship between the two modes seems more frustrated than fruitful (Johnson).
 
 ALAN UGLOW, Stark Gallery, 113 Crosby Street, (212) 925-4484 (through Dec. 19). A painter of seemingly purist abstractions flirts curiously with content. Mr. Uglow's pristine stripe paintings evoke tennis courts or soccer fields, an association he affirms by installing a neat little shed and bench for soccer players, complete with soccer commentary broadcast by hidden speakers. There are also photographs of soccer fields and stadiums. It all leaves one confused about what the paintings are supposed to mean (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
 WILLIAM COTTON, Silverstein, 520 West 21st Street, (212) 929-4300 (through Dec. 23). Paintings of low-income dwellings -- trailers, high-rise projects, worker housing and the Unabomber's cabin in Montana -- made to look as though they were constructed of candy, gingerbread, cookies and frosting. The tension between grim reality and confectionery fantasy is interesting, but the nondescript way the pictures are painted undermines the impact (Johnson).
 
 MONIQUE PRIETO, Pat Hearn Gallery, 530 West 22d Street, (212) 727-7366 (through Dec. 23). Working with a computer, Ms. Prieto generates shapes of blobby, biomorphic contour, then paints them flatly in bright, toylike colors on fields of raw canvas without any hint of shading or perspective. Her antecedents seem to be Pop; the work has suggestions of the commercial bustle of elements in Pop Art, and the bam-splat bursts in cartoon imagery. They are smart and knowing, if not particularly consequential (Glueck).
 
Other Galleries
 
 GREGORY CRANE, Cheryl Pelavin, 13 Jay Street, lower Manhattan, (212) 925-9424 (through Dec. 31). At his best, in magically real, panoramic views of semirural Hudson Valley landscapes, Mr. Crane creates the feeling of seeing the world through the eyes of someone -- an Emerson or a Thoreau -- in a transcendentally (or psychedelically) elevated consciousness. Color and paint are lush; smoke plumes, rainbows and odd clouds animate the sky and a visionary light transforms mundane reality (Johnson).
 
 CHARLEY FRIEDMAN, CRP, 100 Water Street, near the Manhattan Bridge, Brooklyn Heights, (718) 858-1373 (through Dec. 14). Funny conceptualism by a 30-year-old Brooklyn artist. In a large photographic self-portrait, Mr. Friedman appears unshaven with black-rimmed glasses and a cigarette wedged between his lips in deadpan imitation of Chuck Close's canonical self-portrait. In a video, the artist abuses a guitar and violently eats a grapefruit, peel and all, to the driving beat of Led Zeppelin (Johnson).
 
 "JUST RIPE," Smack Mellon Studios, 81 Washington Street, near the Manhattan Bridge, Brooklyn Heights, (718) 834-8761 (through Dec. 20). A lively, uneven show of young artists considered "just ripe" for a major show by its curator, Joan Snyder. Among the better works on display in a sprawling, raw space are sleek, photographic pictures within pictures by Sophia Petrides; small, painterly pictures of flying airliners by Andrea Legge and grotesque, free-standing dresses by Martha Posner. In the basement there's a scary, black-light-illuminated installation collaboratively produced by Kate Dodd, Andrea Reynosa, Kevin Vertrees and David Baskin (Johnson).
 
 JANNIS KOUNELLIS, Ace Gallery, 275 Hudson Street, near Spring Street, West Village, (212) 255-5599 (through Dec. 24). New, huge-scale work by the Italian Arte Povera master. Live starlings flutter in cages hung by meat hooks in front of massive steel plates; antique wooden armoires dangle absurdly by thick ropes from overhead I-beams. His work is grandiose, but Mr. Kounellis's poetic imagination can be charmingly capricious (Johnson).
 
 FRED SANDBACK, Lawrence Markey, 55 Vandam Street, South Village, (212) 627-4446 (through Dec. 19). This slight show of new work features one extremely minimal piece in this artist's signature material: a single length of cardinal-red yarn stretched from a point high on the wall to a point on the floor about five inches out from the wall; the line leans slightly to the left. Less audaciously radical are three small wooden panels incised with saw cuts (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
 FERNANDO BOTERO, Marlborough, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through tomorrow). Large-scale drawings by the South American artist famous for making people and things chubby. You'd think Mr. Botero's shtick would be worn out by now, but his fattening transformations are still hard to resist: funny, sexy and oddly faithful to reality. These drawings in charcoal, red chalk or watercolor on canvas are as big as paintings but have a charming, unforced immediacy (Johnson).
 
 SUSAN CRILE, James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through tomorrow). After a series of combustive paintings of the Desert Storm-related fires in Kuwait, Ms. Crile has turned to the historic architecture of Verona, Italy. Her new canvases, the most interesting of which are long and narrow, present fragmentary views of floors, columns and windows, including areas of elaborate decorative patterning, all rendered with a thin, brushy touch and in a muted, predominantly orange-and-blue palette (Johnson).
 
 * "DAYS OF DISCIPLINE AND GRACE: TREASURES FROM THE IMPERIAL BUDDHIST CONVENTS OF KYOTO," C. V. Starr East Asian Library, Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7403 (through today). Many of the objects in this tiny exhibition, tucked away deep in the library's stacks, are pocket-size or fold-upable. Most date from the 17th century, though some are quite new. Several were made for pleasure, not spiritual profit: parlor games, for example, outnumber religious icons. Together they capture the subtly exalted ordinariness of convent life and the creative spirit of the aristocratic women who chose to live it (Cotter).
