HEADLINE: Something Wicked This Way Comes

BYLINE: By Caleb Crain; Caleb Crain has written for Lingua Franca and American Literary History. He is writing a book on early American friendships.

 BODY:

Charles Brockden Brown
 Three Gothic Novels.
 Wieland: Or, The Transformation.
 Arthur Mervyn:
 Or, Memoirs of the Year 1793.
 Edgar Huntly:
 Or, Memoirs of a Sleep-Walker.
 914 pp. New York:
 The Library of America. $35. 
 "As I am you despise me," Charles Brockden Brown wrote to a friend and ex-roommate on New Year's Day 1798. "How can I remove the burthen of your scorn but by transforming myself into a new being? . . . I shall die, as I have lived, a victim of perverse & incurable habits."
Brown's friends were used to his high-strung self-reproaches. The playwright William Dunlap called them "mysterious & unintelligible." Another friend, Dr. Elihu Hubbard Smith, heard them so often he lost patience. "What, my friend, is the meaning of all this?" Smith once demanded of Brown. "If you meant that we should understand you, why were you not explicit?" But it does not pay to be explicit -- not even to your friends -- when you are trying to get away with something. Brown was trying to get away with writing novels. And in the American Gothic style that he would pioneer, an air of mysterious criminality was a boon.
Charles Brockden Brown was born to a family of Philadelphia Quakers in 1771. Modern literary critics harp on the "Brockden," probably because three names sound grander than two, and because, at cocktail parties, it helps to distinguish him from Snoopy's friend. But Brown himself may not have been so fond of his middle name. He got it from his great-uncle Charles Brockden, whom Benjamin Franklin once described as "an eminent Scrivener or Conveyancer." The original Charles Brockden was a paralegal -- like Melville's Bartleby, though not as lowly. Brockden researched property titles and copied legal documents. Brown's father, too, worked as a conveyancer, after he had failed as a merchant. The family gave young Charles B. Brown an education so that he could become something better -- a lawyer proper. But inadvertently, that education introduced him to the writings of Jean-Jacques Rousseau and Samuel Richardson, who sowed in Brown a wish to use words even more freely and imperiously than lawyers do.
In the words of the critic Leslie Fiedler, Brown became "the inventor of the American writer." Brown was the first to live a myth that is still familiar, despite the Federalist-era particulars of his case. A young man with delicate health (consumption) and a strangely overkeen conscience (see the self-reproaches above) shirks a responsible career (law) to run off to New York City, where he camps out in the apartments of his radical friends (deists, vegetarians and anarchists) and risks his life (during a yellow fever epidemic) for no very good reason. After years of unemployed vagrancy, when everyone has given up on him, he writes masterly novels that earn him little money. He then gives up on art, marries, takes a steady job, and dies in relative obscurity.
Ordinarily, a Library of America edition compacts into one volume a career that spanned decades. But to publish three of Brown's novels at once approximates the pace at which he wrote them. In 1798, the year he burst forth, Brown wrote two and a half novels. By 1801, when he gave up fiction, he had written seven (one has been lost), as well as novel fragments and short stories.
In 1846, the transcendentalist Margaret Fuller called Brown one of "the dark masters," because it was Brown's genius to descend, precipitously, into the twisty maze of a lonely mind that was trying to think its way back to the light. Fuller also noted that Brown was something of a feminist, since he "usually placed this thinking royal mind in the body of a woman." Brown's "Alcuin" imagined a gender-neutral utopia and a critique of marriage based on William Godwin's anarchist philosophy. Unfortunately, this Library of America edition omits "Alcuin," as well as Brown's most woman-centered novel, "Ormond," whose heroine not only resists but stabs to death her would-be seducer, just moments before her girlfriend breaks down the door to save her. But the reader does get to meet Clara Wieland, the fierce protagonist of Brown's first published novel. As Kevin Williamson, the scriptwriter of "Scream," could tell you, as a rule horror heroines should be sturdy. If you think a character is braver than you are, it is easier to let your guard down and sympathize with her fear. Appropriately, the Clara of "Wieland" is strong, and she protects her boundaries. She lives alone, rather than with her brother's family, because she is "an economist of pleasure." To danger she is "habitually indifferent." The first time the Wieland family hear a voice they can't explain (they learn, much later, it's a ventriloquist's), her brother Theodore feels dread, but Clara feels only "a thrilling and not unpleasing solemnity." Clara obeys another law of horror scripts, too: she is so out of touch with her feelings that she has no idea whom she can trust -- and therefore, neither do we. Love, in Clara's narrowed eyes, is "a passion that will never rank me in the number of its eulogists." She also has the obligatory traumatic past: one night while praying, her father spontaneously combusted.
Clara is thoroughly modern. Ventriloquists, however, are no longer scary, which makes it hard to read "Wieland" today with the terror it deserves. When Clara addresses the villain Carwin, a young man who knows how to throw his voice, as "O most fatal and potent of mankind," 20th-century grown-ups may giggle. For an analogous modern threat, you would have to imagine someone who knows your credit card numbers, has broken into your E-mail account and has pocketed your cell phone. In the late 18th century, selfhood was not digitized, and the human voice had the burden of representing political agency, sexual reputation and financial integrity. You were only as good as your word, and words were supposed to give order to the world. It makes sense that an 18th-century set of words, the Constitution, should have balanced power so exquisitely as not to have toppled in 200 years. Corrupted by Godwin and Rousseau, Brown was experimenting with words that failed to give order, or words that called up the disorder of violent feelings.
When Clara unmasks Carwin, she shrieks that "he is able to speak where he is not." She could be accusing her villainous author and the suspect potential of his art. If voices can be split from their subjects, if stories can be made up, then it becomes impossible to know any social fact for sure. And so, in obedience to another rule of the horror genre, Clara blames the wrong person. Carwin the ventriloquist is no mastermind killer. He is just a piece of news: in the future, the media will be unreliable, striving for sensation rather than accuracy. Carwin is a geek. The real monster is someone else, whom this new contingency pushes over the edge.
Brown's writing can be clunky, almost as if he wants to call attention to the inadequacy of words to experience. For example, when Clara hears two voices in her closet debating whether to shoot or strangle her, she explains that "flight instantly suggested itself as most eligible in circumstances so perilous." A sentence like that is meant to take a little too long to read. It's the literary equivalent of the movie actor pausing to tie his shoes while the audience screams and the spree killer raises his ax.
Unlike ventriloquism, the peril in "Arthur Mervyn" is accessible to modern readers -- eerily so. A plague of yellow fever has descended on Philadelphia, poisoning society with distrust and fear, just as young Arthur arrives in the city to find his fortune. Arthur hires himself out as a scrivener, but in a plot twist that hints at Brown's distaste for the family business, the man Arthur copies for turns out to be a forger -- as well as an impostor, adulterer, thief and murderer. In an odd congruence, Arthur's panics, vigilance about secrets, imprudent idealizations and doubtful moral choices foreshadow uncannily the modern experiences of gay men who came to the metropolis in search of community, only to find an epidemic.
"Arthur Mervyn" may have the messiest plot that the Library of America has ever published. In Part 1, Chapter 23, for example, Arthur discovers in his master's attic something that "furnished matter which my curiosity devoured with unspeakable eagerness," but it is apparently too awful to share with the reader, who is hurried on to the next shock, a house of prostitution. Brown does not unravel his mysteries so much as distract you with new ones. Brown's first biographer complained of "this perpetual intrusion of novelty to explain a novelty." However, these disruptions in Brown's style -- the "ambiguities, abruptnesses and dark transitions," as he called them -- are Gothic effects. They are designed to unnerve and compel. Brown's plots have loose ends, but so do most nightmares. (The narrative logic of David Lynch's "Lost Highway" was not exactly airtight, either.) When Brown writes that all the men in the Mervyn family die before the age of 21, it may irk a close reader that Brown ends his novel, happy marriage and all, without either firing or unloading this Chekhovian rifle. But an omen would not be quite so frightening if you knew for sure it would come true.
There is a similar logic of distraction and dislocation at work in "Edgar Huntly." The book starts as a whodunit. Edgar wants to know who killed his friend Waldegrave. He spies on a man named Clithero, who has the guilty habit of digging up and reburying a box while he sleepwalks. Soon Edgar is chasing Clithero through a jagged and confusing limestone landscape in Pennsylvania, then sleepwalking himself, then slaughtering cougars, then slaughtering Native Americans -- and we never find out who killed Waldegrave. Brown's fugue feels genuine, nonetheless. There is nothing aimless about Edgar's path from mourning to obsession to violence. It may have been the path of Brown's own mind, as he tried to mourn his friend Elihu Hubbard Smith. A sort of junior Ben Franklin, Smith had provided the intellectual spark that ignited Brown's fit of creativity. He supported Brown through his fallow years, spiritually and financially, but then died of yellow fever halfway through the writing of "Arthur Mervyn." Like Waldegrave in "Edgar Huntly," Smith left behind a cache of letters full of his troubling, radical ideas. In Federalist America, that was not an easy legacy to inherit, and Brown, like Edgar Huntly, survived it by making a violent break.
"Edgar Huntly" was Brown's last Gothic novel. One of his brothers suggested that readers disliked his books' gloom. Since Brown was impatient to earn a living as a writer, he decided that this was "a sufficient reason for dropping the doleful tone and assuming a cheerful one." Unintentionally, Brown's cheerful tone was even more gruesome, and he soon dropped fiction altogether. He should have persisted in gloom, which would eventually earn a commercial reward that outran the avarice of his most flagitious villains. Though he did not realize it, during his brief, doleful career Brown succeeded in infecting America with his perverse and incurable taste. The nation has been horrified ever since.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: December 6, 1998

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 3224 words

HEADLINE: Editors' Choice

 BODY:
THE best books of 1998, chosen by the eight editors of the Book Review from 25 initial nominees, are three novels, two collections of stories, three biographies, a scientific tour d'horizon and two books about slaughter -- one concerning diplomacy to end it in the Balkans and another asking why it happened and no one tried to stop it in Africa.
At first glance it might seem the editors are habit-bound. There were also 11 books on the 1997 list, by four women and seven men -- and this year's 11 are by four women and seven men. Last year, however, six of the writers had appeared on these lists previously. This year only two are repeaters, a biographer of Victor Hugo and a Canadian fiction writer making the list for the sixth time in 15 years. And one of the books here is its author's first -- a fairly rare occurrence. All the fiction writers are North Americans; the nonfiction authors are three Americans and three Britons. 
 There is no history in the lot. That is unusual. But the biographies contain a great deal of it, our reviewer called one novel a personalizing of history, and the volume of science is a biological history recounting four billion years. One biographer has a passion for his subject's warts and poetry, but the two others exhibit tendencies that may signal a sea change in our mores: the life of a robber baron is eminently evenhanded and does not try to incite mobs against him, and the life of a painter does not peek once into the artist's bedroom. What is going on? Do these writers not know this is the year of the Starr report?
The boss's 1997 decree that editors' discussions must be civil held this year, with a vengeance: everyone found flattering things to say about every book nominated. The result was that the boss expressed surprise that the majority did not make the cut when we voted. Is that remark the first sound of the crumbling of civility? Sweeter than a nightingale's song it was.
Certain types of books, like letters and diaries, are not eligible for nomination. It was not a remarkable year for them in any case, although last month did see publication of "I Will Bear Witness," the disturbing diary of Victor Klemperer, a Jewish-born German academician during the Nazi years.
The best books are chosen from among those reviewed here since last year's Holiday Books issue, and the summaries below are generally drawn from the reviews. They are not included among Notable Books of 1998, the list of which begins on page 65.
 
BIRDS OF AMERICA
 Stories.
 By Lorrie Moore.
 Alfred A. Knopf.
The two epigraphs of Lorrie Moore's third volume of short stories are taken from poems on birds -- one by Amy Clampitt questioning whether their songs mean anything and another by Charlie Smith musing that grief cannot be translated into any comprehensible language. Moore bypasses translating emotions. She uses her fluid, colloquial sentences and her mordant wit to pry the feelings of her characters loose inside the readers, where they resist articulation and make us sense the depth of the predicaments that most of her protagonists, usually women, fail to extricate themselves from. The story is Moore's natural scale, and the best in this collection, especially the last three, are stellar performances. They all concern cancer -- the whole book is a probing of mortality -- but even the most overpowering of them, the already famous "People Like That Are the Only People Here," has a kind of steady hilarity amid its sublime darkness. Moore, like Samuel Beckett, sees that nothing is funnier than unhappiness. Her precise observation of characters' horror, or suffering, is often delivered in prose that extorts laughter, and the mirth is a jolt when it bursts out. Here is a measure of her mastery: in a reverie, a mother discovers that despair over her baby's cancer has deprived her of once formidable gifts of expression, and her search for words to define her grief becomes a satire of Moore's own writing. Now that is confidence, and it is fully justified.
 
CLOUDSPLITTER
 By Russell Banks.
 Harper Flamingo.
How do you survive upbringing by a fanatical prophet? You don't. That is the story in Russell Banks's huge novel about the abolitionist John Brown, whose 1859 raid at Harpers Ferry was one of the fuses that detonated the Civil War. Banks seems to take his cue from the assertion by some modern historians that history is not an account of what happened but of what people think happened. This domestic drama is told early in this century, nearly 50 years after Harpers Ferry, by Brown's son Owen, a spiritual tag-along to his father. Slowly, deliberately -- the storytelling often assumes the leisure of timelessness -- Owen draws a magnificent picture of the older Brown as an unmoved mover, a man of giant ambitions whose biblical learning makes him eerily worldly; his absolute righteousness is a religious mystery, not a neurosis, but a mystery that still brings madness and death to his children and pain to some escaped slaves for whom he is ready to kill if need be. Next to him Owen appears emptier page by page; he knows he died with his father on the scaffold. Banks's analysis is moral, not psychological. The result is that the closer John Brown gets, the more he too appears a ruin -- drawn by Piranesi, to be sure -- scorched and gutted by the purity of his vision. Fittingly, Banks brings the whole world to witness Brown's fate: revolutions, the fall of empires, the grandeur of the earth; indeed, the American landscape is virtually a character, heralded by the book's title, the name of a mountain.
 
LIFE
 A Natural History of the First
 Four Billion Years of Life on Earth.
 By Richard Fortey.
 Alfred A. Knopf.
At last a book that puts dinosaurs in their place -- and it turns out to be a niche. Dinomania has nearly blinded the public to the reality of evolution. But Richard Fortey, a British paleontologist with an extensive range of humane learning and a gift for arresting language, gives a coherent account of the biological history of earth for four billion years, surprisingly the first popular but authoritative one written by a professional. This is no boring slog, but an adventure -- one comes away with a reverence for the courage of the students of fossils -- in which we meet weird creatures like rats as big as bears, dragonflies as big as people, carnivorous kangaroos, poisonous sea octopods and shell-crushing clams. Fortey does not present evolution as warfare, but at times the development of species does look like an arms race. In his words the evolution of whales from land animals is as dramatic as some paleontological expeditions he describes. He decries the mutation of natural history museums into entertainment palaces, but his book has plenty of entertainment in the form of digressions, literary excursions and surprising analogies -- enough to irritate some readers. However, it is a survey of the facts of life that reliably summarizes state-of-the-art knowledge from many sciences, and it is written for readers with no science. It will help them understand the specialized and often technical books on evolution that make headlines but leave most people wondering why.
 
THE LOVE OF A GOOD WOMAN
 Stories.
 By Alice Munro.
 Alfred A. Knopf.
Alice Munro is, in Virginia Woolf's phrase, one of the few writers "for grown-up people." Retrospection has always been important in her work, but never has she been quite this autumnal, acting as the mediator between the way people lived around 1960, when all but one of these eight stories begin, and the way we live now. She has an uncanny ability to make a reader realize that people really think differently in different eras and that morals may shift more quickly than customs. The price can be, as she puts it in a story about a woman who leaves her family to be with her new lover, a pain she will have to get used to until it is "only the past she's grieving for and not any possible present." Her stories were always long, and now they grow longer. The title story -- an extraordinary accomplishment even by Munro's soaring standards -- is really a novella. Also, her conclusions have become ever more open, without being inconclusive. A woman who thinks she knows a quiet man's secret about a drowning death suddenly sees that she faces "an entirely different possibility" from the one that had grounded her until now -- her life will harden into a form unimagined before. The large, enigmatic quality of this ending is reflected in the other stories; they never end where we expect them to and never take a turn without pain. They are like life, but trying to detect their shifts in time or point of view is as difficult as trying to remember where a change came in one's own life that put one in another world altogether.
 
THE POISONWOOD BIBLE
 By Barbara Kingsolver.
 Harper Flamingo.
Zeal is mere termite food in Barbara Kingsolver's novel about a white American clergyman's religious mission to the Congo in 1959. At least ostensibly, this is Nathan Price's story. But it is told by his wife, Orleanna, recollecting years later on an island in Georgia, and her daughters, writing in Africa -- an epistolary novel from places so remote the letters might have been sent to sea in bottles. The picture of Price is merciless; Kingsolver implies that his story is only the one men always tell. There is a load of political message here, but ultimately this is a novel of character; the women discover themselves as they lose faith in Price and find another one, each according to her kind. The tone of Orleanna's reminiscences is ironic, and Kingsolver's use of her unconscious dissembling to reveal her pain is masterly; the mother confides in Ruth May, her baby, the catalyst for breaking up the family, and there is wisdom in every sentence. Rachel, the first daughter, is the brainless soul of American materialism. A younger sister, Adah, is hemiplegic, limping and nearly speechless, but a verbal gymnast whose wit sets fire to her diary and lights up the true nature of anyone she notices. Her twin, Leah, is the conscience of the novel, always measuring the distance she has to go before she is worthy of Africa. Perhaps the greatest character is collective, the Congolese, whose perfect adaptation to the harshness of their lives amid drought, hunger, pests and diseases is simply beautiful. Their rejection of American salvation feels triumphant.
 
PRESTON FALLS
 By David Gates.
 Alfred A. Knopf.
Boomers go bust in this scary novel, the whole generation of them. Doug Willis is a New York public relations executive, and his wife, Jean, a successful designer; they live in Westchester County and own an old getaway house upstate. He is a maelstrom of male vanity whose obsessive irony has left him with little but a withering reflexive consciousness and the cynicism he hopes will prevent him from going missing in the middle of life. Jean's form of denial is keeping up an illusion of normality no matter what happens; she is no wiser than he is, but she is nicer. She's also nicer than their two children. When Willis takes two months off to work on the old house, a family fight on the first weekend lands him in jail, and the lawyer who springs him turns out to be a drug trafficker who brings Willis into the trade. Briefly the dope is a whiff of youth, but then Willis, in a panic about what he is doing, flees the country life without telling Jean where he's going. From there till the end of the novel the suspense about his fate is brilliantly maintained. David Gates has a superb reporter's precision, an analyst's ear, a teen-ager's glee in exposing deception and a moralist's eye that is as unforgiving as Evelyn Waugh's. Here the entire culture is deception, and as these characters betray themselves ever deeper into it, the very possibility of trust, of reliable understanding, is worn away. A reader ends up wary of looking at the book again once he's finished -- because anything could happen and whatever does is likely to be irremediable.
 
TITAN
 The Life of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.
 By Ron Chernow.
 Random House.
"Oh, John D., we hardly knew ye." Sorry. It is not that Ron Chernow unearths so much new information about John D. Rockefeller in this biography, but his dispassionate portrait places the man in so rich a context that we understand how he gathered more economic power into his hands than anyone before or since, and, to a large extent, we know why he did it. As we recognize the intelligence, courage and vision of the man, his rapacity and cunning become more alarming,
not less. Chernow catches the early Rockefeller better than anyone has -- the quick-witted young man who had developed by the time he was 30 all the principles and techniques of his business life. With mischievous humor Chernow points out that his analysis of the American economy was Marxist, and he chose to solve its problems with monopoly. The Government finally broke the monopoly, but Rockefeller's organization of Standard Oil has been the model of global business ever since, and the company's reach and power taught the Government the vulnerability of the economy to manipulation and the need for regulation. Finally, we see that underlying all his achievements and philanthropies was a deep religious commitment that was shared by his wife. It shaped them, their family and, through the philanthropies, many religious, educational and social institutions.
 
TO END A WAR
 By Richard Holbrooke.
 Random House.
Diplomacy is the grungiest job, if one judges from Richard Holbrooke's account of the negotiations he led in 1995 to end years of war in Bosnia. But it must be satisfying, because this enthralling book is also a heartfelt call to America to use its power when societies break down and to become a steady global force resisting human rights abuses everywhere. It is filled with anecdotes and sharp pictures of the wily Balkan leaders Holbrooke had to deal with, as well as with shrewd and seldom flattering analyses of the personalities and motivations of timid American and NATO military commanders. Foreign diplomats who complain that Holbrooke is a bulldozer in the polite corridors of international politics may be right, but few could complain that he is gutless. His re-creations of battles over principle and tactics with Western generals and State Department and White House officials are dramatic, and his description of a rudderless Administration during the early days of his efforts is astonishingly candid, and convincing. It is telling that the decision to use heavy air strikes to bring the Serbs to the bargaining table was not a careful calculation but an act of desperation. His combativeness may offend the pinstripe set, but it is wonderfully refreshing on the page; it is a very rare book on diplomacy that makes you feel you were in the midst of it, and excited to be there.
 
THE UNKNOWN MATISSE
 A Life of Henri Matisse:
 The Early Years, 1869-1908.
 By Hilary Spurling.
 Alfred A. Knopf.
Can this be a biography? It says next to nothing about Matisse's sex life. More than half the population has lived its adult life thinking biography means sex, but here if there's a mistress, well, she's glimpsed in our passing among canvases, but we look at them, not her. In fact, it is a smashing good biography, this first volume taking us up to the painter's 40th year -- Matisse before he was Matisse. Hilary Spurling's role is advocate, and she is a formidable one. Her heroic research pays off; her sense of the time and place, of Matisse's family and friends and competitors, of the old teachers and Young Turks in the French art world, is admirable. We are swept into all-night arguments among aspiring artists about what art is, and into their dreams and prospects. We even fear for Matisse -- will he ever find his style? The tentativeness of his career is pointed up by the deaths or despair of contemporaries who were his equals in art and by his failure into middle age to gain a public. A painter's development is both an intimate and an open transaction, and Spurling makes us feel its peril. By the end of this volume, although Matisse is still largely unknown as an artist, it is clear that having nothing to lose is increasingly a spur to his creativity, and one begins to sense that the next door he opens may be the last he has to.
 
VICTOR HUGO
 By Graham Robb.
 W. W. Norton & Company.
What a life! By the time he was 30, Victor Hugo had witnessed Napoleon's Iberian campaigns and seen his fall; his poetry had made him the lion of Paris, and his drama had touched off street battles. He was elected to the French Academy and the Senate before he started a steady march to the left that made him a political force in the revolutionary period from 1848 to 1851, and he became a national hero when, in exile, he led opposition to Napoleon III for two decades. When he died in 1885, at 83, his funeral drew two million people. His huge body of work in every genre has saturated the French language with his expression. Even in life he disappeared in a cloud of myths he created -- tribune of the republic, the arch-romantic, the lifelong womanizer. Graham Robb penetrates the myths and exposes the hidden impulses and hurts that gave rise to them, and he has deep sympathy for the women, many of them victims, who flocked around Hugo. His enthusiasm for Hugo's writing is infectious, and we share his annoyance that there is no good modern English translation of any of it. He tells us to put down his book and read "Les Miserables." Read both. Hugo lifts spirits. Robb will open your mind and heart. His is the best biography of Hugo in English and probably the best single-volume one in any language.
 
WE WISH TO INFORM YOU THAT
 TOMORROW WE WILL BE KILLED
 WITH OUR FAMILIES
 Stories From Rwanda.
 By Philip Gourevitch.
 Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
In 1994 the Government of Rwanda called on everyone in the Hutu majority of the country to murder everyone in the Tutsi minority. In 100 days 800,000 people were killed, most of them individually cut down with knives. The daily killing rate exceeded that of the Nazi Holocaust, and the deed was done mostly not by trained cadres but by neighbors, co-workers, even family members. In the years since, Philip Gourevitch, a New Yorker writer, has talked to survivors, witnesses and participants to discover the origins and personal motives for this collective crime. His grim book -- it is his first -- lays a burden on the world's conscience. This genocidal crime now has faces, names, personal psychologies. As we encounter people involved in the massacre, we cannot pull back from looking into their souls, and our own. As the title -- taken from a letter by seven Christian pastors to their religious leader -- indicates, there were warnings. Those given to international agencies, especially the United Nations, make dismal reading. And American policy, which encouraged the United Nations to stay out of internal conflicts, is sickening in retrospect. The history of Belgian, French and British racism in colonial times bears on the massacres too. Gourevitch withholds judgments, but his restraint gives his book a subtle, subterranean power.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: December 6, 1998

SECTION: Section 7; Page 44; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1435 words

HEADLINE: Two on the Aisle

BYLINE: By Harlow Robinson; Harlow Robinson is the chairman of the department of modern languages at Northeastern University, and the author of biographies of Sergei Prokofiev and Sol Hurok.

 BODY:

HOT SEAT
 Theater Criticism for
 The New York Times, 1980-1993.
 By Frank Rich.
 Illustrated. 1,050 pp. New York:
 Random House. $39.95. 
 Critics -- especially theater critics -- must expect to be hated. The wiser among them even enjoy the contempt, for they understand their colorful and essential role as villains in the larger drama of the theatrical enterprise.
Few drama critics have inspired more fear, loathing and indignation, however, than Frank Rich, the legendary "Butcher of Broadway." From 1980 to 1993, Rich served as the chief drama critic for The New York Times. Now, in the aptly titled "Hot Seat," he has assembled approximately one-quarter of the reviews and essays he delivered from that bully pulpit, formerly occupied by Alexander Woolcott, Brooks Atkinson and Walter Kerr. Equipped with an introduction, some hindsight, some insider gossip and a few amusing "best" and "worst" lists, the result is an exuberant, enthralling and wistful volume no less valuable as social-economic-political history than as a definitive chronicle of the era's theatrical activity.
Rich sooner or later incurred the wrath of almost everyone he wrote about. He was denounced repeatedly from the stage at the Tony Awards. Directors, producers and actors regularly accused him of single-handedly closing their shows. The producer David Merrick even called Rich "a savage dog" on "60 Minutes."
In "Exit the Critic," published as a valedictory in The New York Times Magazine in early 1994 and anthologized here, Rich expresses a wry amusement at the furious passions his reviews used to unleash: "Critics may not be, as is generally presumed, frustrated actors or playwrights, but few of us mind playing our assigned role in the timeless sideshows of the rialto." Elsewhere, he muses that the virulence of the hatred directed at his strong opinions was directly proportionate to the theater's growing inability to compete with television and film for mainstream American audiences, performers and writers. To blame Frank Rich was far easier than to confront the unpleasant fact that many, if not most, of the seats in the dwindling number of Broadway theaters were being filled by foreign tourists barely fluent in English but happy to pay the ever-increasing ticket prices for shows with mountains of scenery and deafening miking.
In "Hot Seat," Rich is eager to debunk the myth of his and The Times's omnipotence. Obviously, the crowds didn't stay away because of his lukewarm response to "Cats" ("If you blink, you'll miss the plot") and most of the other blockbusters by Andrew Lloyd Webber. Nor did his praise of high-minded productions like "The Grapes of Wrath" or "Les Liaisons Dangereuses" keep them open. Rich cites further examples in lists like "The Power of The Times Revisited 1: Rave Reviews, Short Broadway Runs."
Whatever you think about Rich's opinions, there's no denying that he's an impressive writer and thinker. Residing in New York for much of the period, I turned eagerly each morning to his artfully fashioned pieces, anticipating another good column and at least a few laughs. Rereading them now, I have been happily reliving the sights, smells, sounds and words of many wonderful, and some god-awful, evenings in the theater and experiencing others that I missed.
Who was better at the lethal apercu than Frank Rich?
"Had the actor Philip Casnoff not been beaned by a falling slab of scenery at a press preview last week, 'Shogun: The Musical' might have been best remembered as the first Broadway musical extravaganza to beguile an audience with a song about a dildo."
"Capped Teeth and Caesar Salad," a song from "Song & Dance," starring Bernadette Peters, "recycles Beverly Hills jokes that had seen better days when Joan Rivers was still in college."
It's only fair, too, to remember the conditions under which Rich labored. Writing on deadline with impatient editors breathing down his neck, he still managed to construct apparently seamless miniature essays. As an occasional critic myself, I tell you this takes talent, discipline and nerves.
There was much more to Rich's success than nasty quips and one-liners. If anything, the sting of his reviews has faded with time, and what remains behind are different, more enduring qualities: a thorough historical and artistic knowledge of American and British theatrical tradition; an encyclopedic familiarity with the work of a wide variety of performers, directors and playwrights currently active in the theater; and an infectious passion for this evanescent and impossible medium.
Not surprisingly, the "330-odd pieces" collected here tend to favor shows the critic enjoyed (almost anything by Stephen Sondheim) or judged significant artistically ("House of Blue Leaves," "M. Butterfly," "Cinders") or commercially ("Cats," "Phantom of the Opera"). But Rich has also been careful to include famous bombs. For him, nothing will top the notorious "Moose Murders": "A visit to 'Moose Murders' is what will separate the connoisseurs of Broadway disaster from mere dilettantes for many moons to come."
As engrossing as the reviews themselves may be, the juiciest parts of "Hot Seat" are the spicy italicized postscripts sprinkled here and there. These include sobering "Whatever happened to . . .?" vignettes, as well as dishy tales of backstage intrigue. At the end of his largely favorable notice on the revival of "The King and I" with Yul Brynner, Rich relates how the imperious star ("not an easy guy") demanded to be transported by motorcade the few blocks from the theater to an appearance on "Nightline." To the review of the revival of "The Front Page," staged by Jerry Zaks, that finally brought the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center back to life in 1986 he appends a well-informed commentary on why thrust stages like the one at the Beaumont proved so unsuccessful wherever they were built.
While no one will mistake "Hot Seat" for a novel, it contains numerous narrative strands. Probably the most important, and most poignant, are the story of AIDS and the arrival of numerous gay characters in plays and musicals both on and Off Broadway.
News of the strange new epidemic hit the Times just as Rich began his tenure there. One of the first AIDS play he saw was William Hoffman's "As Is" in 1985. To his credit, Rich got out front early on the issue, and reviewed (for the most part favorably) the growing number of AIDS plays that appeared in the coming years, from Larry Kramer's "Normal Heart" (which he admits he at first undervalued) to Richard Greenberg's "Eastern Standard" (an overlooked minor masterpiece, I agree) to Tony Kushner's "Angels in America: Millennium Approaches" and "Angels in America: Perestroika." That Rich chooses to end the final season in "Hot Seat" with his adoring, even transcendent, review of "Perestroika" shows just how highly he rates Kushner's emotional and artistic achievement.
Remembered here, too, are the numerous important theater people lost to AIDS: among them, the playwrights Scott McPherson and Harry Kondoleon; the choreographer Michael Bennett; and Charles Ludlam, the wild and wildly gifted director of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company. In a wise and humane 1992 Sunday essay, Rich describes how he took his two sons (then aged 12 and 8) to see the gay musical "Falsettos." "I wanted to take my children to an entertainment, a musical no less, that reinforces the notion that there are many ways to be masculine."
In retrospect, this essay ("Discovering Family Values at 'Falsettos' "), not dissimilar to the pieces Rich now produces for the Times Op-Ed page, marked the beginning of his transition to another kind of writing. As he tells it in "Exit the Critic," the incessant attacks on his personal and professional integrity began to wear him down. The disappearance of serious musicals and dramas from Broadway, and the vastly changed economics of producing and ticket prices, depressed him. But the last straw was the deaths of his mother and the visionary New York producer Joseph Papp, founder of the Public Theater. The joy had gone out of the work. "I found myself more interested in writing about the world itself rather than just the theater's vision of that world." It was time to move on.
When the playwright Herb Gardner received the Tony Award for Best Play for "I'm Not Rappaport" more than 12 years ago, he bragged to the audience that his success showed that "there's life after Frank Rich." Judging by this vibrant, eloquent and often moving collection, the same can be said for Frank Rich himself.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 850 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Colorado Resorts Get An International Accent

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: VAIL, Colo.

 BODY:
DEEP in the nation's heartland, the Colorado Rockies are 1,000 miles from the nearest seaport. But jet travel, satellite television and foreign-language Web sites are quickly integrating America's most popular skiing state into the world tourism economy.
This winter, foreign skiers are expected to buy 10 percent of lift tickets at Colorado ski areas, triple their share of a decade ago. Last winter at Vail and Breckenridge, the nation's two busiest ski areas, foreign skiers bought about 15 percent of tickets sold. At Aspen, the most international of Colorado's resorts, foreigners accounted for 21 percent of ticket sales. 
 The number of lift tickets sold to Americans has been more or less flat for the last decade, so Colorado resorts believe their biggest future growth will be international. This winter, the foreign invasion will be fueled by two new factors. In September, British Airways inaugurated a daily nonstop flight between Gatwick Airport outside London and Denver International Airport. This restored a trans-Atlantic link that was lost five years ago when Continental dropped the service.
"Last year, Britain was our third biggest market, after Colorado and Texas," said Jim Felton, spokesman for Breckenridge, a resort that sold 1.3 million lift tickets over all last winter. "The British Airways flight should keep that momentum going."
Vail's international visibility should grow in February, when the resort and Beaver Creek will host the 1999 World Alpine Ski Championships. In 1989, the last time Vail had that honor, the television audience outside the United States was estimated at 300 million people. This winter, with the spread of cable and satellite TV through Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America, the foreign audience is expected to be 500 million.
"The 1989 championships truly put the Vail valley on the international map," said John Dakin, spokesman for the nonprofit Vail Valley Foundation, which is organizing the races. "In 1989, Europe was having a snow drought. European viewers were seeing their correspondents standing waist deep in Vail's snow and saying the men's alpine had been canceled because of too much snow."
This winter, the races will be held from Jan. 30 through Feb. 14. "Vail is going to become one giant TV studio, constantly selling how great the skiing is here," said Bruce Mainzer, head of marketing for Vail Resorts, which owns Vail, Breckenridge, Beaver Creek and Keystone ski areas.
The arson fires atop Vail in October, claimed by environmentalists angry over Vail's addition of new ski trails, are not expected to have much impact on foreign visits this winter, said John Frew, president of Colorado Ski Country USA, a trade group. Three buildings were destroyed and four chairlifts damaged; the lifts are expected to reopen by January.
"The facts seem to have come through fairly accurately, people seem to realize that the Vail experience has not been impacted," Mr. Frew said in a telephone interview from London, where he was the host for ski-promotion events at a travel trade fair. "Out of 500 questions I answered, two were about the Vail fires." He added that he had not heard of any cancellations because of the fires.
Mr. Frew, who was on his third promotional trip to London this year, said that economics are dictating Colorado's pursuit of the foreign skier. His research indicates that foreign skiers stay longer and spend more than American skiers: The average skier from the Denver area spends $49 a day, the average out-of-state skier spends $150 a day, and the average foreign skier spends $300 a day.
While Aspen aims to sell one quarter of its tickets to foreigners by the year 2000, marketers at Colorado's lesser-known ski areas have also caught the foreign bug. Copper Mountain has reservationists that speak Japanese, German and Spanish. Skiers in Australia, Britain, Germany, the Netherlands, Japan, Mexico and New Zealand can now call a toll-free international number and speak in their own language to a reservationist at the Rocky Mountain resort. Silver Creek, a small Brazilian-owned resort, has hired an international marketing manager and is organizing ski trips from Brazilian cities such as Brasilia and Belo Horizonte. Itiro Takahashi, the marketing director and one of 20 Brazilians who will work at Silver Creek this winter, said: "We are promoting easy slopes, a resort where no one gets lost, the possibility of shopping trips on the side."
Skiers from Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo and Buenos Aires tend to go to Aspen, while skiers from Mexico tend to favor Vail. To cater to this market, Elena Campa is publishing this month a 64-page Spanish-language guide to Vail and a 48-page guide in Spanish and Portuguese to Aspen.
On her bilingual Spanish-Portuguese Web site for Latins planning Colorado ski vacations, www.andandocolorado.com, "we are averaging 6,000 hits a month," Ms. Campa said. With traffic heavy to advertisers through the site's links, she said that many Vail and Aspen companies are now having their own Web sites translated into Spanish.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 5; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2965 words

HEADLINE: A Shifting American Landscape;
In the Heartland, A Cornucopia Of Culture

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
WHEN Richard Nixon asked, "Will it play in Peoria?" he was taking the nation's temperature, checking on the predilections of mainstream citizens. But he was also reviving an adage from the early part of the century, when this city was a center of whisky production and an active vaudeville circuit stop, and the farm folks were renowned as a particularly dour and tough-to-please audience.
When I echoed the question last month -- what I actually said was: "So what plays in Peoria?" -- the occasion was a round-table discussion, organized at the request of The New York Times, among representatives of local arts groups. The subject was the health of the arts in this conservative heartland city of 113,000 people on the Illinois River. And it was with the emblematic history of Peoria in mind. 
 "We wondered how long it would take you to ask," said the Mayor, Bud Grieves. "We get that a lot."
Best known today, perhaps, as the headquarters of Caterpillar Inc., the heavy- equipment manufacturers, Peoria, a three-hour drive southwest of Chicago, has exported a healthy regiment of cultural troops: the comedians Richard Pryor and Sam Kinison, the pop singer Dan Fogelberg and the actors Susan Dey and Tom Irwin, not to mention Betty Friedan. But even with them long removed -- and casting aside the gimmickry of my journalistic conceit -- the city still serves as an adequate emblem of the nation's cultural health. Which is to say, there is a lot more going on than you might expect.
The Mayor had joined officials from the Peoria Symphony, the Peoria Players Theater, the Peoria Ballet, Opera Illinois and a dozen or so others on the second floor of a once-abandoned warehouse on the city's developing riverfront that a young entrepreneur has successfully transformed into a dinner theater.
Mostly, they wanted to brag on themselves, with some reason. All the nonprofits at the table, even the opera, were at least breaking even. That week, the city-owned Peoria Civic Center was presenting the music of both Gustav Mahler and Motley Crue. The Peoria Arts Guild, which exhibits the work of regional artists and each summer sponsors an art fair that attracts thousands of visitors, was preparing to move, with the help of a $1 million gift from a local patron, to a new building near the river, one more addition to what is becoming a bona fide cultural district.
The schools have maintained a modest budget for arts instruction. And as Mayor Grieves pointed out, for 60 years the citizenry has upheld, through a referendum, a tax to support twice-weekly summer concerts by the Peoria Municipal Band.
That, of course, is not the whole story; there is much that doesn't play in Peoria. But it is worthwhile to pause here and consider the good news, because in the continuing public discourse about the state of the nation's cultural life, the good news doesn't seem be heard much.
Instead, mostly because of the well-publicized struggle of the National Endowment for the Arts to remain alive and viable, it seems fair to say the prevailing perception is that the arts in America are suffering, that the nation's cultural life has diminished, that the artistic side of the American character is undernourished. The endowment had its budget reduced by Congress from $176 million in 1992 to the current $98 million, and, even though its Congressional support seems to have stabilized in recent months, its role as grantmaker has been decried by conservatives because of its support for a handful of controversial projects.
IN fact, in its own report on the state of the arts in this country, "American Canvas," the endowment sounded an ominous note, describing the arts as undersupported by the public, and the arts community as insufficiently engaged with society as a whole.
That report was released 14 months ago, about the same time this newspaper gave me the assignment to travel the country and write about the arts as they are practiced and appreciated outside New York. In that time, I have visited 40 cities, my own personal American canvas, and my impression is that far from being dormant or in retreat, the arts, on balance, are edifyingly, thrillingly abloom. Virtually everywhere. The quantity of activity in any given community has surprised me almost every time, and more often than not I was surprised by its quality as well.
Who would have suspected that in Bozeman, Mont., a city of 35,000 people, there are some 75 arts organizations? Or for that matter, that in Peoria and its surrounding counties there are more than 50, including an orchestra, now in its 101st season, that is the 15th-oldest in the United States and that drew some 1,500 people to hear Mahler's Fourth Symphony last month, its tricky, exposed solos in the middle movements handled with delicacy by the horns and woodwinds.
Frequently, I would visit a place to see something or someone specific, and while there come upon a trail of breadcrumbs leading irresistibly to something or someone else. In El Paso, I found a Chicano artists cooperative, painters, sculptors and musicians squatting -- with permission -- in the shell of an old furniture store, enlivening a struggling neighborhood. During a visit to the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, I was introduced, by Richard Flood, the chief curator there, to Christi Atkinson, who runs No Name Exhibitions, a group of more than 100 local artists in the midst of renovating an old soap factory. The building was only partly spiffed up; it might be 10 years before the renovation is complete, Ms. Atkinson said. But already artists were working in studios, and several shows had been mounted, even though the place doesn't have heat yet.
I never thought to find -- who would? -- an amateur production of "The Marriage of Figaro" in the woods of mid-coast Maine. Nor did I expect a riverfront concert in Des Moines by the Kabbalas, an Iowa-based rock band with a sound that is part Middle Eastern, part electric klezmer and part Spike Jones. In Sacramento, I stumbled on Fred Rochlin, a 74-year-old retired architect who had just begun a second career -- as a monologist.
This is hardly scientific evidence of anything, true. But these anecdotal examples (and dozens of others) of arts activity in disparate places, often underfinanced and almost always beneath the radar of the media, have reminded me that the impulse toward art -- making it and appreciating it -- is irrefutably potent.
And here are some numbers to underscore my impression. In a survey released in September, the endowment reported that in 1997, 20 million Americans sang in choirs or other groups; 33 million took photographs for artistic purposes; 24 million wrote creatively for reasons other than school or work, and 22 million played classical music on some instrument or other.
The same year, 5 million Americans acted on a public stage. And 97 million, fully half the adult population of the United States, attended at least one of the following events: a museum exhibit, a jazz performance, an opera, a classical music concert, a stage musical, a play or a ballet. In terms of percentage, that is up from 41 percent of adults who attended arts events in 1992, the last time the survey was conducted. (And it is worth noting that this number does not include those who saw a movie, read a novel or played in a garage band.)
The numbers suggest that our arts institutions have begun to address -- successfully -- the problem of integrating themselves into their communities. More educational programs, more children's programming, more outreach: all of this has emphasized the good the arts can do, focusing attention on what Ben Cameron, the executive director of the Theater Communications Group in New York, an umbrella organization for nonprofit theaters, calls "the value rather than the quality" of art.
Of course, in many cities, Peoria included, arts institutions continue to worry about aging audiences. Minority groups still complain about feeling unwelcome in theaters and concert halls where, beyond the occasional token production, programming rarely reflects their interests and where, at the same time, traditional programmers feel frustrated at being unable to attract minority audiences, despite what they feel are their best efforts.
"We have a minority marketing committee but I'll be frank, we have really struggled," said Debbie Ritschel, the marketing director of the Peoria Civic Center. "Our African-American community works very well within its own community, but we can't seem to get them here." Last year, she added, "An Evening With Langston and Martin," a theatrical presentation about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Langston Hughes, sold only 125 tickets, even though it had considerable star power, with Danny Glover as the renowned poet of the Harlem Renaissance.
Stan Maclin, who performs in an African drumming troupe that is based in Peoria, pointed out that in this city, which is 70 percent white, "most people who look like me don't attend meetings like this."
"We aren't usually invited," he said. "It's overwhelming. If you don't know how to get the audience, it's because you've created a situation where you feel you can participate but we don't."
Even so, the fact that minority attendance has recently climbed nationwide in museums, opera houses and theaters is an indication that some people who were not showing up in these places in the past are doing so now.
An annual survey of nonprofit theaters, for example, compiled by the Theater Communications Group, indicated that in 1997, 17.2 million people attended a performance at one of 197 nonprofit theaters in the nation. That is 160,000 more people than the survey counted a year before, which is even more impressive considering that 31 fewer theaters participated in the survey this year.
FURTHER, while it is true that society still marginalizes some outre artists and audiences, even the margins yield a kind of optimism. Did you know that in August, 1,300 people attended the National Poetry Slam in Austin, Tex., testimony to an almost entirely unacknowledged new art form that is being nurtured in coffeehouses and bars in almost every city in the country? I don't even know what to call it -- performance poetry? competitive poetry? -- these spoken-verse contests rooted for and hooted at as though they were football games.
"There is a mix of people involved, people off the street, dissatisfied M.F.A. students," said Guy LeCharles Gonzalez, a New Yorker who, representing the Nuyorican Poets Cafe on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, was a member of this year's championship team in Austin. "We have some people involved in the so-called legit journals, too, but the lifeblood is people who feel they don't have a voice elsewhere."
Interestingly enough, Mr. Gonzalez, 29, works as the membership coordinator for the Academy of American Poets, which is at the very center of the establishment, and whose president, Jonathan Galassi, once dismissed slam poetry as "karaoke." Mr. Gonzalez also runs a Monday night series of readings at 13 Bar Lounge in Greenwich Village. "Obviously, we're not recognized by the establishment as a legitimate form, so funding sources that are there for others are not there for us," he said. "But if the N.E.A. fell apart tomorrow, these coffee shops would still have readings."
For the purposes of many arts groups, of course, the N.E.A. has already fallen apart; it is impossible to know how many groups disappeared when their Federal grant money did. But less publicized is that local and state governments are supporting the arts at record levels. Part of the reason for this is that the arts have become such proven economic generators that countless communities have, in the last few years, applied public funds to the construction of arts facilities in order to spur redevelopment of benighted neighborhoods. Places as different (and unexpected) as Las Vegas and Madison, Wis., have begun creating strategies for developing cultural tourism.
In another economic trend, in spite of concerns that the decline in Federal grantmaking to the arts would spur a dwindling of corporate grantmaking as well, that hasn't exactly happened. Though a triennial survey released in November by the Business Committee for the Arts, an organization in New York that encourages and tracks partnerships between businesses and arts groups, reported that the percentage of American businesses contributing to the arts dropped to 39 percent last year, from 45 percent in 1994, the total contributed amount rose to an estimated $1.2 billion last year, from $875 million three years earlier. Further, and since 1994, when half of corporate arts financing derived from the Northeast and the West Coast, the money is now more evenly distributed.
Last year, 60 percent of corporate arts financing came from the South and the Midwest, which is particularly significant because almost all corporate contributions to the arts are made locally, and nearly half of the businesses surveyed made contributions to small or emerging arts groups.
Indeed, even as Congress, in its snubbing of the endowment, has refused to acknowledge the importance of the arts to Americans, the corporate community has done the opposite, according to the IEG Sponsorship Report, a Chicago publication that tracks corporate sponsorships of all types: more than one-third of corporate arts contributions originate not from corporate foundations or charitable contributions funds but from marketing budgets. Clearly, businesses believe an affiliation with the arts helps instill public confidence.
But does it help sell, say, chocolate cake?
"Oh, sure it does," said John Bryan, the C.E.O. of the Sara Lee Corporation, which recently received a Presidential arts medal for its arts support. "There are a couple of reasons the arts are especially effective for corporations. One is the opportunity to identify with the quality image that the cultural aspects of our lives project. Our business is a simple one of creating value by building brands, and to a large extent this happens in the art world. The name on a painting tells you, 'This is an original thing.' It gives you trust in that bit of art, even though it may not be obvious to you why this piece is better than another. The name gives you confidence. The same is true of a brand. So identifying with art is a fantastic opportunity."
Of course, some would question the value of reveling in the corporate sponsorship of art. After all, if art is a mere commodity, if it is so unchallenging as to be popular, if it is fit for mass consumption, then perhaps it is uncertain why we value art and artists in the first place. Isn't art supposed to be provocative? Thorny? Difficult? Art is, by nature, independent, unbeholden to commerce; as arts organizations increase their reliance on corporate support, and increase their solicitation of it, such independence may be threatened.
In fact, one of the often heard complaints now is that artists and arts institutions are in retreat from controversy, a concession to the indignant conservatism that at the beginning of this decade undermined the National Endowment for the Arts, alienated the public and chilled private support. Artists, the argument continues, have conceded as well to a complacent national audience that won't pay to be challenged, only to be entertained.
This is a reasonable concern, but whether, over all, Americans have access to as much controversial, experimental art as they once did is difficult to measure. So is the relative worthiness of the art we are producing. Does more participation in the arts result in more great art being created? Or does it inevitably attenuate our standards? I'm not touching that.
WHAT is true, certainly, is that in most of the country, art is not being made for export; what is created stays home. And for that reason, it is subject to home rule.
"People don't like to see their friends and neighbors in controversial roles," said Ginny Andrews, a board member of the Peoria Players Theater, a community group now in its 80th season of admittedly fluffy fare. "They'll accept it from a touring company, but not from us."
This is not an altogether terrible thing; it is one reason for places like New York, so artists who get weary of the outlook in Peoria have a place to go. And in my experience, most places, from time to time, will surprise you with their tolerance, if not their enthusiasm.
They have never had Tony Kushner's play "Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes" in Peoria, which is what you might expect, but a production of its first half, "Millennium Approaches" was well received last month at Illinois State University in Bloomington, 40 miles away. Two years ago, the Lakeview Museum here had a Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit, which caused no stir at all. "On the other hand, I can't say the room was overworked," said Pat Barton, the museum board president.
In the last 14 months, I have seen a lot of theater, opera, painting, dance, orchestral music, jazz, blues and rock-and-roll. Some of it has been terrible. But much of it was not, performing valuable service in its community. And if I have learned anything in my travels thus far, it is that I have only scratched the surface.
"People pay attention to certain places, New York, Chicago, as if they're the center of the world," said Preston Jackson, a sculptor who teaches at the Chicago Art Institute but whose studio is on the Peoria riverfront. "They're not. There's a healthy art scene in Springfield. There's one here. Benton Harbor, Mich., that's another hot spot. People who want to see art should get up and travel a little bit."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 43; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
An Appreciation of Cute Finds a Niche in High Art

BYLINE: By SARAH BAYLISS; Sarah Bayliss is an editor at World Art magazine.

 BODY:
KNOWN to American television viewers as Astro Boy, Tetsuwan Atom was one of the earliest icons of cuteness in Japan, a country preoccupied with youthful paraphernalia. The wide-eyed robot with a nuclear-reactor heart and rockets in his feet launched Japan's first animated television show in the 1960's. Atom was created by the comic-book artist Osamu Tezuka, and he spent each episode battling evil robots and supernatural phenomena that threatened to wipe out the human race.
 Signs of Atom and his cartoon descendants are entering the mainstream in the United States, as Japanese comics (manga) and animation (anime) make their presence known in American media and museums. The rap singer Missy Elliott adopted a manga landscape in her 1997 video "Sock It 2 Me," while Michael Jackson used imagery from the Japanese animated sci-fi classic "Akira" in his 1995 music video "Scream." Kim's Video stores in New York have extensive "Japanimation" sections, and the Kim's outlet on St. Marks Place in the East Village has a range of Atom dolls (selling for $19.95 to $65). This month, Stone Bridge Press will release "The Anime Companion: What's Japanese in Japanese Animation?" by Gilles Poitras, the latest of several Japanese pop-culture books produced by American publishers in recent years. 
 In the museums, two young Japanese artists, Kenji Yanobe and Mariko Mori, are also bringing their manga visions to the American viewing public. At the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, images of Mr. Yanobe's cartoon-inspired costumes are on view in a group show through January. Mr. Yanobe's survival suits and bulbous go-carts refer to animated figures from Godzilla to Atom and his sister, Uran, or Astro Girl. First shown in the United States last year, the sculptures move, inflate and make noise. But all of this occurs in a rather endearing, toylike manner. An ambulatory blue Godzilla vehicle, for example, is balanced on small tricycle wheels.
Like Atom, Mr. Yanobe's sculptures are friendly, unthreatening beings. There's a babyishness to their tubby profiles. "Atom was a robot who was trying to be more human, a sort of Pinocchio robot," says Frederik Schodt, author of "Dreamland Japan: Writings on Modern Manga." "He established the tradition in Japan of the robot-as-pal, or human friend, which remains a very big genre for children."
Ms. Mori includes more contemporary anime imagery in her photographs and videos. She describes Mr. Tezuka as a "moral teacher" for her generation, someone who taught children about the complexity of human life. Currently at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, Ms. Mori's stylized dreamscapes -- in which she poses -- portray electronic geishas, goddesses and animated aliens. Some of her images, like a photograph of a cyborglike geisha offering tea to indifferent businessmen, play off traditional images of Japanese women. Others suggest sci-fi wonderlands with spiritual overtones, as in "Nirvana," in which Ms. Mori appears as a levitating goddess flanked by alien musical attendants.
Some view Japan's love of childish effects, from female fashion trends to Hello Kitty accouterments, as a recreational release valve for Japan's conventions of public conformity. Artistic preoccupation with animated fantasy also reflects Japan's obsession with comics. "More people read manga than read newspapers in Japan," says Jeff Yang, co-editor of "Eastern Standard Time: A Guide to Asian Influence on American Culture From Astro Boy to Zen Buddhism." "School kids read it; businessmen read it; homemakers read it. There are different manga for virtually every background, profession and kink. In America, the television sitcom is like a fun-house mirror of the American id. In Japan, you have that in manga."
Mr. Yanobe readily identifies himself as an otaku, a term that emerged in the 1980's and broadly translates to mean Japanese computer nerds or information junkies. Mr. Yanobe, who was born in 1965, grew up near the ruins of the 1970 World's Fair in Osaka. As a child, he would play among the defunct robots and deserted scientific pavilions left at the festival's enormous site. Mr. Yang characterizes otaku as young men who trade tidbits of information on arcane topics as if they were commodities of value.
Products of Japan's boom economy and post-information age, many otaku are steeped in comic culture. "I don't hesitate to say that my best friends are TV and manga," Mr. Yanobe says, adding that "Star Wars" is his favorite film. His "Radiation Suit (Atom)" and the female version, "Radiation Suit (Uran)," are antiseptic contraptions supposedly made for survival in a toxic landscape. Atom, silver and pot-bellied, features nine Geiger counters and a helmet with Atomesque cowlicks; Uran's headgear has protrusions shaped like mouse ears. Mr. Yanobe recently toured Chernobyl in an Atom suit; the resulting photographs, alternately chilling and endearing, are in the San Francisco show.
While Mr. Yanobe's artworks portray the comic disasters of boyish fantasy, Ms. Mori's imagery, which has also been presented at Deitch Projects, her New York gallery, reveals demurely feminine future scapes. The childish sprites in her earlier artworks draw on Japan's enthusiasm for juvenile attributes and modern anime's portrayal of women as kittenish nymphets. In "Tea Ceremony III," Ms. Mori's lame hooded cap mimics the doggie garments worn by Japanese women in fashion magazines.
"Play With Me" finds Ms. Mori dressed up as a platinum-blond robot meekly loitering outside an electronics arcade. "A lot of so-called otaku shop at that store," she says. "They are more interested in cartoon characters than real girls. That's why I wanted to stand there." During the photography shoot, shoppers ignored Ms. Mori and her unusual costume. "I think they were shy," she says. "I was too overwhelming to look at.".
Mr. Schodt attributes at least some of Japan's culture of cute to manga's influence. "Animation and manga were originally created for children," he says. "Now they're full-fledged media, just like novels and films in the United States. But they still have a legacy of having been for children."
The presence of manga fantasies in museums also suggests the blurred lines in Japan between fine art and pop culture. "With established Japanese artists like Yasumasa Morimura or emerging artists like Yanobe and Mori, you see the self-invention of a persona," says Renny Pritikin, director of the Yerba Buena Center. "Just as a pop singer might change his image or even his name from tour to tour, these visual artists put on masks to explore social and political conditions. Among contemporary Japanese fine artists, I see a form of magical realism that is tough, fragile and electric."
At the Japanese box office, anime counts for approximately 55 percent of film revenue. Modern anime encompasses many different genres, from the robotic machismo of "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers" to "Sailor Moon," a television show about perky schoolgirl avengers who all die at the end of the first season, then come back to life later on. The technically superb film "Akira" and its spinoffs have portrayed a "Blade Runner"-esque Tokyo, while pornographic anime commands a big market, distributed by labels like Anime 18. At the friendlier end of the spectrum is the anime master Hayao Miyazaki, who is said to have watched "Bambi" 80 times until he knew each frame by heart. In Japan, Mr. Miyazaki's productions have outsold both live-action Japanese films and imports like "The Lion King" and "Beauty and the Beast."
American animation enthusiasts like anime's edgy narratives and emotive characters. "The Japanese place a high value on the feelings of others," says Mr. Poitras. "This is revealed in anime, including satirical anime. American shows tend to be more superficial when it comes to feelings, and that is reflected in American action shows."
In the United States, anime now commands some $80 million in annual revenues, mostly from video rentals.But that number may be growing. Two years ago Disney acquired worldwide distribution rights for nine Miyazaki films, and Disney's Buena Vista Home Entertainment released his "Kiki's Delivery Service" in September. Miramax is planning an English-language edition of Mr. Miyazaki's film "Mononokehime" ("The Princess Mononoke") in American theaters next summer, with celebrity voice-overs by Claire Danes and Minnie Driver.
To Ms. Mori, this pop-culture crossover makes perfect sense. "We are bonded to heavy local cultures," she says. "But pop culture, like what Disney produces, is a universal language."
You've come a long way, Astro Boy.
