HEADLINE: THEATER;
Adobe's Motto: 'We Do What We Want To Do'

BYLINE: By STEVEN DRUKMAN; Steven Drukman, a theater critic for Artforum magazine, is an adjunct professor in New York University's drama department.

 BODY:
WITH the bravado of youth, the Adobe Theater Company, a nonprofit troupe that prefers to spell its name in lowercase letters, shuns other unnecessary highs: high art, high-handedness and -- until their recent transfer to the 170-seat Actors Playhouse in Greenwich Village -- high overhead.
But after their critically acclaimed "Duet!: A Romantic Fable," a pulpy parody of puppy love and American culture, closed with sold-out houses in SoHo last year, this Off Off Broadway troupe took the leap to their first open-ended commercial run and reopened the play Off Broadway. 
 "Our original mission statement was, 'We do what we want to do,' " said Jeremy Dobrish, the company's 30-year-old artistic director and founder. "We hope we are still doing that, but with a little more attention." For the eight-year-old Adobe, a company that has, Mr. Dobrish said, "cleaned toilets and rat droppings in small downtown theaters so we could work there," the move is significant.
Combining talking animals and punning trees with macabre plot turns, "Duet!" seems poised somewhere between Saturday morning cartoons and "Saturday Night Live" as directed by David Lynch, and geared to an audience weaned on television.
The 75-minute show was developed and staged in episodes for five years by Erin Quinn Purcell and her co-writer and co-performer Gregory Jackson, whom she had dated 12 years ago when they were freshmen at the University of Iowa. The play, which focuses on a young couple (portrayed by Ms. Purcell and Mr. Jackson, both 30) who meet and begin dating, opened in its current form in 1997 at the 75-seat Ohio Theater, directed by its two chief performers and Mr. Dobrish. Mr. Jackson, who is not an Adobe member, said, "The spoof quality of 'Duet!' was something Erin and I had done since college, and it was great that the Adobe, with its playful esthetic, found us and we found them."
However, the company's move "uptown" to the Village could not be financed alone. Adobe's average annual operating budget is about $83,000; it has cost $190,000 for the commercial remounting of "Duet!" To the rescue came Dodger Endemol Theatricals, a producer of such current mainstream Broadway fare as the musicals "Footloose" and "Titanic."
"We are fans, pure and simple," said Michael David of Dodger Endemol, which became a producer of "Duet!" "I came to them after seeing three of their shows. 'Duet!' is such good theater that it seemed serendipitous to support them at this time. It's a win-win situation. They need us, and we felt the need to expose the future of the theater. Twenty-five years ago, grants and foundations did this sort of thing."
The Dodgers' support of "Duet!" may reflect a trend in New York theater: producers with deep pockets, often with several Broadway productions up and running, taking financial risks on shows clearly aimed at younger audiences. Fran and Barry Weissler are planning to produce the commercial transfer of Kenneth Lonergan's "This Is Our Youth," now at Second Stage. And the Shubert Organization's backing of the recent "Stupid Kids," a tale about being gay in high school, was a play, according to Gerald Schoenfeld, the organization's chairman, that was "taken on in the hopes of getting young people into the theater."
Now a collective of 26 actors, designers and playwrights, Adobe initially involved six people when it was founded in 1991, five of whom were friends from Wesleyan University, including Mr. Dobrish and Christopher Roberts, 31, the producing director. The troupe's offices were in Mr. Dobrish's living room in the Flatiron district of Manhattan until 1997, when they rented office space from the Atlantic Theater Company in Chelsea.
With his beard, pony tail and casual clothes, Mr. Dobrish, who grew up on the Upper West Side, still looks like a college student. The fact that he and Mr. Roberts called their company Adobe to evoke a sense of homeyness and because the word to them looks like "a visual palindrome," reflects the kind of breezy collegiate style that still informs some of the company's work.
Their first break came in 1992 when a company dropped out of its rental agreement with SoHo Rep, and Mr. Dobrish, then working at the theater, was given the booking in exchange for box office duties. "I couldn't turn it down, even though I had no play," he said recently over lunch in a diner near his apartment. "I threw together an evening of sketches called 'True Words Are Never Spoken,' hardly our crowning achievement, but it launched us."
This early effort, which Mr. Roberts wryly describes as "modest in its ambitions and its achievements," made an instant playwright out of Mr. Dobrish, who has since written or directed most of the company's 20 or so productions. It also defined the troupe's esthetic, which draws from "high art to pop culture, fairy tales to urban myths and traditional theater to modern performance art," in Mr. Dobrish's words. In his review of "Duet!" in The New York Times last year, Peter Marks called the company "an 80-channel cable television system, accepting signals from a host of sources."
While this cut-and-paste style may be more the rule than the exception on Off Off Broadway, Adobe differs from other downtown troupes in its focus on the audience. Spectators can buy beer and soda onstage before a performance and are invited to talk with cast members after every show. "Where else do you get a sense of community these days, besides church or the local bar?" Mr. Dobrish said.
Early experiments with audience involvement included pre-show pranks like an on-stage ringing telephone. And "fun" and "entertaining" seem to be favorite words of Mr. Dobrish and Mr. Roberts.
Frank Wood, an actor currently playing the title role in "Side Man" on Broadway, performed in Dobrish-directed productions with the Adobe between 1992 and 1994. Mr. Wood compared the current "Duet!" "to everything Adobe does, in that it captures the company's spirit: sweet, but not afraid to show the grotesque side of human nature, like Grimms' fairy tales." Mr. Dobrish, in fact, adapted a Grimms tale for "The Handless Maiden," his company's well-received play last spring that was set in both "the faraway kingdom of New York City" and magical forests of demons.
Like their art, Mr. Dobrish and Mr. Roberts wear their erudition lightly, quoting rock musicians (John Lennon and Bob Dylan) rather than Bertolt Brecht or Antonin Artaud to explain their artistic philosophies. And they borrow from everyone, including critics. When Ben Brantley, writing in The New York Times, described Adobe's 1995 film-noir satire "Blink of an Eye" as "Pirandello on Prozac," Mr. Dobrish thought, "Hey, I've read 'Six Characters in Search of an Author' but I should read some more Pirandello."
Recently, adapting an obscure Pirandello play, "Each in His Own Way," he incorporated images of mobsters from popular culture and dialogue filled with contemporary vernacular. The result was last year's "Notions in Motion," a gangster spoof that played with theatrical illusion, written and directed by Mr. Dobrish in a style he calls "Pirandello meets Tarantino."
"Notions in Motion" was the Adobe success of which he is most proud. "It got high school students into the theater, and they were screaming and shouting," he said. "They might never have been in the theater before, and suddenly they were sticking around to talk about the play with the actors afterward."
Mr. Dobrish, who was a psychology and theater major in college, says he enjoys theater that is "accessible" and expresses disdain for the "self-conscious preciousness" that some people associate with downtown experimental theater. "I would often go see things Off Off Broadway," Mr. Dobrish said, "and feel like I was at a party with the cool kids, but I wasn't really invited."
He mentions as influences the director Mark Brokaw ("This Is Our Youth") and the playwright Tony Kushner, but he is more likely to emulate artistic directors -- Doug Aibel of the Vineyard Theater and Neil Pepe of the Atlantic, for example -- and speaks of admiring artists for sustaining long careers in the theater. Richard Foreman and David Mamet, two far-flung names with whom he admits no stylistic affinity, are to Mr. Dobrish "heroic" in this regard.
He likes to call the Adobe "a downtown theater with an uptown sensibility." "Our company believes," he said, "that it's too bad people think of Off Off Broadway as sitting trapped in some hot basement, watching untalented actors being pretentious. Let's not do that."
But will Adobe's downtown following be alienated by the move to Off Broadway and the $45 ticket price it demands? Mr. Roberts bristled: "Suddenly, the media notices you and wonders, 'Why are you moving?' Everyone forgets that that's the reality of the economic mechanisms in the theater of getting your work seen. You'd never say to a painter, 'You must show that painting 20 times and then put it in the closet and never show it again.' "

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Filmmaker's Duty: To Document Her Homeland

BYLINE: By NANCY RAMSEY; Nancy Ramsey's most recent article for Arts and Leisure was on the politics and legacy of Sergei Eisenstein.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
EARLY in the spring of 1992, when lining up at the gas pumps was a weekly ritual of life in the newly non-Soviet Russia, the documentary filmmaker Marina Goldovskaya decided to take advantage of the two-hour wait at a Moscow station. She stepped out of her car, lifted her Super VHS camera onto her right shoulder and began shooting video for her latest work, "The Shattered Mirror: Journal of a Time of Trouble." Turning toward a man waiting his turn in a blue Zhugili sedan, she kept her camera rolling as he called out his window.
"For whom are you filming?" he asked Ms. Goldovskaya, an energetic 5-foot-2-inch blonde. 
 "For history," she said.
"That's noble," he said.
"No, it's not noble," she countered. "It's my profession. I'm a director, a cinematographer."
"Ah, then it's your duty," he said.
For more than 30 years, Ms. Goldovskaya has dutifully and imaginatively chronicled Russia's history in almost 30 films and videos. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called her landmark "Solovki Power" "a remarkable documentary," one "so good that it leaves the audience wanting to know more."
That 1988 film (part of an eight-film retrospective of Goldovskaya documentaries beginning Thursday at Anthology Film Archives in Manhattan) took viewers to an island in the White Sea, in the north of Russia. Solovki, once the site of a monastery, served as a labor camp from 1923 to 1939; among those who served time there were workers, mathematicians, theologians, historians, economists and poets.
Juxtaposed with a 1928 propaganda film that Ms. Goldovskaya uncovered about the camp's enlightened teachings, clean linens and tasty meals are interviews with eight survivors. A worker can "never forget the fine leather boots of his tormentors, polished to a high shine." An economist revisits the night she had to wake up her children, ages 4 and 6, and tell them she was going "away to work."
"Papa went away and now you're going," said her son. "If Nanny goes, too, who will stay with us?"
An academician talks about avoiding execution by hiding as 300 shots were fired at his fellow prisoners. The executioners were too drunk to aim properly, and the next morning bodies still squirmed in a dirt pit.
Grisly tales of Soviet life are no longer shocking, but when Ms. Goldovskaya and the scriptwriters Viktor Listov and Dmitri Chukovsky first began working on "Solovki" in 1986, it was still risky to talk of such subjects publicly. Under the guise of making a film about the monastery, they began production.
"When I told my mother, she started crying," recalled Ms. Goldovskaya. " 'You are committing suicide,' she said. 'Don't you remember what happened to your father?' " In 1938, Yevsei Goldovsky, then a Deputy Minister of Film, was supervising the construction of the Kremlin movie theater when a lamp exploded. Stalin, claiming the incident was an assassination attempt, threw the official into prison for five months.
"But while my mother was crying," continued Ms. Goldovskaya, "my son was telling me, 'If you don't make this, I'll stop respecting you for the rest of your life.' "
THE film, released in 1988, helped secure her reputation in Russia. "Marina is one of the best of her generation of filmmakers," said Naum Kleiman, director of the Film Museum in Moscow. "Her work presents small, individual lives in the larger context of history. In our cinema, we traditionally showed the larger view, with a few figures inside. Her reverse angle is very important. It's as if she's painting a fresco; you can examine each figure by itself, but together they form a panorama of the entire country."
Today Ms. Goldovskaya's son, Sergei Livnev, whose father she divorced when Sergei was a child, is a film director living in Moscow with his wife and their 3-year-old son. While Ms. Goldovskaya lives in Los Angeles, she has returned to Moscow in summers to shoot the five films (all part of the retrospective) she has made since the Soviet Union's collapse in 1991. That year, while teaching at the University of California in San Diego, she was introduced to Georg Herzfeld, an engineer and businessman who had grown up in a Swedish orphanage and moved to Los Angeles. Six days after they were introduced, he "polished off his kneecaps" and proposed. Ms. Goldovskaya is now a tenured professor at U.C.L.A.'s department of film and television and serves on the steering committee of the International Documentary Association, which met at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in October.
Everybody is really making a film about himself," Ms. Goldovskaya told filmmakers assembled at the academy. "You pick a subject that is close to your heart; it's your understanding of the truth."
"I grew up in a house filled with filmmakers and cinematographers," said Ms. Goldovskaya, in response to a question about how she got started. "Many cameramen died during the war; it was so romantic to die for your country. There were so few women in the profession. My father told me that if I went into it I would never have a family, that I would be unhappy all my life. But I was young, it was romantic, and I loved to push the button. I cannot stop pushing the button."
Ms. Goldovskaya often says her field is human emotions, how politics affects the soul, and that her favorite subjects are people with obsessions. So she understands very well when one of her students, making a film about a teen-ager whom he feels has been wrongly convicted of a gang-style murder, may be too close to his subject. "When I begin a film, I write down what it will be about," she told the student. "I write and I write. You hear in yourself a melody of the future film. The bell starts to ring. It will be a long, dark tunnel; you will butt your head along the walls. But if you don't have an angle, you won't get to the light."
Right now Ms. Goldovskaya's own light is a film about a Russian prince, Yevgeny Meshchersky, whose royal family dates back 800 years and who has just moved with his wife and three children to his family's former estate, an hour outside Moscow. It had been nationalized by the Soviets, and now in ruins, its ownership is in question.
Everywhere she and her camera turned, she found metaphors: workers carrying a piano into the once-grand entrance hall in the pouring rain, the prince and his wife coming home with a huge sack of flour on the day the ruble collapsed.
"They drove right into my shot," she said. "Can you imagine how lucky I was? And I followed them into the kitchen. 'This flour will last two months,' Yevgeny told his wife. 'We've grown potatoes and carrots, and we can survive.' "
"It's these moments of truth, little moments that reveal relationships between people, that are important to me," Ms. Goldovskaya said. "They're available only to the camera that is very observant."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

LENGTH: 2965 words

HEADLINE: A Shifting American Landscape;
Downtown, Theme Parks For the Arts

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
LATE at night, along Main Street in Louisville, the Kentucky Center for the Arts sits in desolate silence across from the office building of a major financial supporter, the Humana Foundation. Restaurants are barely visible in the corners of office towers on deserted streets. A few pedestrians turn up, walking with purposeful strides. Cars pull into lots beneath the center.
One evening not long ago, the scene inside was almost as surreal. In a packed theater, a three-hour tribute to the mandolin was in progress, featuring a folk musician playing bluegrass mandolin, a Russian virtuoso known as "the Paganini of the Dorma" and a stage full of mandolinists modeling themselves on ensembles that thrived in the Midwest 70 years ago. 
 This collection of high, low and in between, of classical, jazz, country and bluegrass, set in the middle of a darkened, urban street of empty towers, seemed strange to a visitor used to the more frenetic exteriors and less eclectic interiors of New York, but the odd mix is not unusual in American arts centers. These multipurpose, multicultural, multihalled institutions now dominate the cultural scene, often in ways that have barely been recognized. They are becoming as common as city halls, cost anywhere from $30 million to $200 million, and promise cultural rebirth and economic vitality.
The development of these centers may mark the most dramatic change in the American performing arts landscape since concert halls were built in the 19th century. And just as concert halls transformed the nature of classical music, arts centers are having a profound, unexpected and largely unexamined impact on the arts.
The centers, which range from converted movie theaters to Lincoln Center-style complexes, were originally meant to provide homes for classical performing arts groups like orchestras and ballet companies. But they have become something else entirely. The buildings don't just house culture; they alter it.
They have, in their shape and design, actually created an "arts center culture." And the newest centers -- like the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, or the Bass Performance Hall in Fort Worth -- already take it for granted. Arts-center style leans toward the classical performing arts but celebrates populist variety; it boasts an elite character but celebrates a democratic view of culture.
Bass Hall in Texas, for example, was built with $65 million from private and foundation sources, with orchestra, ballet and musical theater in mind. But its current inaugural season also offers Milton Berle, Judy Collins, the Flying Karamazov Brothers and the ballet "Romeo and Juliet" danced on ice. And all across the country, high-grossing and popular Broadway road shows are often displacing classical groups from their center homes, sometimes for months.
Why have classical arts tended to become less important in institutions supposedly designed for their nurture, and why has a more eclectic arts-center style emerged? Several reasons became evident during visits to a number of arts centers, including three vastly different types in Tulsa, Okla., Minneapolis and Louisville.
* The urban goals of the arts center -- to rebuild downtown areas, increase foot traffic and invite large attendance -- often conflict with the nonprofit artistic goals that the arts center is supposed to embrace. If an artistic event does not attract sufficient popular attention, it becomes a burden to the center rather than an asset.
* Because many centers were also designed as grand civic statements meant to transform declining downtowns, their main halls are often too large for their communities, guaranteeing swaths of empty seats for the more demanding arts -- a vacuum that many centers have come to abhor.
* The high overhead of their new homes and increased competition from the arts centers' own programming add to the classical groups' woes, aggravating their already growing sense of marginality in American culture.
* In an unexpected way, the arts center directors, with the mandate to reach far beyond the classical performing arts for programming, have become the dominant cultural impresarios in many locales, supplanting the artistic directors of orchestras, ballet companies and opera houses. The inevitable result: eclectic strains in American performing arts are strengthened, while classical strains are weakened. Arts that turn a profit compete with those that rely on patronage.
The arts center's creation hinged on one set of premises; its success hinges on another. In 1966, when Lincoln Center was still incomplete, its first president, the composer William Schuman, predicted that its model of a "cultural center" would become "the new establishment." It has, but not in a way that Schuman could have imagined.
THE concept of the arts center developed in the decade beginning in the mid-50's: classical arts were secure in their prestigious positions in cultural life, and the National Endowment for the Arts was conceived. At the same time, attention was ever more focused on the racial and economic problems of American cities. Lincoln Center -- still the archetype -- combined these concerns, beginning with an idea from Robert Moses's Committee on Slum Clearance in 1955 to redevelop New York's West Side.
As the concept spread to other cities, it brought the hope of civic rebirth to abandoned downtowns. More than two-thirds of this country's performing spaces have been built since Lincoln Center was begun, with many of these thousands of buildings being called not concert halls or theaters but arts centers.
Typically, but not always, arts centers are products of financial patchwork quilts. A state or city donates or leases the land to a nonprofit organization. Private and foundation money is used for construction, sometimes with public matching funds. Classical arts groups are often given priority access, sometimes renting at a discount and contributing to the center's overhead. Other rentals are solicited. And the center often puts together its own presentations as well.
Complexes range from the gargantuan Wortham Center in Houston to more humble examples like the Myrna Loy Center in Helena, Mont., housed in a renovated former county jail. Some are mainly concert halls, like the $118 million Benaroya Hall that opened in Seattle this fall. Others, like the $187 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center, are multihalled variations on the Lincoln Center model. Some centers rent out their spaces for body-building competitions and wedding receptions; others have more refined standards. Some compete against other auditoriums; others don't.
But the emphasis on urban renewal is fairly consistent. The buildings do not evolve from their surroundings but are seemingly inserted into them. This can create an eerie quality (one that even Lincoln Center had in its earlier years), in which arts centers seem in a place, but not of it, often rising out of dark, deserted streets and reachable mainly by car. A new urban logic is created: the arts don't grow out of the city; the city will grow out of the arts -- or rather, out of the upper-income demographics associated with them.
This urban ambition is one reason so many arts centers -- including Lincoln Center -- are overbuilt, as if preparing for the hoped-for multitudes. But size can create problems. An opera house with 2,500 seats must often satisfy a symphony orchestra that attracts an audience of less than two-thirds that number (as is the case in Tulsa); the ballet may fill even fewer seats (as has sometimes been the case in Louisville).
Size also affects content. Stars are hired to fill halls; pop presentations are courted for their drawing power. And great chunks of repertory are slighted. Lincoln Center's offerings, for example, are hampered by the lack of a chamber opera theater; its organizations must also scale their productions to fill large spaces. Chamber music and vocal recitals may have a harder time on the national circuit partly because they are unsuitable for many centers. Some arts complexes offer small halls, but even then, operas, ballets and orchestral concerts tend to be placed in arenas too large for their audiences.
The problems with the arts-center model are not just physical; an unexpected tension has arisen between centers and the classical groups that inspired their construction. The groups need and want a supportive home; the centers, though, aspire to more events, more money, more artistic possibilities. And while a center can help arts groups by easing promotional costs, interests often conflict.
This competition has been most fierce outside the largest cities, a situation aggravated by -- and aggravating -- the increasing marginalization of the classical arts. In the 1950's and early 60's, the Louisville Orchestra (which had an important national presence with its recordings of new music) had no home; neither did the local opera or ballet. They leased a local legitimate theater, but the landlord planned to replace it with a parking garage. The conflict ended up in court; finally, after 17 years of wrangling, negotiation and fund raising, the Kentucky Center for the Arts opened in 1983 to provide a lasting home.
But in recent years, the Louisville Orchestra, which has been struggling, has had to seek other performance spaces when the center wanted to make room for touring Broadway shows. The Kentucky Opera, experiencing a drop in subscriptions, cut back its seasonal offerings from five to three. There has been contentiousness over how much responsibility lies with the companies and how much with the center. The orchestra is about to announce that next season it will move its classical series from the main arts-center building to an off-site 1,400-seat theater managed by the center.
Richard Van Kleeck, a classically trained musician who is programming director of the Kentucky Center for the Arts, said in a recent interview, "Classical music continues to be the toughest sell; it's tough to get audiences to come out." But the center, he said, has recently examined its mission and will "continue to keep a schedule" of classical events -- though they have become more marginal than the center's founders originally planned.
In fact, the immense success of touring Broadway shows has caused serious conflicts in cities with limited performing spaces, forcing many opera companies and orchestras to relocate temporarily. Next February, in Louisville, the Disney musical "Beauty and the Beast" will take over the main theater of the Kentucky Center for the Arts for a month, forcing the Louisville Orchestra to play at a renovated movie theater. And last season, the Florida Orchestra could obtain only 3 of its desired 21 dates in the Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center because of touring shows.
In an interview, Judith Lisi, the president of the Tampa center, acknowledged that the potential conflicts might even force classical groups to reconsider their place in the very halls that had been built for them.
"At some point," Ms. Lisi said, "the orchestras may have to deal with the problem and may have to build dedicated halls."
IN place of the steady diets of classical fare originally anticipated at many centers, what is being offered there now? Here politics can be as influential as taste. At the Kentucky Center, the board is appointed by the state's governor; in Tulsa, the facility is overseen by the city government; in Hartford, the Bushnell Theater is completely private and nonprofit. But municipalities always stand in judgment, and these pressures -- unlike those from private donors -- tend to push in a populist direction.
This has helped create the arts-center style. The emphasis is on serving disparate communities, which in some cases leads to diverse excellence and in others to pandering variety. Performances for children are plentiful. So are performances that try to create links with local ethnic and racial groups. In Louisville, country fiddling and jazz have found their way into subscription series. In Los Angeles, the opera company has appealed to Hispanic communities with zarzuelas. The California Center of the Arts in Escondido also courts multiple audiences, scheduling, during the next two months, "The Hanukkah Story" narrated by Leonard Nimoy, a mariachi band, "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," Argentine tangos and the violinist Itzhak Perlman.
The particular balance partly depends on the vision of the arts center director, who, in city after city, has emerged as a dominant cultural force. Ms. Lisi, for example, may be the most important performing arts presenter in South Florida, booking about 100 different performances a year and running an education program for about 100,000 schoolchildren.
In Louisville, Mr. Van Kleeck's programming may be creating a stronger profile than that of the classical arts groups. Last season, the local premiere of "Les Enfants Terribles" by Philip Glass attracted just a few hundred people, but Mr. Van Kleeck believes the performance was important to his artistic mission.
More commercially successful is Mr. Van Kleeck's regular subscription series, "Lonesome Pine," which last season included the mandolin celebration and this winter offers the bluegrass of John Cowan, the African rock vocals of Salif Keita, the Celtic music of Anam and a Hawaiian slack-key guitar festival.
The eclecticism can take on different characteristics in different cities. During an intermission in Verdi's "Aida" at the Tulsa Performing Arts Center last season, a 13-foot boa constrictor was wrapped around the neck of an "Egyptian." It was held out to daring donors who were offered Polaroid photo-ops. In Tulsa, which was celebrating its centennial origins as an American Indian settlement and is proud of its close connections to the Midwestern wilderness, the snake seemed a reminder of how arts centers adapt to their surroundings.
Tulsa's character -- its conservative taste and entrepreneurial spirit -- is evident even in the nature of the arts organizations that perform at the center. The Tulsa Ballet owns rehearsal studios in an outdoor strip mall, where store rents are used to support it. Theater Tulsa lost many of is resources during the 1980's oil depression, but continues as a thriving amateur group at the center.
The situation is far different in Minneapolis, which is a more cosmopolitan university city; the Walker Art Center can even specialize in a playful, often political avant-gardism that would never last in Tulsa.
Once last season, the Sun Ra Arkestra entered the auditorium of the Walker, clapping, chanting and wearing glittering outfits and headgear -- a style set by the jazz orchestra's late founder, Sun Ra, who liked to claim he was a visitor from outer space. But when the group started to play "When You Wish Upon a Star," peppering the familiar tune with shrieking riffs and dissonant improvisations, the audience -- at least half children -- looked as if it had been abandoned by Jiminy Cricket. Undeterred adults filled the hall for more serious intergalactic jazz that evening.
This was not an atypical event for the Walker, a museum spiced with performances. Its self-consciously post-modern presentations of conceptual art, performance art and film easily find audiences in a cultivated city that has the classical bases well covered. (The Brooklyn Academy of Music under Harvey Lichtenstein has defined a similar vision in New York City.) The Walker's director of musical performance, Philip Bither, puts the museum's spirit of rambunctious and contentious play in audible form, including, this season, a cross-cultural band of Afro-Hispanic pop (Radio Tarifa), an afternoon of interactive electronic music making ("Sonic Circuits"), and "A Prelude to Faust," in which the stories of Faust and Job are intertwined and performed by a local puppeteer and performance artist, Michael Sommers, and his troupe.
DESPITE its variations, the overall arts-center style is still unmistakable, tapping into contemporary America's preoccupation with democratization of the arts and taste: a refusal to make many distinctions, a preference for events that provide the greatest pleasure to the greatest number, a distrust of all elite claims.
The clearest portrait of arts-center style was actually suggested by an exhibition at the Walker last year, a show now at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York: "The Architecture of Reassurance."
This exhibit, about the design of Disney theme parks, shows maps of various Tomorrowlands and Frontierlands, their grand vistas and exotic possibilities extending outward from a quaint Main Street in a stylized American town. That town hardly exists today (if it ever did), but its remnants can be seen in the surreal street signs like Market Street in bare, downtown Louisville, or in the suspended corridors called skyways in downtown Minneapolis, which bridge office buildings for the convenience of pedestrians in winter.
At the artificial heart of these post-urban Main Streets, the arts center is creating its own architecture of reassurance, a kind of eclectic Disneyesque dream image rising out of the cityscape. The towering office buildings and abandoned streets of many a downtown lead to a cultural temple filled with fantastical offerings. The bustle of the streets may be gone, but remnants of the streets -- snakes and mandolins and mariachi bands -- find a home even if classical arts languish. That home is a comfortable well-lighted mall, with a series of amusements high and low, rides for the daring, icons for the devoted, entertainment for the bored and, on occasion perhaps, a kind of enlightenment.

HEADLINE: Word & Image;
Let's Be Chromatically Correct

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Americans who are simplistically called people of color seem to have had none of the difficulty felt by the allegedly uncolored in absorbing the evidence that Thomas Jefferson sired at least one of Sally Hemings's children. "Everybody knew that already," Fareed Thomas told a Times reporter, referring to his like-minded African-American classmates in a Los Angeles high school.
The reporter, Don Terry, readily accepted this testimony and inserted a charming autobiographical note. He said that adult African-Americans, too, have never doubted that Jefferson and many other of their ancestors practiced miscegenation freely.
"They believed it every time they traced the black and white branches of their own family trees," Terry wrote. "They believed it every time they held a family reunion, and Aunt Wakara, her skin the color of coffee with cream, showed up along with dark-skinned Uncle Noah, espresso-colored cousin Henry, brown sister Julie and baby Nia, who was smack dab in the middle." 
 Without even a wink of irony, Terry went on to quote Fareed's teacher, Fahamisha Butler: "Look at the black people in this class. We are the color of the rainbow. Our ancestors didn't come over from Africa this way."
They sure didn't. But neither did they ever call the rainbow black. Or white, for that matter. The Terry dispatch suggests that a faster way to escape some of America's racial and ethnic muddles may be for all of us to sharpen our vision and make our speech chromatically correct.
The police and the news media could help by becoming much more discriminating about skin color. Just as they have always distinguished among people's black, brown, red, yellow, gray or white hair and their blue, brown, green, gray or hazel eyes, let them offer a rich array of skin shades. What a boon to social harmony and effective police work if we all shed the sloppy habit of identifying achievers and miscreants as merely blacks or whites, and instead called them ebonies, chocolates, cocoas, coffees, lattes and creams on the one hand, and pinks, ivories, taupes and eggshells on the other.
Think how liberating it would be to read, "The gunman, a six-foot ocher, fired twice at the frail, russet shopkeeper before two elderly neighbors, one buff, one milky, wrestled him to the ground." Or, "Muhammed Jefferson Akeem, the first umber ever elected to the House of Representatives, is being actively wooed by both the Melanic and Earthtone caucuses." And how helpful it would be to detectives if police artists rendered their portraits of wanted suspects in truly descriptive shadings.
An even larger social benefit could be achieved in the national census in 2000. America's mating habits have confused and distorted the decennial population counts since Jefferson's time because the racial classifica-
tions have forced so many inhabitants to make an intolerable choice between "black" and "white."
At the least, the census should have provided a registry long ago for "mulattoes" and "quadroons," and for their descendants -- as "octonegral" and "octocaucasal" or some such. In still later generations, of course, this would lead to a wholly unpronounceable nomenclature, without clearing up the additional confusions created by the remaining census racial categories -- American Indian, Eskimo and Aleut and Asian and Pacific Islander. Worse, the Census Bureau then divides all these arbitrary racial groupings into Hispanic and non-Hispanic subsets, looking to document racial and ethnic strength rather than facial coloration.
Whatever may be the residual political and sociological value of these categories, they should not dominate our thought and speech. They cry out for refinement in the next century. Modern printing and computer technologies would make it easy for all of us to be given a new census form that includes a vivid color chart depicting the planet's full range of skin shades. That chart would be held up against every face to determine the closest match.
Such a supplementary survey would finally produce a record that looks like America. The results could be filed and published both graphically and in a new
vocabulary of designer colors: mahogany, saffron and zinc, among others. Bar-ring any change in our mating habits, what may still strike conservative minds as facetious in 2000 will, I think, appear not only sensible but also downright necessary by 2100.
As we correct our speech and thoughts chromatically, why not begin to clean them up historically, too? Unvarnished color consciousness requires that we abandon African-American, Hispanic and Caucasian as anachronistic exaggerations or falsehoods.
Jefferson, who believed that the starkest sort of race mixing produces a "degradation of human character," obviously judged Sally Hemings as sufficiently pale (i.e., un-African) to bear his child, but still dark enough (African) to remain his slave. Most of his American contemporaries probably saw no contradiction in such bifurcated reasoning. Even a man of great intellect and democratic conviction could love and own a woman simultaneously. Nowadays, we ascribe that attitude to a "timebound" racism -- not unlike the timebound sexism that we blame for preserving the ideal of wifely obedience into our century's marriage vow.
Finding this dusty furniture in the mind's attic can be both shocking and illuminating. Just as we now wonder how otherwise enlightened people could trade in dark-skinned bodies or demand and accept female subservience, future generations are bound to marvel at how so many of their forebears could routinely feast while others went hungry, or how some ancestors could amass fortunes while others went begging. Like slavery and male domination in their time, the inequalities of our day are justified even in the most progressive circles as not only tolerable but also actually essential to economic growth and social harmony.
Our descendants will shake their heads in disbelief. But in that distant time, like Jefferson, we will surely want it said that things were never so black and white.

HEADLINE: Helping the Fish Return Upstream

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA 

 BODY:
SHAD and other anadromous fish -- even some salmon -- are back in the Connecticut River, thanks mainly to the construction of fishways that let fish get past the river's dams. But small streams with dams of their own, also matter, in a big way. Recent collaborative efforts have put fishways on lesser-known streams, and more such projects lie ahead. The plan is to boost not just the fish, but the ecosystem.
Anadromous species hatch in freshwater streams, spend their adult lives at sea, and return to their birth streams to spawn -- unless dams bring them to a halt. Besides the prized shad and salmon, they include alewife, blueback herring, sea-run brown trout and sea lamprey. All are valuable, even the ugly lamprey. 
 This spring fishways opened on two tributaries of the Connecticut in Lyme and Old Lyme. The Lyme Land Conservation Trust led efforts to build one on the Eightmile River, while the Old Lyme Conservation Trust worked to put one on the Mill Brook. "Someone in New Jersey has never heard of these streams," said Steve Gephard, a biologist with the Department of Environmental protection, "but they're important."
Basically, each of the new fishways is a sloping arrangement of four 10-foot aluminum sections (from the Sheepscot Machine Works of Newcastle, Me.), and other components. Each was installed to fit its particular location, has controlled water flow, and lets fish swim past a dam that long ago provided power for a nearby mill. Right from the start, each has proved a success. "We had this question," recalled Anthony Irving, president of the Lyme group. "Was this going to work? The first day we opened, we had herring migrating up."
Jennifer Hillhouse, president of the Old Lyme organization, reported similar success. "Within an hour, the first fish came in. I think it was an alewife," she said, noting its distinguishing fat belly. "Like an old alewife," she explained.
Autumn traffic on the fishways, Mr. Gephard added, includes juvenile alewives and bluebacks, bound for the sea. "What we call 'the young of the year' are going down these fishways in the fall," he said. Meanwhile, sea-run brown trout, which spawn in the fall, generally travel upstream from October through December.
Sea lampreys go up in the spring to spawn, then die. (The larvae remain in the mud for years before they emerge as miniature lampreys and head downstream.) Mr. Gephard stressed that while sea lampreys have caused problems in some areas, where they're an introduced species, in Connecticut streams -- where they've existed for centuries -- they're excellent food for many creatures.
Both new fishways are part of the Anadromous Fish Restoration Initiative, a long-term effort to improve the ecosystem of the lower Connecticut as well as conditions in Long Island Sound and beyond. Partners in the initiative are the D.E.P., the Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge and the Connecticut River Watershed Council.
Tom Maloney, river steward for the council, calls the initiative "a food-chain support program." The idea is to have more fish as food for bigger fish, for birds like osprey and kingfishers, and for animals like river otter and mink.
Mr. Gephard also pointed out that having more bait fish coming and going at the mouth of the Connecticut adds to food stocks in the Sound and in the near waters of the Atlantic Ocean. Fishways, he said, "not only provide localized benefits, they contribute to the big picture -- the whole ecosystem." All that means better fishing, better birding and increased economic benefits.
Anadromous fish were in big trouble after centuries of development along the Connecticut and neighboring streams. Dams blocked them, pollution did further damage, salmon disappeared, and other species were greatly diminished.
Efforts begun in the 1960's to clean up the river, build big fishways, and restore fish have brought considerable success. "We had 670,000 shad this year -- a pretty healthy run," said Mr. Gephard. "With salmon, we've gone from zero to 300, 400 a year in the Connecticut. It's a start, especially since they were gone for 200 years."
Now efforts continue to open more streams. While the initiative prepares to build two more fishways, and improve another, on lower Connecticut tributaries, other groups are working to build fishways elsewhere, Mr. Gephard noted. And fishways are becoming more effective, said Mr. Maloney, as people learn more about just what various species require, such as particular slopes.
But it's not easy. While owners of big dams along the Connecticut were required by law to build huge fishways (costing millions), and a hydroelectric plant in Seymour is now putting a fishway on the Naugatuck River to meet licensing requirements, most dams on smaller streams don't come under any laws. Nor can government agencies afford to build fishways everywhere. That's why cooperative endeavors are essential, said Mr. Gephard. The few fishways in Lyme and Old Lyme involved the Watershed Council, the towns, the land trusts, land owners, the D.E.P. and Federal programs. Each cost upwards of $75,000, with money coming from public and private sources. And in each case local people saw a need and got to work, while people like Mr. Gephard and Mr. Maloney provided expertise and support.
Mr. Irving recalled an action-spurring visit, around 1991, to the Moulson Pond Dam on the Eightmile River (so named because it ends -- in Hamburg Cove -- about eight miles upstream from the mouth of the Connecticut). "I was down there one day, and I saw a sea-run brown trout trying to jump over the dam," he said. "I called Steve and asked, 'Wouldn't it be a good idea to have a fish ladder?' We started working on it."
Land trust members tackled such tasks as getting engineering studies, raising money and working with various agencies. "We were just volunteers," said Mr. Irving. "It was a big education project."
To route fish around the dam and a privately owned hydroelectric plant, Mr. Gephard devised a plan that put the fishway between two sluiceways, one of which needed to be reopened.
Sue Hessel and Karen Dahle, the property owners, who live in what was once a mill, granted an easement for the project. Now the Moulson Pond Fishway stretches across their backyard in a channel lined with large rocks found nearby. "We made a point of making this look as natural as possible," said Mr. Maloney.
Working on the Mill Brook (the headwaters of the Lieutenant River, which flows into the Connecticut) is the Mary Griswold Steube Fishway. Mrs. Steube, who died early this year, originally granted an easement for the fishway, then willed the property to the land trust. Other help came from many sources, said Mrs. Hillhouse. She especially recalled an anonymous donation of $10,000 that arrived one day after trust members had been wearily collecting cash from little cans that they'd placed in local bait shops.
Mr. Maloney noted that volunteers now look after both fishways. They check water flow and temperature, count fish and clear debris. "You can have an $80,000 fishway, but if there's one log, there's no fish," he said, as Mrs. Hillhouse bent down to remove twigs from the fishway.
Before putting in that fishway, supporters checked with people like James Tripp, who lives with his family in an old mill just across the Lower Mill Pond Dam. The scene was once lively, with mills, stores and other operations, but today the Tripps' view is mostly of water, woods and fields. Maybe, Mrs. Hillhouse said, they didn't want to gaze on "an aluminum thing."
But the Tripps welcomed the fishway. "Fish come in by the thousands," said Mr. Tripp, a sculptor. "You see ospreys circling ahead of time, watching the brook." He and his family have seen river otters, mink, kingfishers, great blue herons and other wildlife. "When the fish come," he said, "everybody shows up."

LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
North Fork Duck Farmer Holds His Ground

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
SURVIVING as a duck farmer in the suburbs isn't easy.
Especially when you're raising 140,000 white Pekin ducklings in the backyard. 
 "Houses have grown up around us," said Douglas Corwin, a fourth-generation farmer who lives on the edge of his 140-acre duck farm just past the fringe of Riverhead. "This is not a perfume factory." As the last duck farmer on the North Fork, Mr. Corwin, 39, worries about more than the pungent odor of live ducks and the dogs and raccoons that occasionally sneak into his pens.
As the sixth-largest duck producer in the nation, Mr. Corwin's family-owned and operated Crescent Duck Farm harvests 800,000 to 900,000 ducklings a year, 4.5 percent of all ducklings sold in the country.
The only way the business can make it, Mr. Corwin said, is by breeding a premium bird, improving the succulent variety that gave Long Island duckling a national reputation before higher costs and stricter environmental regulations drove most duck farmers either out of business or to the Midwest.
"Labor's expensive, utilities are expensive, land is expensive," he said. "Feed is 15 to 20 percent higher than in the the Midwest, where it's readily available. We can only overcome the costs with quality and service." Mr. Corwin, whose ducklings end up a l'orange or confit on plates at high-end restaurants like the Four Seasons and Tribeca Grill in Manhattan and at Starr Boggs in Westhampton, has no intention of moving.
"I don't know if I'd want to live in the middle of Indiana, Illinois or Ohio," said Mr. Corwin, sitting in his pickup truck on a gravel road in the middle of his farm with nothing but fluffy white ducks in sight, "where the idea of a good time is to go to Cleveland for a weekend, just to be a low-cost duck producer. There have been operators who have moved that way and done that."
Half a century ago, more than 100 duck farms dotted the East End. Climatic conditions, sandy soil and proximity to water helped build the Long Island duckling's culinary reputation, said Joseph Gergela, executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau.
Requirements to install sewage treatment facilities to alleviate pollution to nearby bays in the 1970's forced farmers who couldn't afford compliance out of business.
Not only the ducks have flown the coop. Just one turkey farm and one chicken producer remain on Long Island. The last dairy farm went out of business in 1986. And only 6,000 acres of potato fields are left, where once there were 70,000, Mr. Gergela said.
While three other duck farmers still work on the South Fork, Mr. Corwin, who hatches 20,000 baby ducks a week, is the largest breeder. And his Eastport feed mill is the only one left on Long Island.
"This is a high-cost area to farm," Mr. Gergela said. "It's very hard to be competitive. They're not making any more land, it's high valued. It's an equity issue. For farmers, their land is their pension.
"We're not farming in a rural area anymore," he continued. "It's suburbia, and it's a suburban value system. People complain about irrigation systems running on Sunday morning. Farmers have to live with their neighbors. People have moved from west to east to live out here where the remaining farmlands are. While they want to enjoy the esthetics of the area, they don't understand the noise, odor and dust that goes along with farming."
Despite the urban sprawl, Suffolk County remains the leading agricultural county in New York, based on the wholesale value of its agricultural products. As the duck industry declined, the grape and wine industry developed and greenhouse and nursery production expanded. Mr. Corwin, who sells more than $7 million worth of ducks a year and employs 85 workers, isn't complaining. Instead, the scientist, businessman and farmer -- who pursued agricultural economics at Cornell University -- relies on advanced genetics, statistics and four computerized duck diets.
"They eat a much better balanced diet than a human eats," Mr. Corwin said, ticking off a list of nutrients, proteins, vitamins and amino acids he feeds his developing ducks and breeders. "They eat what they need to eat. We eat what we want to eat." The Corwins have 7,000 laying females at any given time, each of which lays 200 eggs a year. He picks the parents, grandparents and great-grandparents of his breeding stock from seven different strains to create a more meaty, less fatty duck. Ducks he can be proud of.
"They're smart for poultry," he said, wandering into the nursery. Hundreds of 2-week-old ducks stood and waddled about at his approach, nary an ugly duckling in sight. "They know me. If I wear a red shirt, they get all mad. They're smarter than turkeys or chickens. You can herd these animals from one building to another. You can't get turkeys to move. Ducks aren't as spasmodic as turkeys. They are much more fluid in their motions. You feel proud when you see a nice, comfortable, uniform group like this," said Mr. Corwin, admitting that he is not entirely comfortable harvesting his flock.
Ducklings mature into ducks at six to seven weeks. Along the way, Mr. Corwin pointed out, their voices change. Females ducks quack; male ducks make belching noises. In the farmyard, he grabs a 5-week-old duck by its neck and runs his hand down its chest, pointing out the broad, thick expanse of muscle along its flat keel bone. He weighs the duck on a scale, then uses ultrasound to measure the thickness of its muscle tissue.
"We're trying to take the genetics of a duckling and make it something that is desirable to a consumer, he said. "We're in the meat-production business. Traditionally, ducks had less meat per pound, but now we're making them tremendously meaty, much more than 10 to 15 years ago, while marginalizing the fat."
A three-and-a-half-ounce serving of his skinless duckling breast has half the fat of the same amount of skinless chicken breast. "The muscle tissue rivals any meat nutritionally," he said. "But duck has always had a negative connotation. People don't eat enough of it. People don't cook enough of it."
Four years ago, Mr. Corwin created an artificial wetland on his property to treat waste water. He's about to invest in a new sewage treatment plant.
"What was good for the 70's, 80's and 90's won't be good for the next century," Mr. Corwin said. "The technologies have increased in waste treatment so much you'd be foolish to ignore them. It's an ecologically sensitive area. Being out here on eastern Long Island, it's a tourist area. The Peconic Bay is an important shellfish area. We have to be proactive, not reactive. We just want to be able to have what we have and keep on doing what we're doing and making a decent living doing it."
Mr. Corwin's self-contained business makes use of every duck part. Duck feet are sold to Chinese restaurants. A quarter of a million pounds of feathers are laundered and baled after processing for use in down jackets and comforters.
In the poultry world, duck is small potatoes. Twenty-one million ducks are consumed a year, versus two billion chickens. According to the Duckling Council, consumption is going up 5 to 7 percent a year.
Sometimes, Mr. Corwin takes a thick lobe of duck, marinates and grills it. "A duck steak cooked medium rare tastes more like beef than what you would think," he said.
Could be. Just don't ask his spouse.
"My wife, Tami, doesn't like duck," he said. "We've been married 17 years. Maybe she's eaten it once or twice. She's cooked it maybe once or twice. We're going out for our anniversary tomorrow night. We're going to a seafood restaurant."

HEADLINE: In the Region/ Connecticut;
Revamping UConn Storrs for Over $300 Million

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
SOMEWHERE in the School of Fine Arts complex at the southern end of the University of Connecticut's main campus in Storrs, a student practiced on a French horn.
Suddenly a horn of a different timbre resounded, once, twice, three times, a warning followed moments later by a muffled explosion as construction crews blasted away a ledge for the $10-million Fine Arts Center, which will include a new music library and performance hall, part of the first major construction on the campus in a decade. 
 "These are people who would normally complain if a light fixture was making a humming noise, but they're putting up with it, because everyone is so excited about what's happening," said Robert H. Gray, the dean of the school. "The place is coming alive. It's like watching the school wake up."
At the north end of campus, sidewalk discussions were disrupted by construction noises from a former plaza between the physics and biology buildings where a $37.9-million, 133,000-square-foot addition to the science complex is taking shape. In the middle of the campus, workers took the wraps off a $40-million library renovation -- literally. Because bricks had been falling off the old building it had been draped in plastic almost a decade, but the renovated building was dedicated Oct. 18.
The university is charging ahead with changes called for in a master plan developed over the last few years, with funds from a 10-year, $1-billion program known as UConn 2000, most of it devoted to Storrs. In the $382-million Phase 1, which concludes next year, about 80 percent of the funds and all but four of the 30 major projects will go to the 4,400-acre main campus.
"We will move forward from a campus that is unattractive, and technologically underdeveloped, to a beautiful, technologically advanced campus that will make the students part of the process of learning," said Philip Austin, the university's president.
Chancellor Mark A. Emmert said a successful university must have a recruiting "funnel." "The more students and faculty you have to choose from at the top, the more selective you can be at the bottoms," he explained.
"UConn 2000 and the master plan have really opened up the top of the funnel," Dr. Emmert said. "We're seeing a lot more interest in UConn at every level, everywhere in the country. It's really ratcheted things up."
For most of this century, the university has had a reputation as an agricultural school. For two decades administrators have tried to redefine it as a leading research college, with limited success, until the state approved UConn 2000 three years ago.
There will still be agriculture, but it will be agriculture for the 21st century, in a new $13.8-million biotechnology building, in addition to a new $25.6-million School of Business Administration and in a new $4-million pharmacy building. There will also be recreational projects, such as a $4.35-million renovated ice rink that has been expanded to 50,465 square feet, and residential projects, such as the recently completed $12.3-million South Campus dormitory complex.
THE sturdy, brick turn-of-the-century buildings at the east end of campus, and the newer 60's and 70's buildings at the western end, are being renovated. The Family Studies building, a World War I-era edifice, has been repainted and renovated. The walls are now large display screens linked to personal computers, the Internet, or other electronic systems on campus.
"In the confines of buildings that are 70 or 80 years old, we've done things that make a dramatic difference in the quality of learning," said Scott Brohinski, the university's director of governmental relations, who helped build support for UConn 2000 in the legislature.
Many of the buildings in the center of the campus have come down, or are scheduled for demolition. "These are 1950's 'get-'em-up-fast' kind of buildings," Mr. Brohinski said. "This is a makeover that will change the way people feel about themselves, and about the institution."
The university is situated in a rural setting in the Town of Mansfield, so town officials have been invited to sit in on the planning sessions, and there have been compromises to make sure the work is acceptable to local residents.
"The master plan, for the most part, really deals with the core of the university, and in that respect doesn't have a major impact on the town," said Town Manager Martin H. Berliner. "There were some questions about traffic, and parking, but we've worked on those issues. I think it generally is supported by the town."
Larry G. Schilling, the university architect who oversees the planning staff for UConn 2000, said that there were about 20 major contractors on campus, and close to 1,000 workers. He has hired the Bechtel Corporation, a worldwide construction company, as the construction manager.
He tries to make sure that the projects don't overlap, to avoid major disruptions to traffic and having construction crews hampering one another.
But in an area about the size of a city block, he had the new biology and physics project, the chemistry building and a $13.2-million upgrading of a heating all under way at the same time this year.
Dr. Arthur W. Dimock, assistant chairman of the chemistry department, has for the last 10 years headed the committee planning the new 200,000-square-foot, $56.8-million chemistry building now nearing completion that will replace 75,000 square feet in two buildings now.
"But in fact, we're going to have much more space than the numbers would suggest," Dr. Dimock said. "The space we're in now was designed in the 1950s. I'm not sure it was well thought out even for that time, and our needs have changed considerably since then."
FOR instance, most chemistry research now is done under hoods that whisk away any dangerous vapors; the old building had fewer than 60, but the new one will have more than 230. There are a dozen safety showers for people in the old building; now there will be more than 80.
"We hope never to have a need for them, but you feel a little more comfortable knowing that they're there," Dr. Dimock said.
The university is also encouraging partnerships with industry. This year, Pfizer Inc. announced that it would build a $19-million laboratory for animal vaccine research on campus that it will share with the university. That partnership, Dr. Emmert said, will tie into the school's key strengths in agriculture, biotechnology, pathobiology and pharmaceutical science.
"You enter into those relationships very carefully," Dr. Emmert said. "Intellectual freedom is very important to us. Pfizer's commitment to research was absolutely a critical factor in our decision. What's absolutely critical is that we not engage in development and partnerships randomly, but that we do it in a highly selective, highly focused manner."
But Dr. Emmert said the most exciting change was not the most expensive. This summer, Fairfield Road, which bisects the campus from east to west, was torn up for a $1.8-million pedestrian mall bordered by the renovated library, a new Student Union and other student centers.
"It will redefine the core of the campus as a place where you go, and stay," Dr. Emmert said. "I'm a big fan of loitering. The best campuses are the ones that encourage people to hang around, where you have to shoo the faculty and students home at 2 o'clock in the morning because they just want to be there."
Dr. Austin said that after UConn 2000 is completed, the university will be able to win state support for follow-up elements of its master plan, because officials will see that the university will help revitalize the state economy, and that research there will help spin off new companies that will pay taxes and create jobs.
"We want to make it so obvious, four or five years from now, that what the legislature did was such a wise move, other people and organizations will support the work of the university," Dr. Austin said. "Then, six or seven years from now, we will assess where we are, and if we're as successful as I think we will be at attracting new students and more outside investment, the state may see that it makes sense to do even more."

HEADLINE: New Routes for Moving the Workers to Work, Bus Style

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE bus, not more traffic lanes, is the way to relieve highway congestion. Commuters will park their cars and hop on, if the bus is comfortable and convenient. So say transportation planners studying shifting travel patterns and a changing economy.
Bus routes, established decades ago, usually radiate from the center of a city like the spokes of a wheel. The design enabled them to carry suburban riders to and from the city. But the pattern is changing as more businesses move to suburban locations, and commuters look for different routes. "All over the country, we've realized that the hub-and-spoke system of transportation doesn't reflect where people are going," said David Lee, general manager of Connecticut Transit, the state-owned bus system that serves Hartford, New Haven and Stamford. "We're seeing a lot more suburb-to-suburb travel. Stores, movies and doctors' offices that used to be in downtown Hartford are now in the suburbs." And so, in 1996, the state's Department of Transportation established routes between suburbs. The X-Route, Connecticut Transit's first new route in 15 years, runs from Buckland Hills Mall in Manchester through East Hartford and Glastonbury, crosses the Putnam Bridge into Wethersfield and ends up at the Wethersfield Shopping Center. Stops along the way include Charter Oak Shopping Center, Putnam Bridge Plaza and Somerset Square. The number of riders averages an estimated 350 each weekday. The I-Bus provides weekday express service between downtown Stamford and White Plains. Passengers can transfer to local buses, shuttles and Metro-North or Amtrak trains. Connecticut Transit, under contract with the Connecticut and New York State transportation departments, operates the service. The I-Bus is a federally funded pilot project intended to relieve heavy traffic in the Interstate 95 and Interstate 287 corridors between Stamford and White Plains. The number of passengers averages almost 300 day. A shuttle between Danbury and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's Harlem Line train station in Brewster, N.Y., was started in October to serve commuters to New York City or White Plains. Metro-North trains run more frequently from Brewster than from Danbury. The shuttle is sponsored by the Transportation Departments of New York State and Connecticut. 
 Federal programs designed to move people off welfare and into jobs helped prompt the growth of travel between suburbs and from cities to suburbs. Regional agencies receive Federal funds to pay for transportation for people making the transition from welfare to work.
Mr. Lee said there is interest in starting bus service along Route 1, between Milford and Norwalk, that would not require passengers to change buses. "It hasn't started yet," Mr. Lee added, "but it's likely to be part of the next phase of welfare to work service."
Michael Sanders, administrator for transit and ride sharing for the Transportation Department, said the X-Route had not been as successful as hoped. "I think a network of services will have to be set up, not just a single route," he said.
The state's Transportation Department is evaluating the 16 transit systems it supports or operates. Richard Martinez, chief of policy and planning for the Transportation Department, said: "We're going to look at those systems to see if the routing is correct and determine whether or not we would pick up more passengers and respond better to changes in development if we moved a route. Some were established in the 1970's."
Mr. Martinez said the study would also examine how the transit districts are financed and governed. The Transportation Department, which currently pays 99 percent of the operations deficit for transit districts, will decide whether to continue that level of support or ask for a larger share from local agencies. The department will also consider whether the transit districts should be operated by the state or another body.
Five separate transit systems provide local bus service in the Route 1 corridor between New Haven and Greenwich.
"These districts are organized to work only in their areas. Sometimes there are connections between them, but they're not the best," said Mr. Lee. "Our vision is a statewide system, and we're asking where the gaps are that make it difficult for people to use the bus."
A step was taken this year to improve connections. At the Derby railroad station, buses from New Haven and Bridgeport link with Valley Transit District buses, which operate in towns in the Naugatuck Valley, and Metro-North's Waterbury branch. The Bridgeport bus was added to transport people who had recently left the welfare rolls and taken jobs, Mr. Lee said.
Genia McDuffie, who lives in White Plains and works in Stamford, said her commute on the I-Bus, a product of a connection across state lines, is seamless. She has a 10-minute walk from her home to the bus stop, where she is picked up, taken to the Stamford Transportation Center and boards the shuttle that takes her to her office.
"As soon as the bus arrives, I get on the shuttle," Ms. McDuffie said. "There's no wait."
Ms. McDuffie would not have taken the job in Stamford if the bus had not been available, she added, because the trip by train and bus would take at least an hour. The I-Bus and shuttle get her to work in about 35 minutes.
Word about this convenience is getting around, Ms. McDuffie added, and seats on the bus are filling up. "I've seen people on the bus who have cars and could drive," she said.
Southeast Area Transit District, which operates in nine towns in southeastern Connecticut, is proposing a regional plan in which bus routes would connect 12 towns in the region and provide local service in Groton, New London, Norwich, Waterford and Stonington.
The time between the departure of one bus and the arrival of another at the same stop would be shortened. Also in the plan is the building of major transportation centers in Norwich and North Stonington.
The current Southeast Area Transit system was designed more than 20 years ago. Over the past 5 years, the region's economy has undergone drastic changes, which have placed new demands on the transportation system. Military-based industries laid off thousands of workers, who made up a large portion of the bus ridership, and the Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun casinos opened. With the growth of the gaming and tourism industries, southeastern Connecticut has become a year-round tourist destination.
A bus traveling one morning from Groton to New London and Norwich carried a student at the University of Connecticut's Avery Point Campus, a housekeeper at the Navy Base in Groton, two people who work on night shifts at the casinos and a man who said he lives on the street.
The bus, which has a capacity of 64 passengers, never carried more than a dozen people at any time. But Melvin Prince, who lives in Norwich and works as a cook at the Radisson Hotel in New London, said mass transit saved him.
"I've been riding the bus for the past eight months," Mr. Prince said, "and it's always on time. People might see these buses and think nobody uses them, but they have some faithful riders."
The Capitol Region Council of Governments, comprising mayors and first selectmen of 29 towns in the Hartford area, is considering ways of developing a regional transit system in Greater Hartford.
"One of the primary goals is to determine how to pay for improved transit and build public support for it," said the director of the council, Richard Porth. The council received a state grant to support bus service for former welfare recipients who have found jobs. The route, which follows the Berlin Turnpike from Hartford to Newington, takes most riders from their homes in the city to jobs in the suburbs. "We're moving about 800 people," Mr. Porth said.
The radial routes will continue to be useful in city-to-suburb travel, Mr. Lee said. Banks and insurance companies in downtown Hartford are still destinations for many commuters, and plans are underway to make the downtown area attractive as an entertainment center.
The latest plan to lessen highway traffic is a busway on Interstate 84 between downtown Hartford and New Britain, the stretch where traffic is the heaviest. Mr. Martinez said he hopes to have approval for the project from the Council of Governments by early next year, clearing the way for receiving Federal transportation funds.
"We made a decision that we wouldn't build a new lane in the I-84 corridor," Mr. Martinez said. "Adding a fourth lane would just perpetuate the congestion. We looked at the idea of light rail. But the best idea in terms of cost and potential usage was the busway." Trains are not workable in places like Connecticut, where the population density is low, Mr. Martinez added, and light rail is expensive to build and maintain. In addition, buses allow more flexibility with pick-up and drop-off points. The strongest argument against busways is that commuters won't ride the bus, Mr. Lee said.
What will convert commuters, however, is adequate parking, a terminal with amenities and undisrupted travel to their destinations, he said. "Once you give people those things," he explained, "they don't care whether a vehicle has steel wheels or rubber tires."
