HEADLINE: Single-Screen Theaters Find Their Days (And Nights) Numbered

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
THE LAST PICTURE SHOW" would have been an appropriate film to feature at the Branford Theater on Oct. 10. That was the day that John and Lee Vogel closed the theater they had operated in the center of town for the last 23 years. As it was, the final feature attraction was the far more recent "Studio 54."
"We fought as long as we could, but we just couldn't compete with the 10-screen Hoyt's complex about a mile and a half away that opened last January," said Mrs. Vogel, who began working at the theater selling candy in 1965. "It was sad because we ran a clean, friendly, community-type of movie theater that had been a part of Branford for a long time." 
 Indeed, the Branford Cinema had been part of the town's scene for 61 years. The original building was gutted by a fire in February 1953, but the theater was rebuilt and reopened eight months later. Still, even though its top ticket price of $4 was about half that of the Hoyt complex on Route 1, the 880-seat Branford Cinema with its huge screen could not withstand the competition. Neither, apparently, can two movie theaters on the Post Road in Westport -- one with two screens and the other with one -- that will close Jan. 7, in large measure because of strong competition from a six-screen multiplex that opened a few miles away on the Post Road in Norwalk in November of last year. In an era when single-screen movie theaters are becoming a vanishing part of Americana, several other old movie houses also have closed, including those in Canaan, Cheshire, Madison and Milford. But intensive efforts by community groups are afoot in Canaan and Cheshire to reopen theaters that many residents feel are an integral part of those towns.
Meanwhile, following a heated controversy, construction is expected to begin next spring on a quadriplex cinema in the Wilton town center, which has never had a movie theater; a single-screen theater in the town on Route 7 closed several years ago. Opponents of the new theater, which will be adjacent to a planned 10,000-square-foot retail development, have contended that the multiplex will create traffic problems and negatively alter the character of the town of approximately 17,000 residents in lower Fairfield County.
After a downturn in movie attendance in the 1950's and 60's that was attributed to television, more people than ever seem to be going to the movies in Connecticut. Indeed, there are now about 480 movie screens -- not individual movie theaters -- in the state, compared with about 350 a decade ago in the state, according to Milt Daly, the president of the Connecticut Association of Theater Owners and the chief operating officer of Crown Theaters of Norwalk.
The vast majority of the state's moviegoers are viewing films at multiplex centers like the six-screen Crown Royale on Westport Avenue, one of two Crown multiplexes in Norwalk, which has sharply cut into the business of the two Westport theaters that are being closed. The announcement of the closings came as a surprise, since Westport has long been a magnet for moviegoers in central Fairfield County.
"All three theaters had been doing well, but business has fallen off since the multiplex in Norwalk opened," said Mark Pascucci, a spokesman for Loew's Cineplex Entertainment in New Yok, which operates the two theaters along with a third in Westport, the Post Cinema, which will remain open.
"It's no longer economically feasible to operate theaters with one, two, three or even four screens," Mr. Pascucci said. "And nowadays most people gravitate towards the multiplexes where you have far more choices. Our lease on the buildings with the two theaters runs out in January, and, in a mutual agreement with the landlord, we decided to leave."
Mr. Pascucci said he expected the buildings, which are in downtown Westport, would be converted to retail use. "I know they have other options for the sites," he said.
While the Westport theaters and the one in Branford apparently can blame their demise on multiplex cinemas, the Cheshire Cinema has been closed, at least temporarily, because of the building's condition and a longstanding battle between the theater operator and the building owner that has led to a court fight.
John Salomone, the Cheshire Town Manager, said town building inspectors had deemed the building unsafe because of falling bricks and masonry.
"It's strictly a matter of public safety," he said of the town's order to shut down the theater, which is situated on South Main Street, also Route 10, in the heart of the Cheshire business district. "We'd be welcome to an amicable agreement" between Peter Spodick, -- the theater operator, and Donald Stern, the building owner-- "since we feel the theater is an asset to the town."
Mr. Spodick, who also manages the three-screen York Square Cinemas in New Haven, has offered to pay for any necessary repairs, but Mr. Stern has asked the town to demolish the theater and an adjacent building that he owns and then place a lien on the property for reimbursement.
Despite competition from multiplex cinemas in nearby Meriden and Southington, Mr. Spodick said his theater has been doing well, even with ticket prices at just $2 to $4. "We are able to pick whatever pictures we want," said Mr. Spodick, whose 78-year-old father, Robert, has been a movie exhibitor for more than a half century in about a half dozen Connecticut cities and towns. "It's a matter of choice and consideration, and it works."
So much so that two Cheshire residents, Jackie Sully and James McCorkle, have banded together to raise money and obtain signatures on a petition to insure that the Cheshire Cinema will reopen.
"I've taken my two daughters to movies there quite often," Mr. McCorkle said. "And one day after the theater had closed, I was driving by with my 7-year-old daughter and told her what had happened. And she said, 'What are you going to do about it?' Then I called Jackie Scully and several others and we decided to get going. After all, this theater is a cultural landmark in town. It's clean, with great sound and has a lot of charm."
So far, Mr. McCorkle said, he and Ms. Scully, along with Thory Heye of Clinton, have raised more than $21,000 to be used for repairs to the theater. "We've also gotten about 2,300 names on petitions urging that the theater be saved and given them to the Town Council," Mr. McCorkle said. "We also brought in our own structural engineer from Hartford who said all the building needs are some cosmetic repairs."
Moviegoing hasn't been the same for many fans in northwestern Connecticut since the Colonial Theater in Canaan closed in January of last year, following the death of the owner, Shirley Boscardin. Since August a nonprofit organization known as the Colonial Community Theater Group Inc. has been raising money in an effort to buy and reopen the 75-year-old theater, which showed silent films and featured vaudeville acts when it opened in 1923.
"We expect it will cost about $1 million to buy the building and so far we've raised $25,000," said Nick Stuller, one of the organizers of the group, which has rented a storefront adjacent to the theater. "But we'll need a lot of donations and, hopefully, some money from the state."
Meanwhile in Enfield, north of Hartford, a group calling itself "Save Our Strand" has succeeded in obtaining a $1 million state grant to rehabilitate the 61-year-old Strand Theater, which closed as a movie house in the 1980's mainly because of competition from nearby multiplex cinemas.
"We plan to reopen as a performing arts center, but we will also have a classic film series and show movies for children from time to time," said Gerard Fitzsimons, one of those who formed the group. "At present, we're installing a new roof and hope to open by the end of next year."
In Wilton, the town's Planning and Zoning Commission on Sept. 28 approved, by a 5-2 vote, the plan to build a four-screen movie theater and an adjacent retail complex along River Road in what is known as Wilton Center. The action followed several contentious public hearings last summer during which opponents and proponents of the plan expressed their sentiments.
"I think it's a good idea and only wish they had a movie theater in town when I was growing up here," said Arlene Carlson, the owner of Boyd's of Wilton, a gift and card shop in a shopping center adjacent to where the movie theater will be built. "As it is now in Wilton Center, after sundown everyone runs home. And if you want to go to a movie, you have to go to Norwalk or Westport."
In fact, there are a half-dozen restaurants in the village, along with a supermarket, that are open at night. But, as Ms. Carlson pointed out, not much else goes on in Wilton Center at night. Further, traffic at night is extremely light in the village, which is close to Routes 7 and 33 but does not have a main highway running through as is the case in nearby Darien, Norwalk, Westport and Fairfield, all of which have movie theaters.
Even though the Wilton quadriplex would seem to be a competitor, Tony Sakalis, the manager of a video rental store in the same shopping center, said he would welcome the theater. "It will draw more people into town at night," Mr. Sakalis said. "And I don't think it will affect us, since people who want to watch movies at home will still come in and take out videos."
But Don Klotz, who operates a package design business in Wilton, decried the theater plan. "One screen would be fine, but not four," said Mr. Klotz who is the founder and head of a citizens' action group known as Common Sense Coalition. "The traffic pattern is going to be terrible, and we're going to wind up with a mall complex in town. I think we're inviting disaster. And the charm of the town is going to dissipate."
Richard Paukner, a member of the Planning and Zoning Commission who voted against the theater proposal, said "Wilton is one of the last vestiges of a small New England town in Fairfield County, one of a dying breed. And in my vision I don't see our streets in Wilton Center being able to handle all the traffic for a four-screen movie theater. I just don't think this is the way to go for Wilton."
When the multiplex cinema in Wilton does open, it will, most likely, not offer some of the amenities that Peter Spodick has at his 300-seat Cheshire Cinema. "I remember the first time I went there, Peter asked me if I'd like a cup of coffee," James McCorkle said. "Then while I was in my seat on the aisle in the darkened theater, he came down and gave me a cup of coffee. And if you happened to come in late, Peter would tell you what you missed."

HEADLINE: County Seeks Ways To Harvest Methane Gas At Landfill

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
WHAT Westchester does for today's garbage it also wants to do for the garbage of yesteryear: use it as fuel. Westchester officials are exploring ways to harvest the methane gas created by decaying garbage at the former Croton Point landfill, long the dumping ground for all of the county's garbage. That was until it was closed, capped and became a park about five years ago. Now the gas is simply burned.
The situation could change as the result of a $9.5 million budget item. The money would be used to do more research and eventually put into effect projects to convert the gas into usable energy. The item is in the county's proposed 1999 capital projects budget. 
 A gas collection system is already working at the landfill. Robert N. Matarazzo, the county's Deputy Commissioner of Environmental Facilities, said there are alternative uses of the energy, which could be generated over 25 years in varying amounts. Mr. Matarazzo and the county's consultant, Dr. Rengachari (Nivas) Srinivasaraghavan, president of Savin Engineers in Tarrytown, said the alternatives include the following.
*The gas could be used to generate electricity to serve Croton Point Park and run the pumps at the landfill. About 15 million kilowatts of electricity a year could possibly be generated. Savin Engineers has designed a generator, and bids could be awarded next year to build it. A drawback is that power companies appear willing to pay only a few cents a kilowatt for electricity, Dr. Srinivasaraghavan said, so the economic returns are not certain.
*The gas could be purified and made into compressed natural gas, known as CNG, to run the county's fleet of cars, trucks and buses. The county has already shown in the first phase of its methane use program that purification of the landfill gas is feasible. Some county trucks have been converted and are running some of the time on compressed natural gas. Ultimately, from 1.4 million to 2.6 million cubic feet of gas could be generated a day, for about 30 years, Dr. Srinivasaraghavan said. This is equal to between 1 million and 4 million gallons of gas a year, Mr. Matarazzo said. The drawback to this proposal is that vehicles must be refitted to use the energy. It would cost about $5,000 for passenger cars and $10,000 to $12,000 for buses and trucks.
*The county could build a hydroponic (water-based agriculture) and fish farm at a two-acre site at the Croton Point landfill, to be run either by the county or a private company. Under this plan, the methane gas would be used to heat and purify the tanks and greenhouses and re-circulate the water, among other uses. The products -- mainly tilapia, a warm-water fish -- would be sold. Dr. Srinivasaraghavan said that 800,000 pounds of fish could be produced a year, and that the fish currently sell for $2.50 to $3 a pound wholesale. He estimated that the project could raise $1.5 million to $2.5 million a year for the county. The advantage of this approach, he said, is that the return on investment is quicker. The disadvantage is that the county does not know any company using methane gas to fuel such an undertaking, but the county could set up its own project next year to test the idea, he said.
Westchester's efforts to harvest usable energy from the Croton Point landfill parallels what it did in the early 1980's with its garbage incinerator at Charles Point in Peekskill. The garbage burned there is used to generate electricity, which is in turn sold to Consolidated Edison, from 2 to 3 cents a kilowatt hour.
Like that plan in its infancy, the one at Croton Point has its cadre of skeptics who question whether the technology exists to justify the cost. "My concern is that we are being asked to commit $9.5 million of taxpayers' money when we don't know the efficacy of this," said County Legislator Katherine S. Carksy, a Republican from Yonkers.
Richard R. Knabel, a member of the board of directors of Federated Conservationists of Westchester County and a professor of physical science at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, said, "The idea of using the gas makes sense, but to spend $9.5 million sounds like a lot of money."
Both he and Mrs. Carksy said they wanted more details before they could endorse the proposal. For that reason, the Board of Legislators last Monday delayed a vote on issuing the first $2 million in bonds for the project, Mrs. Carsky said. While this year and in previous years, the Board has approved capital projects budgets that included this $2 million in spending, the actual bond authorization had never been approved by the Board, as is required by law.
Michael B. Kaplowitz, a Democratic Legislator, whose district includes Croton-on-Hudson, was generally enthusiastic about the concept of using the gas for energy. He said that spending $9.5 million did not bother him if the county could recoup it in energy savings. "But I am concerned about the visual, the esthetic," he added, referring to the proposed fish farm and greenhouse.
The question of how to use the methane gas has been under discussion for about three years.
Dr. Srinivasaraghavan said he considered and rejected a number of other possible uses for the methane gas. Those included the production of synthetic fuels like diesel or methanol, the production of electricity or gas for large projects at the Metro-North's Croton-Harmon maintenance site, or using the gas in some form to burn sludge at the nearby Water Treatment Plant in Ossining.

GRAPHIC: Photo (Photograph by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "RECOVERING METHANE GAS"
An example of what could be done at Croton Point Park to turn garbage into usable fuel is the methane recovery system in the Meadowlands in New Jersey. There 111 vertical wells are connected to underground pipes. At certain points a section loops above the surface. The gas is sucked out of the wells, which vary from 50 to 100 feet, under vacuum. Once collected, the gas goes to a processing plant, where it is compressed and treated to remove excess moisture and other contaminants.

HEADLINE: Finding Home Values on a Florida Coast

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
EXPLORERS are still arriving along the northeast coast of Florida. Ponce de Leon was looking for the Fountain of Youth when he reached what is now St. Augustine in 1513. He didn't discover it -- but maybe Nobuko Koop has come as close as anyone will.
A newly retired financial analyst with the Federal Aviation Administration in Washington, Ms. Koop has moved into a one-story ranch house that was built for her on land she bought a year ago in Grand Haven, a new community in Palm Coast, 30 miles south of St. Augustine. 
"I sold my house in June and the next day I headed south," Ms. Koop said. "I've been playing golf five days a week ever since. If I had to describe my life in one sentence, I would say I am on a perpetual vacation, with the convenience and comfort of my own home."
Another of Ms. Koop's discoveries was that these indulgences cost less than they do in comparable communities in southwest or southeast Florida. It is a point that was made by several other recent arrivals, golfers and otherwise, encountered on the 65-mile stretch of the northeast coast from Ponte Vedra Beach in the Jacksonville area to Daytona Beach to the south. It was echoed by newcomers even in the very different environment of historic St. Augustine.
Ms. Koop wound up spending about $200,000 for a three-bedroom ranch with a lake at the rear and views of the 13th and 16th fairways of a new golf course. She said she had taken almost all the upgrades offered by a Palm Coast builder, Arthur Rutenberg. The house has 1,760 square feet of space and was offered at a base price of $160,000.
North of central St. Augustine, Donald and Jacqueline Bosley, retired schoolteachers and avid golfers from Smith Mountain Lake, Va., near Roanoke, bought a lot for $90,000 on a lake at the new World Golf Village, the first project at the 6,000-acre Saint Johns master-planned community in St. Johns County. They are planning to build a house in the $300,000 to $350,000 range. The land is midway between downtown St. Augustine and Jacksonville.
The Bosleys said they spent four years looking at golf communities in southeast and southwest Florida. "We probably would have had to spend 20 or 25 percent more to buy in other places we looked," among them Venice and the Fort Myers areas, both in southwestern Florida, Mrs. Bosley said.
All is not golf, however, in northeast Florida. In the 15-mile oceanfront stretch running south from Matanzas Inlet to Flagler Beach along Route A1A -- halfway between St. Augustine and Daytona Beach -- the appeal is the ocean. Condominium prices are about 40 to 50 percent below those in oceanfront communities in South Florida, said Robert F. Follansbee, who runs Wolcott Realty in Flagler Beach. They range from $75,000 to $145,000, he said. Population density is thin in comparison with South Florida, and much of the development that has occurred aims at a moderate-income market.
Lower land prices in a region of relatively lesser market demand account for the lower price structure. Charles R. Clark, a real estate consultant based in Ponte Vedra Beach, estimated that lower land prices have made it possible for buyers to pay 20 percent to 40 percent less for new homes in vacation communities in the area than they would pay in the more developed vacation- and retirement-oriented centers of southeast or southwest Florida.
In and near Jacksonville there is a substantial burst in primary housing, both rentals and sales, in a wide range of prices, a result of economic growth. One builder there is Mercedes Homes, based in Melbourne. Cora Johnston, president of the company's Jacksonville division, estimated that 5,600 new homes a year were being built in the Jacksonville metropolitan area and that probably 70 percent of the buyers were buying in Florida for the first time, an indication of the region's economic growth.
"As few as 3 percent of our buyers are second-home purchasers," Ms. Johnston said. The Mercedes houses sell for $180,000 to $280,000, and are generally priced a notch lower than other new housing in the immediate area. For example, the company's houses sell in that range at Oceans Edge in Ponte Vedra. Nearby, the average price in recent sales is $611,000 at the high-end Marsh Landing golf-course community.
But it is the new master-planned communities of Saint Johns -- with its World Golf Village as the first major phase of development -- and Grand Haven in Palm Coast that show the region in its strengthened role as a destination and ultimate resettlement location for vacationers and retirees.
A golf course designed by Sam Snead and Gene Sarazen has been completed only within the last year at World Golf Village. The Golf Hall of Fame opened there in May. A hotel and a midrise time-share resort hotel have been completed, and now new home construction is moving forward apace.
There have been 100 house sales so far in first-phase developments by both national and local builders, with homes selling for $180,000 to about $600,000, said Rob Kearney, the marketing vice president. The first occupants arrived in June.
The Grand Haven site in Palm Coast was sold by ITT Community Development Corporation to Lowe Enterprises, of Brentwood, Calif., two years ago. ITT started developing Palm Coast in the 70's on portions of over 100,000 acres of timberland that it owned in Flagler County. The development area was ultimately scaled down to 42,000 acres, and much of it is still undeveloped although many lots have been sold for future construction. But over 33,000 people live there already, many year-round, in such neighborhoods as Indian Trails, Pine Lakes, Sea Colony and Palm Harbor.
It was ITT that developed Palm Coast's first master-planned community, the high-end Hammock Dunes, between the Intracoastal Waterway and the ocean. Lot sales began in 1990, and there are already 376 completed homes -- single-families and condominium units. Its unsold single-family home sites -- currently 154 -- are among the few assets that ITT still retains at Palm Coast, and they are expected to be sold in the near future to another development group. There is nevertheless a sales office on site for developable lots and completed condominium homes. The condominiums start at $315,000 and the building lots sell from the mid-$130,000's to $750,000.
The nearby Grand Haven is on 998 acres on the inland side of the Intracoastal. It will reach a much broader middle-income market than Hammock Dunes. The master developer, Grand Haven Palm Coast Inc., a Lowe affiliate, is building the streets and other common facilities, and last May it completed an 18-hole golf course designed by Jack Nicklaus.
Home building is proceeding apace. Lowe itself is developing three single-family-home neighborhoods, with five local home builders authorized to do custom residential construction. Two national builders -- Centex Homes, based in Dallas, and Pulte Home Corporation, of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. -- are building in three other residential neighborhoods.
Prices for lots range from the mid-$30,000's to the low $200,000's, the higher prices being for lots along the Intracoastal. Home construction began 18 months ago, and so far 175 houses are completed or under construction. There is a golf club, in which membership is optional at a cost of $150 a month, and a village center with health and fitness facilities.
Through Centex or Pulte, home-and-lot packages are available from the high $130,000's to the low $200,000's. One of Pulte's buyers was Dennis Brydges, an executive with the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization in Washington, and his wife, Evelyn. They closed in October on a $165,000 patio home on a lake, in walking distance of the golf course. "In Naples we couldn't have gotten something like this for under $250,000," Mr. Brydges said.
I F past trends hold true we would expect that 30 to 35 percent of our buyers will be avid golfers," said Bill Haussmann, vice president for sales. "The rest will be occasional golfers or they will be attracted to other amenities." Most buyers are retirees with incomes in the range of $75,000 to $125,000 a year, he said.
Another new golf-oriented project in the area is in Daytona Beach. Indigo Development Inc., a subsidiary of Consolidated Tomoka Land Company, a publicly held company based in Daytona Beach, is developing the LPGA International golf community in cooperation with the Ladies Professional Golf Association and the city.
Two 18-hole golf courses have been completed, one of them only last October, and in the first phase of residential development 57 houses are completed or under construction. The entrance to the site is near a new LPGA Boulevard Interchange on Interstate 95.
Local builders are producing single-family houses, close to a completed course designed by Reese Jones, at prices ranging from $125,000 to $750,000. A 3,000-square-foot home on a third of an acre on the golf course, with four bedrooms and a pool and a two-car garage, would sell for about $330,000, said William H. McMunn, president of Indigo.
Nowhere does golf enthusiasm ride higher than it does at World Golf Village. Buyers are paying a premium for condominium units that offer a direct view of the World Golf Hall of Fame itself. Ecogroup Ltd., based in Tampa, is developing 200 condominium units selling for $250,000 to about $500,000 in buildings of one, two and three stories. They use as a facade element a fieldstone from Tennessee and Alabama that is frequently used in home construction in mid-Atlantic states. The style contrasts markedly with the Spanish or Mediterranean stucco-and-tile-roof look found in southern Florida.
The names of golf heroes of the past are embedded in the cobblestones of a circular walkway, about a mile long, that connects the major elements at the center of the development: 80,000 square feet of new shops under construction, the completed 300-room World Golf Village Resort Hotel, and the 180-foot tower of the hall of fame itself.
The PGA Tour, the professional organization of tournament players and the organization that runs tournaments in the United States, has had its headquarters in Ponte Vedra Beach since 1980. It had long wanted to have a Hall of Fame, Mr. Kearney said, in collaboration with other national and international golf organizations. It ultimately joined forces with Davidson Development Inc., the master developer of the 6,000-acre Saint Johns site, to develop the World Golf Hall of Fame as the centerpiece of the project. The location is off Interstate 95 at International Golf Parkway, near an interchange that the developer built in 1994.
A second golf course -- the first collaboration between Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus -- is scheduled for completion in spring 2000. Beyond that the master plan calls for still another golf course.
There are three single-family-home neighborhoods, all in construction, each of which will have a community facility, parks, pools and tennis courts. Five local builders and one national builder -- Panitz Homes, a subsidiary of Beazer Homes, of Atlanta -- are authorized to produce houses in the development. So far 20 are completed and 50 are under construction.
Buyers can purchase lots and bring in their own builders, or build at a future date. About a third of current buyers are planning to build at a future time, Mr. Kearney said. Lot prices range from $55,000 to $100,000. Buyers who are building now are paying from $180,000 to $600,000 for lot and house.
Like Mr. Davidson himself and other executives of his company, Mr. Kearney was active in the development of the Arvida Corporation's Sawgrass master-planned community in Ponte Vedra from 1981 to the early 90's. About 12,000 people live in Sawgrass, which is only 25 miles from Jacksonville and over the years has become as much a bedroom community for Jacksonville as an active-leisure retirement community.
"There's a perfect analogy," said Mr. Kearney. "I think that Saint Johns will eventually evolve into a bedroom community of both Jacksonville and St. Augustine."
Even in the fully developed downtown of St. Augustine, there is new construction aimed at the inter-regional market. An Orlando-based hotel owner and developer, Richard C. Kessler, is restoring an 1888 Spanish Moorish hotel, the Casa Monica, into what he says will be a four-star hotel with 137 rooms and an Old World ambiance, something St. Augustine has lacked in the modern era despite its wide popularity as a tourist resort. It is a $16 million development project, Mr. Kessler said.
The Casa Monica was one of three grand downtown hotels once owned by Henry Morrison Flagler, the one-time business associate of John D. Rockefeller Sr. who wanted to establish St. Augustine as the American Riviera. He bought the Casa Monica in 1889, a year after it was built, and later developed two other hotels nearby. One is now the home of Flagler College and the other is the City Hall and the Lightner Museum.
The Casa Monica closed in the 30's and became the St. Johns County Courthouse. Mr. Kessler, whose Grand Theme Hotels chain has projects in Orlando and Savannah, Ga., bought it last year and began construction three months ago, with Howard Davis of St. Augustine as the architect. It will reopen next September.
"The county wanted to reconstruct it as a hotel and they put it out to bid in 1994 when the hotel market was struggling," Mr. Kessler said. The designated builder was not able to close, and the project long seemed in doubt. "But they stuck to their guns," Mr. Kessler said.
Uncharacteristic as it is of the region as a whole, St. Augustine offers some of the most interesting old houses and one of the few places where restoration has become a major business. "There's not much turnover and there's a waiting list for houses," said Patricia A. Merritt, a broker who set up shop in St. Augustine in 1992 after she and her husband moved from Palm Beach County. "I was a broker there for 20 years, and when I saw the opportunity here I decided to open an office."
There are about 75 sales of turn-of-the-century houses a year in downtown St. Augustine, Ms. Merritt said. Prices are as low as $120,000, but many houses need substantial upgrading. John Valdes, a contractor who specializes in custom restorations, said that many were Mediterranean Revival houses that he has renovated as bed-and-breakfasts.
BUT some become primary housing. Jim Jaffre, an international fast-food consultant, bought a house on Marine Street just outside the city's historic district for $375,000 in 1997 and had it restored and enlarged by Mr. Valdes at a cost of $250,000. "This town is unlike any other part of Florida," Mr. Jaffre said. "Everything else looks like it was built after 1950, whereas this town is older and more quaint."
In a section called the Abbot Tract, old houses on heavily shaded streets sell for $110,000 to $450,000, Ms. Merritt said, and new buyers will often invest $20,000 to $125,000 to upgrade them.
There is also ongoing home development on a strip of land called Camachee Island, bordering on its 300-slip yacht harbor, and on Anastasia Island, reached by the Bridge of Lions from the historic district. There the Thompson family has been developing a waterfront community called Pelican Reef, fronting on the Matanzas River, on land it has owned since 1936.
It took 13 years to complete the permitting process for the 132 home sites, said Paul Thompson. Approval came in 1992. Since then 33 lots have been sold and 22 houses have been built, mainly as primary homes for local residents. The typical cost of a lot with a new house is currently about $350,000 to $400,000, Mr. Thompson said.
For Anthony and Frances La Duca, inland roads are as much an attraction of the region as golf courses, the ocean or a historic city. Mr. La Duca is a motorcycle enthusiast who owns a restaurant called the Camino del Mar in Deerfield Beach. The couple live in Boca Raton.
A year ago they bought a beach house for $178,000 in Flagler Beach. Daytona Beach and its celebrated Speedway are nearby, and Bike Week, which drew half a million motorcyclists to the city last March, also brought 15 or 20 visitors to stay with the La Ducas at their beach house.
But on normal occasions there is more solitude. "When we're up there we like to drive our bike on the back roads around the countryside," Mr. La Duca said. "It's so nice and quiet. It's beautiful."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BACK FROM THE BRINK;
The Fear That Made The Fed Step In

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
THE slide toward financial panic would have begun with a flutter of pages off a fax machine in Greenwich, Conn., each a notice of foreclosure.
The instant that Long-Term Capital Management missed a payment to a creditor, it would technically have been in default to all of its roughly 75 creditors, thanks to loan provisions that required it to remain current on all its debts. Facing losses, those creditors would have sold assets that the firm had pledged as collateral, sending prices plunging. Dozens of markets, from Denmark to Brazil, would have bucked like terrified stallions. 
 The selling frenzy would have roiled American markets in junk bonds, corporate takeover stocks, mortgage securities and even Treasury bonds. Businesses that depend on those markets for money to expand and add jobs would have suffered. So would consumers whose mortgage rates are influenced by those markets and who have billions in retirement savings in them.
Fears of such a financial panic and its economic aftershocks prompted the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to help arrange an 11th-hour rescue of the fund by 14 Wall Street banks and brokerage firms in September.
The rescue prevented the fire-sale liquidation of Long-Term Capital's far-flung, $125 billion portfolio, assembled almost entirely with borrowed money. But even though no public funds were involved, the rescue also produced some of the most stinging criticism the Federal Reserve has faced since its inflation-fighting efforts prompted a national recession in the early 1980's.
SOME economists and members of Congress -- and privately, even a few Wall Street executives -- accuse the Fed of overreacting by helping to rescue a speculative partnership of wealthy investors and the bankers who allowed its speculation.
"Why should the weight of the Federal Government be brought to bear to help out a private investor?" asked Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Others say the markets could have coped with the fund's collapse, although plunging prices would certainly have inflicted some pain on market participants. "There is the impression that the Fed interfered with a market solution," said Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington.
Fed officials have defended their limited role as essential in avoiding what could have become a free-fall panic in markets already struggling with the aftershocks of Russia's debt moratorium a month earlier.
"It was my judgment that the American people, whom we are pledged to serve, could have been seriously hurt if credit dried up in a general effort by banks and other intermediaries to avoid greater risk," said William J. McDonough, president of the New York Fed, in testimony before Congress a week after the rescue.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, agreed that the times required action.
"With markets currently volatile and investors skittish," he told Congress in October, helping to facilitate a timely rescue of the fund "seemed entirely appropriate as a matter of public policy."
Still, critics worry that by orchestrating the rescue of Long-Term Capital, the Fed suggested that a speculator that grows large enough to threaten the system will be saved -- a message that might encourage recklessness.
"We need to get away from the 'too big to fail' idea," said Hans Stoll, a professor of finance at Vanderbilt University and the author of a number of important studies of the volatility in stock markets. "We are not in the position of saving hedge funds, and the Fed or someone should make that pretty clear."
A SENIOR Wall Street banker who is a director of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association argues that the markets for swaps and other derivatives could have coped with Long-Term Capital's collapse.
"There surely would have been price changes, and they might have been significant," the banker said, speaking on condition of anonymity. But as the prices changed, he added, bargain hunters would have stepped in and the markets would have adapted.
"When the stock market crashed in 1987, swap activity trudged right through without a problem -- with less liquidity and less standardization than we have today," he added. "Would prices have changed? Yes. Would the system have than been in jeopardy? I don't think so."
Few critics of the Fed can be found in Wall Street's corner offices, however. Top executives of banks and brokerage firms estimate privately that the collapse of Long-Term Capital alone could have cost their businesses a total of $8 billion to $15 billion, and one senior executive said he believed that the amounts could have been 10 times higher in a market stampede. "It would have turned a machine gun on the Street," he said.
Andre Levy-Lang, chairman and chief executive of Paribas, the French investment bank that contributed $100 million to the rescue effort, said the Fed "was right in raising the question and making sure the solution is found." There was, he added, "the beginning of a systemic problem" for the markets, and the situation "might have unraveled very quickly."
In the end, said Mr. Litan, the Federal Reserve was "damned if it did and damned if it didn't." If the Fed had done nothing and the hedge fund's collapse had precipitated a bank failure or a market panic, he said, criticism of the sort being cast at the central bank today would seem trivial.
INDEED, some people say a key lesson of the debacle is the need for more regulation, not less. Long-Term Capital's troubles demonstrate that "the regulatory infrastructure is not strong enough or encompassing enough," said Henry Kaufman, an independent market strategist. Unless it improves, he added, there is "a better-than-even chance" that the markets will see "future significant financial problems of this magnitude, or greater."
Mr. Greenspan has acknowledged that an emergency like this one could occur again, and he recently called on bankers and regulators to be more alert to the risks of financial derivatives and other investments in unseasoned markets.
"New instruments, like derivatives, afford the opportunity to reduce risk, but they also afford opportunities to become more vulnerable," Mr. Greenspan told a meeting of Wall Street executives early last month. "Borrowers, lenders and regulators need to improve their understanding of the risk characteristics of the new instruments under a variety of circumstances -- some extreme."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Drawings: "Every Flavor but Plain Vanilla"
 
Beyond investing in ordinary ways, like buying and holding stocks and bonds, Long-Term Capital used a number of unusual arrangements to pluck profits from various markets. Two of those strategies are illustrated here.
 
TOTAL-RETURN SWAP
 
This novel derivative temporarily allowed Long-Term Capital to acquire the benefits and risks of stock ownership without actually buying the stock.
 
HOW IT WORKED
 
Long-Term Capital entered into a short-term agreement with a brokerage firm that had access to a block of stock.
 
During the term of the swap, Long-Term Capital agreed to pay the brokerage firm a fixed interest rate on the amount it would cost to buy that block of stock outright.
 
In return, the brokerage firm agreed to pay Long-Term Capital an amount equal to any dividends the stock generated during the period of the agreement and any increase in the price of the stock during the term of the agreement.
 
But, if the stock price fell, Long-Term Capital agreed to reimburse the firm for the difference.
 
THE POTENTIAL FALLOUT
 
If the stock price declined, Long-Term Capital lost money; if it could not pay, the brokerage firm would have to absorb the loss on the stock.
 
CONVERGENCE TRADING
 
Long-Term Capital looked for securities whose prices normally moved in tandem. For example, the prices of corporate bonds usually fall within a certain range of the price of a U.S. Treasury bond of the same maturity. When these prices deviated from their historical relationship, the fund tried to exploit the divergence using a technique called convergence trading.
 
HOW IT WORKED
 
In one convergence trade, Long-Term Capital noted that the prices of some Brady bonds -- issued by developing nations and backed by U.S. Treasury bonds -- had risen faster than the prices of non-Brady bonds issued by those same nations.
 
Long-Term Capital borrowed Brady bonds and sold them, promising to replace them in the future, a tactic called selling short.
 
Long-Term Capital then bought non-Brady bonds issued by the same countries.
 
If the price gap narrowed between the Brady bonds and the non-Brady bonds, Long-Term Capital would profit. For example, if the Brady bonds fell in value, it would cost less to replace them. If the non-Brady bonds gained in value, the fund could make money by selling them.
 
THE POTENTIAL FALLOUT
 
If the gap in prices widened, Long-Term Capital could lose big on both bets. And if the fund could not replace the borrowed Brady bonds, the lending institution would have to replace them at its own expense.
 
(Illustrations by Michael Linley)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
What If the Legislature Really Deserves a Raise?

BYLINE: By David Kocieniewski; David Kocieniewski reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
No, that silence emanating from the New Jersey State House isn't the symptom of some epidemic of legislative laryngitis. There's no mime contest going on, pitting the Assembly against the state Senate. The peculiar hush surrounding New Jersey's elected officials these days is actually one of the most time-honored forms of political shadow play: the nearly imperceptible sound of government officials beginning to raise their own pay.
The state Assembly took the first surreptitious step late last month, by voting -- without debate -- to authorize a salary commission to study the pay of all three branches of government. Still, one of the sponsors of the bill, Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon, insists that the issue isn't pay increases for legislators, but pay equity for New Jersey's judges. Governor Whitman won't publicly address the issue until, and unless, legislators summon up the fortitude to pass a pay increase plan, according to her press secretary, Jayne O'Connor. But Ms. O'Connor made certain that the Governor's no comment explicitly stated Mrs. Whitman's aversion to the dreaded R-word, by volunteering that the Governor is not considering raises for members of her cabinet. 
 In fact, the issue has rendered so many eloquent people speechless, that it might be easy to overlook the fact that there's a strong case to be made that New Jersey legislators do indeed deserve a raise.
That may sound unusual in this age of civic cynicism and widespread dismay at the state of American democracy. After all, New Jersey's state legislators are paid $35,000 a year, plus health benefits and some expenses, and are supposed to consider their positions part-time jobs. Tax-relief advocates such as John Budzash argue that the lawmakers already earn more than most full-time employees in New Jersey and don't deserve a raise until their constituents also see an increase. "They've done a mediocre job," said Mr. Budzash, founder of Hands Across New Jersey, a tax watchdog group. "Do most employers give their workers a pay raise if they're only doing a mediocre job?"
According to Gerald Pomper, a political science professor at Rutgers University, the answer to that question is yes. Although productivity bonuses are used as an incentive in many businesses, the vast majority of American workers receive periodic raises, either in the form of cost-of-living adjustments or contract raises, regardless of performance.
What's more, Mr. Pomper argues, New Jersey state senators perform a more rigorous, complex task than most workers -- including legislators in many other states. New Jersey lawmakers have to wrangle with some of the thorniest problems of the day, from waste hauling and economic development to transportation and school funding. State senators and members of the Assembly must decide how New Jersey spends its $17.9 billion budget, houses its thousands of prison inmates; regulates its insurance companies; whether it subjects its student athletes to drug tests. Even emotional issues like what denomination of trout should be designated the state fish (Brook trout). All this, while placating that most cantankerous of creatures, the New Jersey voter.
"You ought to think of these people as mid-level executives," Mr. Pomper said. "But they get paid what you'd pay a mid-level clerk."
When compared to their counterparts in other states, New Jersey legislators are the 14th best paid, according statistics from to the National Conference of State Legislatures. They get more than the $16,760 Connecticut pays its state representatives, but a pittance compared to the $75,600 annual salary plus $119 per diem given to California lawmakers.
But a closer look at the duties involved shows that New Jersey's lawmakers have more duties, and a more time-consuming schedule than representatives in other states. In New York, for example, where the legislative session usually lasts just six months, lawmakers are paid $57,800 and are now pushing for a $20,000 increase. New Jersey's legislative calendar runs throughout the year, and although the legislature usually only meets two days a week, many representatives say they spend 40 to 50 hours on their governmental duties, not counting the arduous work of campaigning.
The Senate Majority Leader, John O. Bennett, , one of the few state legislators willing to tiptoe near the issue, says the pay issue, which hasn't been addressed in a decade, could be deterring many quality people from running for office.
"Anyone who's in this for the money has a lot of problems," said Mr. Bennett, a Republican from Monmouth. "You don't want the pay to reach a level where smart, capable people aren't interested because it just isn't worth the time."
Interestingly, one of the few people willing to speak out in favor of granting lawmakers a raise is one the legislature's most outspoken critics, Sam Perelli, state chairman of United Taxpayers of New Jersey. Mr. Perelli says the legislature is now dominated by lawyers who can supplement their government income in the private sector or by "double-dippers" who earn two public sector salaries. By raising the pay to a more livable wage, Mr. Perelli said the state would ultimately make the legislature more closely resemble the make-up of the state itself.
"It would open it up to all the carpenters and auto mechanics and secretaries who can't afford to support their families on $35,000 a year," he said. "We need more Minutemen and Minutewomen there. That way, you wouldn't need to take opinion polls. You'd have the real voice of the public sitting right there in Trenton."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
It's Never Too Soon for the Squirt to Wise Up

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
THE two words that strike the most terror into the hearts of educators these days are "core curriculum." This refers to the Department of Education's list of 61 skills that each New Jersey school child will have to master by the time today's fifth graders graduate in 2006.
Many things one might expect are on this list: reading, writing and arithmetic, for example. And then there are those other things that the state of New Jersey also considers important enough to have enumerated. Fourth graders should be able to hop, skip and jump (Standard 2.5). Eighth graders should recognize visual messages of irony (Standard 3.5). And 12th graders must be able to analyze "the responsibilities, joys, demands and challenges of parenthood" (Standard 2.4). 
 Now, I'm in favor of irony as much as the next person, but what I'm wondering about is how the geniuses in Trenton are going to measure it. Because the scary thing about the core curriculum is not that the state wants children to become the temperate, well-rounded, intellectually sophisticated people we are not, but that it's going to put it all on a standardized test. By 2006, one presumes, 12th graders will have to hop on one foot and point out the funniest lines in an Erma Bombeck column.
In fact, it's already started. In last year's Elementary School Proficiency Assessment, given to all fourth graders, each student had to give a short speech (Standard 3.1). There were also several open-ended questions. Unfortunately, I cannot report on how well last year's fourth graders did. Although the test was given in May, the state has not finished grading it yet.
But that isn't all. Now Trenton has proposed a new set of graduation requirements and a school-to-work initiative so sweeping as to make the core curriculum look like the ABC's. Among the proposals: "career awareness" for students starting in kindergarten, a "career plan" for each student starting in fifth grade and a system of "career majors" (the state provides a menu of 14) starting at grade nine. All 11th and 12th graders would have to work in some kind of career-related job one day a week.
I won't even go into what happens to districts that don't get with the new program quickly enough. Suffice it to say that New Jersey schools are preparing their fourth graders for this year's tests as though they were planning the invasion of Normandy. The stress goes from the superintendent's office down to the playground.
It doesn't take a rocket scientist to understand the motivation behind the initiatives. The core curriculum, in its breadth, speaks to the desire to create little Renaissance men and women, people versed in arts and sciences, people who will be good citizens, not just drones. Creating well-rounded people is a fine goal. It's the bureaucratization of such a goal that seems misguided. It's the same codifying impulse that, in health care, has taken power from doctors and given it to 1-800 operators. Here, it turns teachers into test administrators.
But the impetus behind school-to-work and the new graduation requirements stems from a different value, that of creating smart, snappy workers to make sure the United States remains a world-class economic power. I'm not making this up. "America is losing the war with respect to international competition," Ellen Schechter, New Jersey's assistant commissioner of education, told me in a telephone interview. "Unless we significantly raise our standards for all students, then America will continue to lag."
It's all about keeping up with the Japanese.
Putting international competition on the backs of children makes me queasy. Take the Olympics, the very symbol of excellence, perseverance and national pride. The idea of little girls waking every day at 4 A.M., endlessly cutting the same patterns in the ice, all to win Olympic gold, saddens me. It's the opposite of well-roundedness.
And when in 1996, Kerri Strug, the teen-age American gymnast, became a hero by making her final vault despite obvious physical pain, I was appalled. How, I wondered, could her coach allow an injured child to make that leap? The picture of Kerri Strug, crying tears of agony, being carried around as her teammates collected gold medals, filled me with pathos, not pride.
Just how low is our national self-esteem that we have made success more important than childhood? To Marilyn Birnbaum, superintendent of . the North Plainfield public schools, that is what Trenton's new testing plan amounts to.
"In the spingtime, the children should be playing outside," Dr. Birnbaum said. "Instead, they are so stressed out."

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Overcoming a Door Jam

BYLINE: By INGRID EISENSTADTER 

 BODY:
FOUR years have passed since Barry Tesser plunked down $1,500 for a sofa bed at Jennifer Convertibles. It had deep cushions, a high upholstered back and heavily padded armrests.
This was one fat couch. Mr. Tesser's apartment, however, had a skinny Manhattan doorway, and that presented a delivery problem. Say hello to the Z Brothers, a sofa disassembly service, which for 25 years has been doing a good business getting big couches through small city entryways. 
 "At first I was extremely leery of buying a couch that had to be taken apart to deliver," Mr. Tesser said. But that was the couch he wanted. It took the Z Brothers about 20 minutes to disassemble the sofa bed, right on the street, and about half an hour to reassemble it inside Mr. Tesser's Murray Hill apartment.
Mr. Tesser and the Z Brothers are part of the city's "tight fit" economy: the business of squeezing, disassembling and hoisting fatter-than-your-doorway pianos, pool tables, hot tubs, furniture, appliances and artwork to get them into urban spaces. Some companies even design their products to come apart easily, while some movers make cardboard mock-ups of items to test how snug the fit is. But whatever the strategy, the need is there.
Just ask Mr. Tesser. He sold his sofa bed in August and called the Z Brothers back to get the old one out and the new one in. In the intervening years, however, he had moved from one Murray Hill address to another, and he called the Z Brothers then, too. All told, Mr. Tesser has spent more than $600 trucking his sofa beds around town; just another routine expenditure in a city where people hail cabs to take them to their cars.
When Joe Zeolla, who owns the Z Brothers with his wife, Diane, started his business, he also had a regular delivery service hauling couches that did not need to be broken down. But now, "We only deliver couches that need to be disassembled," he said. "There's so much call for it, we don't bother with just delivery anymore."
Mr. Zeolla said his company, based in Thornwood, in Westchester County, takes apart and puts together 150 couches a week, mostly for delivery in the five boroughs. A typical disassembly, reconstruction and move costs $165, said Mr. Zeolla, adding that expensive custom sofas held together by glue and dowels instead of nails can cost up to $600. But the profits aren't guaranteed.
"Once my son was reassembling a couch upholstered in silk," Mr. Zeolla said of Joe Jr., a vice president in the business, "and he caught his hand on a staple and got blood on the fabric." Mr. Zeolla paid $45 to a dry cleaner and $200 for another yard of fabric, plus money for a seamstress. He charged just $400 for the job.
Carl Demler, owner of Bronx-based AAA Beethoven Transfer, does for pianos what Mr. Zeolla does for sofas. Mr. Demler's business moves and disassembles about 1,000 pianos a year, he said, including a half-ton, 9-foot-6-inch, $150,000 Bosendorfer, made in Vienna, which his movers occasionally march up and down four rickety flights of stairs into a West Side recording studio.
The price of lugging a piano varies. To move a small spinet from an elevator building to another elevator building costs $110, Mr. Demler said, while disassembling and moving a concert grand costs up to $1,000.
Other variables include $45 an hour for travel time on long-distance moves, Mr. Demler said, and $25 per flight of stairs if the piano does not fit into the elevator. At least once, Mr. Demler recalled, he and his workers carried a piano up 15 stories.
But creativity is as useful as muscle in this business. Once, Mr. Demler said, when his workers were moving a grand piano for Leonard Bernstein, "the fit through the door was so tight we couldn't measure it accurately enough." To figure out the angle of attack, he said, "We made a cardboard mock-up and banged that around for a while, instead of Bernstein's Steinway."
Makers of big household items often design disassembly into their wares. Ron Blatt, the third-generation owner of Blatt Billiards, said all his pool tables typically disassembled into 30 to 50 pieces.
But New York businesses often build easy disassembly into items that do not usually have that feature. "Most Castros are made to come apart because our sofas have been built for this market," said Jerry Benson, manager of the reupholstery division of Castro Convertibles.
Not all manufacturers build to make breaking down easy, however, even if, like Donghia, they specialize in big, expensive custom-made furniture. Customers or their interior decorators must make sure the furniture fits, said Emily Nomer, vice president of operations, adding, "We don't accept returns for this."
For such items, hoisting, though sometimes expensive, may be an alternative. Frank Narcisco, president of Dun-Rite Movers of the Bronx, has hoisted furniture, hot tubs, Batman (for a promotion) and even Godzilla (for a film). He often lifts trees to terraces; one client wanted 30-foot logs for an interior design scheme.
Recently, Mr. Narcisco moved a man from a three-room apartment to a brownstone six blocks away at a cost of $5,000. "Every piece of furniture had to be hoisted through a window," Mr. Narcisco said.
In hoisting, when windows must be removed, "Everything is systemized," he said. "Glaziers take the window out half hour to hour before we hoist, and they hang around to reconstruct the window after the move is completed."
Rope hoisting works well even for heavy objects. Robert Degen, who with his wife, Elie, owns Auer's Moving and Rigging Company, said his workers can hoist up to 1,500 pounds that way. But to move a 7 1/2-ton sculpture by Charles Ray, a Los Angeles artist, into the Whitney Museum of American Art in September 1997, Mr. Degen had to use the company crane.
Yet not all fatter-than-your-doorway stories end in success. Sometimes, said Mr. Demler, particularly in basements, a piano that has been moved in cannot be moved out because the room has been redesigned. And some squeezes are just too snug. Ms. Nomer of Donghia could not get her queen-size box springs up a narrow staircase and under the low ceilings of her city apartment.
Now, "I sleep on a mattress on the floor," she said.
 
War Stories On the Move
UP AND OVER -- The couch was "as big as a house," said Joe Zeolla of Z Brothers, a sofa-disassembly company. Even after the arms and back were removed, the couch still would not fit into the elevator or on the stairs. The solution: the office building next door, which had a wider staircase. "We brought the springs over the roof to the other roof," he said. Luckily, it was a penthouse delivery.
 
HIGH ART -- Robert Degen, of Auer's Moving & Rigging Company, said his highest lift, 48 floors, was of a $1 million painting into an East Side apartment. "After the 10th floor you can no longer see what you're hoisting," he said, "and you need a man on the roof with a radio." Cost: $5,000.
 
ON A TEAR -- "15 years ago we were moving a piano that got stuck on a narrow staircase," said Carl Demler, of AAA Beethoven Transfer. That normally might kill amove, but not this time. "The owner of the piano was a carpenter and he said, 'Tear the wall down' and so we did. Then he built it back up."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Masters of Jersey;
Wall Street Shudders At Life Across the River

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
TO the surprise of almost no one, the New York Stock Exchange has agreed to stay in New York. Whether its well-heeled officials really, truly, turn-blue-and-die meant their many threats to move to New Jersey will probably never be known.
After years of negotiations, the exchange finally muscled city and state officials into coming up with $900 million in cash and tax breaks for a new trading complex in lower Manhattan. The exchange's board still has to vote, but by Friday, it was virtually a done deal. 
 But buckets of money aside, there are certain intangibles that add up to a strong case that they were never really serious about leaving. There are, after all, some things that you just can't put a price on.
Start with the name problem. The New Jersey Stock Exchange. The Jersey City Stock Exchange. Actually, officials had anticipated that problem long ago and secured the right to call themselves the New York Stock Exchange wherever they might land. Still, there would be the inevitable jokes.
"People use the phrase Wall Street around the world," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association. "It's a brand name and a marketing image. It's Coca-Cola; it's Scotch tape. The New York Stock Exchange would jeopardize its enormous psychological and marketing value if it moved very far away from Wall Street."
Some companies will move part of their operations to less expensive space in New Jersey or elsewhere, Mr. Shostal said. For an institution like the New York Stock Exchange, however, there is an incalculable value in being in New York, where the financial industry is concentrated.
In the 1980's, Mr. Shostal made his living luring New York companies to Jersey City for Cushman Realty. He jumped through hoops putting together a deal to build a broadcasting headquarters for NBC in Jersey City, only to see NBC snap up a $100 million tax break to stay at Rockefeller Center. "We knew Tom Brokaw was not going anywhere," he said. "The people in the bright red suspenders and the silk ties are not going to go to Jersey City."
After all, New Jersey is off the beaten limo track. Could the masters of the universe have handled the logistics? The trip from, say, Greenwich would border on indignity. The train to Grand Central, then the subway to Times Square, then a transfer to a subway to Penn Station, a walk through the tunnels to get the Path train for the trip under the Hudson River to Jersey City. Then a taxi or who knows what to the new quarters.
And could they really leave behind the headquarters of Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Salomon Smith Barney, or the restaurants, or the recognition of having made it in New York?
Mr. Shostal did get Merrill Lynch to move several thousand back office workers to Jersey City. But, he said, the tax breaks and subsidies on either side of the river are merely icing on the cake. "The vast majority of tenants locate where they need to for business reasons," Mr. Shostal said. "The bidding war between the states is really a milking of the public sector, rather than a determining factor in where they want to go."
There is no question that the New York Stock Exchange, which pays about $51 million a year in a variety of taxes, is cramped at its 100-year-old home on Wall Street. On an average day, 680 million shares are traded on the market, up from 160 million 10 years ago. Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the exchange, who lives on Long Island, always maintained that he wanted to remain in New York. Yet, new construction is always a difficult proposition in Manhattan.
In playing the relocation card, the Stock Exchange was no different than Mercedes-Benz, Nebraska Beef, Intel Corporation or any company that has pitted one state against another, from Alabama to Maine and California. Corporate relocation has had as much to do with the chairman's comfort as with economics. In a study of 38 companies that left Manhattan in the 1970's, the urban planner William H. Whyte found that 31 moved to within 8 miles of the chairman's home.
Sometimes, the flight to the suburbs ends in a crash landing. Mr. Whyte found that 17 of the 38 departed companies were later bought out or raided, or merged with a dominant partner. A majority posted lower-than-average profits, while a comparable group of three dozen major companies that remained behind saw their stock valuation jump an average of 277 percent.
BUT this is an old movie. In 1990, New Jersey offered to build New York's five commodity exchanges a $100 million complex at the Harborside Financial Center before New York offered a more generous deal. Five years later, the Cotton Exchange signed a letter of intent to move to New Jersey, but New York countered with a higher bounty and the traders stayed put.
Even the developers in New Jersey who talked to the the New York Stock Exchange privately acknowledged long ago that they had little chance of luring away the Stock Exchange.
Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, said the New York Stock Exchange needs to be in Manhattan to retain its crown as the world's largest equity market, especially with Frank G. Zarb's Nasdaq moving to New York and merging with the American Stock Exchange.
"New Jersey may be a better place to live but it's not a better place to work," said Mr. Moss. "There is more of a chance of schmoozing and acquiring random information in an hour in the hallways, on the streets, at lunch or on the concourse at Grand Central Terminal in New York than there is by spending a week in a parking lot in New Jersey."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The New York Stock Exchange, left, will be staying in Manhattan. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
The Bubble Is Back, Compliments Of the Fed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THIS has been a very strange year. Consider these events:
A 24-year-old woman shakes the Presidency. 
 A septuagenarian senator rockets into space.
Stocks plummet for a couple of months, then turn around and set new highs by the end of November, leaving many to wonder why they fell so far in the first place.
Charles I. Clough Jr., chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company recently took some time -- before Thursday's 185-point selloff of the Dow Jones industrial average -- to talk about developments in the financial markets, and to share his ideas on the year ahead.
 
Q. It has seemed for a while, given the market's upward moves, as if Asia, Russia, Long-Term Capital and Brazil never happened. Are the steps that have been taken to deal with these problems sufficient?
 
A. We have thrown a lot of money at a lot of problems, but throwing money at them doesn't necessarily solve them.
It is really hard to make the case that foreign events caused the mighty, powerful reserve currency capital market to collapse. It closed because American corporations are spending so much right now on investment they are running big cash deficits. And that led the Federal Reserve Board to throw a tremendous amount of money at the capital markets. It is that liquidity that is helping stocks.
 
Q. When they try to explain the money that is flowing into the market, a lot of folks cite big cash balances in money market funds and at mutual funds. Do you buy that?
 
A. The stock market has seen its capitalization increase by at least $1.5 trillion in the last two months. You can't do that with normal savings. There is something powerful underneath this thing, and I would argue it is the Fed.
 
Q. This all sounds rather ominous. Is the market's recovery really that tenuous?
 
A. We are the biggest bulls in the world. But the real question the market is going to have to deal with is what happens when the economy slows. The Fed has now reflated the equity market bubble.
The risk is that next spring they will be looking at an even bigger bubble at a time when the economy will be slowing and profits will still be declining.
 
Q. A lot of people have recently been talking more optimistically about profits, if not in the first half of the year, then later on. You seem to take issue with that view.
 
A. I think the argument is flawed. For the last five quarters, profits have been flat to down in the context of a Goldilocks economy. The basis for profits is fantastically positive, and yet they are weak.
I don't know if we will go into a recession or not next year. But I do know we will run that risk, and will go through a period of very, very sluggish growth, a time when investment spending will slow. When that happens, spending, income growth, profit growth and employment will all be weaker.
 
Q. Are the announcements of the Exxon-Mobil merger and Boeing's production cutbacks examples of that?
 
A. They sure are. So was Intel's decision to cut capital spending by 40 percent, which it announced a couple of weeks ago. I think we are going to see more of that. We have had the biggest capital spending boom in history. But after a while, there is too much of it.
 
Q. You have been a much bigger fan of the bond market than of the stock market for at least a year. Is that still the case?
 
A. Yes, it is. The best-kept secret in the world is how well the 30-year Treasury bond has done this year. It has returned about 18 percent so far, in line with the Standard & Poor's index and much better than the average stock, which is down. I think by year-end it will beat the S.& P. That's unheard of, for a bond to beat the stock market in a period of strong economic growth.
 
Q. Is 1999 a year to buy bonds?
 
A. I think bonds will outperform stocks by a country mile next year. We think rates will fall, and could fall substantially, because there is no inflation out there. A year from now, we could see yields on the 30-year bond at 4.25 percent, possibly lower. I am not holding back.
 
Q. Is there more money to be made abroad than at home next year?
 
A. Today, nobody dares look outside the United States. But the theme for 1999 is that money will gravitate toward economies and markets that are running current account surpluses and are not heavily dependent on inflows of foreign capital.
That may point you to Asia, where countries like Korea and Thailand are already generating current account surpluses. Others will start doing the same soon. Asia could be the big story in 1999.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
The Military-Technological Complex Is Thriving in Israel

BYLINE: By JESSICA STEINBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
YOUNG soldiers with automatic rifles slung across their backs are a familiar sight here, defending the country's borders, boundaries and bus stops. With few exceptions, mainly for medical or religious reasons, conscription at age 18 is universal, and almost all Israelis serve a term in the Israel Defense Forces.
But the draft hasn't only provided manpower for national security. It has also given birth to thriving civilian industries built by entrepreneurs who gained invaluable technical skills, leadership abilities and personal connections in the military. 
 Several hundred new companies spring up every year in Silicon Wadi, as the Israeli technology sector is sometimes called. Analysts estimate that three-quarters of them grow directly out of army service.
Technology is arguably Israel's most important industrial sector, accounting for a third of the country's exports and absorbing half the foreign investment in the country. Electronics exports totaled $5.7 billion in 1997 and are growing at 17 percent a year; software exports, at $500 million in 1997, are growing at 25 percent a year. As a proportion of its population, Israel has half again as many scientists and engineers as the United States. Put them together with the country's burgeoning venture capital industry, and the result is an abundant crop of start-ups.
One example is GEO Interactive Media Group, which makes multimedia transmission software used by Web-site designers. Tzur Daboosh, 32, and Sharon Carmel, 28, two of the founding partners, met in the army in the late 1980's when both were working on multimedia combat simulators. "We gained experience in technologies that went to market five or six years later," Mr. Daboosh said.
In 1994, after several other business ventures, the men teamed up with another former army technical specialist, Eli Reifman, and began turning out software in a Tel Aviv apartment. They brought in a more experienced businessman, Naftali Shani, 49, to serve as chairman, and took the company public in 1996. Still a development-stage company, GEO lost $9.9 million in 1997 on just $3.1 million in sales. Its London-traded stock, which peaked above $3 last summer, plummeted in late July when the company warned that profits were being hampered by production delays; it closed on Friday at 26.6 cents a share.
Though its products have little direct military application, GEO continues to benefit from its army links, and vice versa. Mr. Carmel and Mr. Daboosh serve as reserve officers in technical units, teaching young draftees software design and programming. And while they teach, the two executives can scout the class for future hires.
 MOST able-bodied 18-year-old Israelis are drafted after completing high school. Women serve a minimum of one year, nine months; men spend a minimum of three years on active duty and remain in the reserves until age 45, taking time out from civilian life to serve 24 to 30 days a year.
Ambitious draftees compete furiously to gain assignment to the military units where their experience will be worth most in later life: army technology units, paratroop units and the air force. "If you get in there, it's like getting a bachelor's degree in computer science plus five years of work experience," said one programmer who served in an electronics unit and now works at an Internet telecommunications start-up.
In Israel, an impressive army profile on a resume carries weight similar to that of an Ivy League degree in the United States. Informal networks of veterans of special units open doors the way alumni networks do for graduates of American colleges.
That is how Joseph Ackerman got into the technology business. After completing army service as a flight test engineer in 1975, Mr. Ackerman was farming near Haifa when some army buddies persuaded him to join Elbit Computer, now Elbit Ltd., to oversee one of its new projects. He is now chief executive of Elbit's military electronics business, which was spun off as a separate company, Elbit Systems, in 1996.
Elbit Systems, which had $397 million in sales in the most recent four quarters and is growing at about 10 percent a year, makes a helmet-mounted display system that helps tank gunners and combat pilots aim radar and missiles. The engineers who developed the technology get to see it in action firsthand during their annual reserve call-ups, Mr. Ackerman said.
While the Government restricts exports of some kinds of military technology, it generally supports such trade. Domestic demand, after all, is not large enough to support fully an industry it wants to see thrive.
"The Ministry of Defense has a finger in this success, so it can't be unhappy with it," said Aharon Beth-Halachmi, head of Federman Enterprises, a management and investment firm. Mr. Beth-Halachmi, an electrical engineer by training, capped a 30-year army career as the ministry's chief administrator.
MILITARY technology was the first, and for many years the only sector of Israeli industry with the technical sophistication to develop globally competitive software and systems, said Mr. Beth-Halachmi, whom the army sent to graduate school in the United States in 1962.
Military experience also gives Israelis an eye for shortcuts and a penchant for aggressive innovation, said Shaul Shai, 36, a reserve major and executive vice president for marketing at Aladdin Knowledge Systems, a security software maker based in Tel Aviv.
"In the I.D.F., there's a great imbalance between the size of tasks that must be accomplished and the available resources," he said. "It's such a huge gap that one needs to think smart all the time."
But military service is no panacea, and starting a company is not the same as leading a fighter squadron, observed Shlomo Kalish, founder and chief executive of Jerusalem Global, a technology investment bank. Mr. Kalish spent five years flying combat jets in the 1970's.
"To be a great C.E.O.," he said, "you have to be a natural leader, and that can't be taught."
Army veterans can be autocratic and somewhat inflexible, especially when it comes to the culture of titles, said Eran Goren, a reserve officer and the chief executive of Nessuah-Zannex, an investment bank.
But while rank matters in the army, so does personal initiative, said Mr. Shai, of Aladdin. And that, too, can cause problems, he said, "when everyone thinks they're a general."
Still, the army's approach seems to breed success in civilian life.
"We learned how to live with constraints, and that's an added value," said GEO's Mr. Carmel.
Mr. Daboosh agreed: "We learned flexibility in the army. The I.D.F. is huge, but it listens to young soldiers. Things were always changing, which is good and bad, but very Israeli."
