HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Two forecasters see record spending for ads in 1999, barring any unforeseen circumstances.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE light at the end of the tunnel may not be an approaching freight train after all, two respected forecasters of advertising spending predicted yesterday in offering optimistic outlooks for 1999 despite the recent concern about worldwide economic turmoil.
Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson U.S.A. in New York, and John Perriss, chairman and chief executive at Zenith Media Worldwide in London, presented their upbeat assessments at the opening session of the 26th annual Paine Webber Media Conference. The conference, at the McGraw-Hill Building in midtown Manhattan, continues through Friday. 
 The peaks and valleys of advertising expenditures by marketers in the media are carefully followed because they are considered an important gauge of the strength of the economy. The global financial difficulties since the summer -- particularly in Asia, Latin America and Russia -- had thrown into doubt earlier forecasts made by Mr. Coen and Mr. Perriss about the robustness of ad spending next year.
But in their presentations, Mr. Coen and Mr. Perriss agreed that barring any drastic worsening of the world economies -- particularly disruptions in the United States or Europe -- ad spending ought to reach record levels in 1999. And Mr. Perriss predicted accelerating rates of growth through 2001.
"We think 1999 will be a pretty good year for advertising," Mr. Coen said. "Not as good as 1998, but still a good year."
Even though the percentage gain for 1999 will be the lowest in six years, he added, "the overall trend certainly looks better than any of us thought possible" during the steep stock market slump in late summer.
The primary reason for the improved outlook, said Mr. Coen, who has been tracking advertising and media trends since 1948, is that American consumers "will be in a position to feel fairly secure and spend" as a result of low inflation rates and low unemployment. Ad spending closely tracks consumer spending and as American ad spending goes, so usually goes worldwide ad spending.
Mr. Perriss, who sometimes differs with Mr. Coen in his forecasts, echoed him.
Though "there are some cautionary clouds on the horizon," Mr. Perriss said, "broadly, I'm not going to say anything to contradict Bob's pretty great outlook."
"In September, we were looking for pretty grim times in 1999 and 2000," he added. "Thankfully, I am able to stand here today and say that's not our view."
"We think the very worst has now passed in Asia," Mr. Perriss said. "Nineteen ninety-eight was our 'soft landing' and in 1999 we will go forward virtually everywhere."
Mr. Coen predicted that marketers would spend a record $212 billion in the United States next year, an increase of 5.5 percent from the $200.8 billion that he now forecasts for 1998. The 1998 figure represents a 7.1 percent gain from the $187.5 billion spent in 1997.
The 5.5 percent increase for 1999 would be the smallest in percentage terms since a 5.2 percent increase in 1993. Still, advertising as a percentage of gross domestic product in 1999 would reach 2.40 percent. That would set a record, beating the figure of 2.36 percent for 1998. Before this year, the record had been 2.35 percent in 1987 and 1988.
Mr. Coen's figure of $200.8 billion for 1998 marked the third time he had raised his forecast for the year since an original prediction in June 1997 of $196.5 billion. That was increased to $198.4 billion in December 1997 and to $200.3 billion in June. Mr. Coen adjusts his figures every time he makes a semiannual forecast, based on updated data.
Among the national media that Mr. Coen predicted would do particularly well in 1999 are cable television, radio, syndicated television and newspapers. Among the local media, he cited radio and television, fueled by growth in retail advertising from store openings.
Overseas in 1999, Mr. Coen forecasts ad spending of $223.9 billion, up 3.5 percent from a revised figure of $216.3 billion for 1998. The figure for this year marked the third time that Mr. Coen revised downward his total for international ad spending.
The figure of $223.9 billion is lower than a prediction of $228.2 billion made by Mr. Coen in June. That reflects continued ad-spending weakness in countries such as Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia and South Korea, which he said would offset strength in, say, Hungary and Poland.
Mr. Coen's worldwide total for 1999, then, is $435.9 billion, which would represent an increase of 4.5 percent from a revised worldwide total of $417.1 billion in 1998 -- the first time world ad spending has exceeded $400 billion. The 1998 figure marks an increase of 4.9 percent from the $397.5 billion spent in 1997.
Mr. Perriss, who uses a different methodology than Mr. Coen, tracking only major media, said that the Asian economic tumult had caused him to shave about $3 billion off his prediction for 1998 worldwide ad spending, which now totals $300.3 billion, and about $7 billion from his forecast for 1999, which now totals $312.9 billion. Last December, he predicted that the 1998 total would be $317.8 billion and the 1999 total would be $336.8 billion.
Still, he added, his revised forecasts are "pretty optimistic against where we thought things would be" at the deepest point of the summer gloom when "great horrors" were foreseen.
To illustrate that, when Mr. Perriss mentioned Russia, he said, smiling, "That's a word I've hardly heard mentioned in the last six months."
Yet "all forecasts are highly dependent on the United States continuing to grow," Mr. Perriss said. "A hiccup here, a loss of consumer confidence here, and it will change around these forecasts."
The worldwide total of $300.3 billion for 1998 from Mr. Perriss is up only 1.9 percent from the 1997 total of $289.1 billion, which he said was the smallest gain since the recession of the early 1990's. But the gains are then to increase from year to year in constant prices, he added, to 2.2 percent in 1999, 2.5 percent in 2000 ($329.5 billion) and 2.7 percent in 2001 ($348.7 billion).
Among reasons listed by Mr. Perriss for those gains were accelerating economic growth in Continental European nations like Germany and Italy and recoveries in some economically battered Asian markets. There will be a stronger second half in 1999 than a first half, he said, as Asia gradually recovers from the problems of 1998.
McCann-Erickson is part of McCann-Erickson World Group, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Zenith is a joint venture of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.

HEADLINE: U.S. Home Values Rose in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
United States home values rose in the third quarter as low mortgage rates and a growing economy helped home buying and refinancing, a survey by Freddie Mac showed.
The conventional mortgage home price index, which measures both sales prices of existing homes and the appraised values of homes being refinanced, rose at a 4.9 percent annual rate in the three months from July through September. That compares with a rise of 4.2 percent in the second quarter and a 4.9 percent increase in the first three months of the year. 
 "Historically low interest rates and strong labor markets continue to support a healthy housing market," said Amy Crews Cutts, an economist at Freddie Mac, the No. 2 buyer of United States home loans.
Home prices showed the largest regional increase in New England, where they posted an annualized gain of 8.2 percent in the third quarter. Pacific Coast states registered the second-largest third-quarter rise, increasing at a 7.2 percent pace.
The benchmark United States mortgage rate fell last week for a third straight week to the lowest level since early October. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped to 6.71 percent from the previous week's 6.78 percent.
Sales of new United States homes rose eight-tenths of a percent in October to an annual rate of 851,000 units, the Commerce Department said.

HEADLINE: Rise Is Reported in Announced Job Cuts

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The number of planned job cuts by United States businesses rose in November from a year earlier, putting the annual total on track for the largest number of planned cuts in five years, a survey showed today.
Announced job cuts rose 9.3 percent last month to 51,642 from 47,241 in November 1997, according to the monthly survey by the employment firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. 
 "We could see more pre-Christmas job cutting over the next 15 days, as companies finalize 1999 budgets," John Challenger, the company's chief executive, said.
Among the industries showing the largest rises in planned cuts this year are electronics, industrial goods and computers, the survey showed. So far in 1998, United States businesses have announced plans to cut 574,629 jobs, the firm said, about 40,000 behind 1993's total of 615,189.
But November's total planned dismissals was 43.6 percent below October's 91,531 -- a 33-month high.
Multinational corporations are doing most of the cutting, while hiring by small and midsized companies helped lower the November unemployment rate to 4.4 percent -- just shy of a 28-year low -- from 4.6 percent in October.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Climbed in October

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
American consumers increased their borrowing in October at the fastest pace in more than two years, providing a solid spending base for holiday sales.
Credit outstanding grew at a 9 percent annual rate, to a seasonally adjusted $1.29 trillion, the Federal Reserve said today. That was up from rates of 4.9 percent in September and 3.9 percent in August. There has not been a faster increase since July 1996. 
 Economists said the gain was significant, coming during a month when Wall Street was in turmoil and the Federal Reserve was cutting interest rates to restore confidence in the economy.
The borrowing helps to explain why the personal savings rate was negative for a second consecutive month -- the first such occurrence on record. The personal savings rate is savings as a percentage of after-tax income. Another factor is that in addition to borrowing more, consumers are spending part of their stock-market gains.
Growth in consumer credit in October was led by a catchall category that includes loans for education, vacations, mobile homes and boats. It shot up at a rate of 19 percent, the most in three months.
Revolving credit, primarily credit cards, advanced at a rate of 8 percent, the fastest in four months.
Auto lending increased at a moderate rate of 3.5 percent after three months of strong gains.
The report does not include home-equity loans.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A Cautionary Note on Mergers: Bigger Does Not Mean Better

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
A year ago, the stock of U.S. Office Products was a star. The company had just reported surging sales and earnings for the quarter. The shares had more than quadrupled since going public two and a half years ago.
It was a magnificent performance from a company selling the mundane: paper clips, note pads and swivel chairs. U.S. Office Products had wanted to be the leader in its field, and so it had followed the lead of much bigger companies in industries as varied as retailing, banks or health care. It bought the competition. To acclaim from investors, U.S. Office Products acquired hundreds of mom-and-pop office supply stores, and in one year, its sales rocketed to $2.8 billion from $702 million. 
 But bigness has lost its luster at U.S. Office Products. Sales growth has slowed, and the company just announced a quarterly loss of 11 cents a share. Its stock has tumbled to nearly half its offering price.
In a month already dominated by mergers of already giant banking and oil companies, not to mention the America Online-Netscape Communications liaison, the story of U.S. Office Products is a small but cautionary one. For even as the executives of Exxon and Mobil and Deutsche Bank and Bankers Trust contend that their marriages will create a best of breed, the history of mergers is often not pretty for shareholders.
Although the stocks of some acquirers may rise on the news of a combination, a variety of studies show that over the longer term -- one year or more -- most mergers result in stocks that lag behind those of other companies in their industry. And many mergers result in actual losses for their shareholders.
Furthermore, the odds of shares underperforming in current mergers are almost certain to increase going forward, given today's sky-high stock prices. When the price of premiums to the acquired company's shareholders and the costs of integrating two companies are added, such lofty prices make it almost impossible for these deals to perform.
"In some individual mergers, it could be that size is helpful in meeting world market demand," said Richard Sylla, professor of economics and financial history at New York University's Stern School of Business. "But a lot of history shows us that bigger isn't necessarily better."
The merger wave is particularly risky to shareholders because many deals are not only about what they can deliver to the customers or the shareholders but also about what they provide, directly and indirectly, to top management.
That's because the deals often help executives keep their companies' stock prices high -- at least early on -- by increasing revenues, essentially making the companies grow faster than they could ever have done internally, some analysts and academics contend. And among more aggressive managements, acquisitions allow them to perform accounting that helps make their financial statements appear sounder than they actually are.
That does not mean, of course, that a number of mergers are not driven by necessity. In a world awash with $10-a-barrel oil, for example, combining Exxon and Mobil to cut costs is seen as perhaps the only way an integrated oil company can thrive.
Outside the oil patch, many of today's corporate combinations are necessitated by too much competition. Too many goods produced by nations around the world that are embracing capitalism for the first time means that more and more American companies are finding it hard to increase their sales or profit margins. The solution has been to get bigger, even if it means joining forces with a company that used to be a competitor.
To the degree that mergers reduce excess capacity, they do provide a benefit. But since these combinations also usually involve huge layoffs, these benefits do not come cheaply.
These forces have made 1998 a banner year for mergers. So far this year, 23,926 deals have been announced or completed worldwide for a total value of $2.31 trillion, breaking last year's previous record of $1.6 trillion worth of deals. In 1994, there were 19,166 deals with a value of $560.3 billion, according to the Securities Data Company.
Much of this growing appetite has been whetted by the stock market. Chief executives' obsessions with ever-rising stock prices, and the rewards those stock prices deliver, play an ever larger role in merger mania today, some academics say.
Indeed, today's high-priced stocks make mergers easier than ever. For chief executives faced with slowing internal sales growth, an easy solution is to jump-start revenues by buying another company.
And so, 70 percent of the value of mergers and acquisitions today is made with stock, according to Mark L. Sirower, a professor at New York University's Stern School of Business. Ten years ago, 90 percent were all-cash deals.
Proof that higher stock prices drive merger activity can also be seen in the value of deals done during September, when the stock market was falling. Then, a mere $51 billion in deals was done, down from about $200 billion a month in the spring.
As merger decisions become driven in part by higher stock prices, it is almost certain that more combinations will fail. For shareholders, that is bad news, given that most mergers of the recent past are already producing dismal returns.
In a study of 100 large deals completed between 1994 and 1997, Mr. Sirower found that two-thirds resulted in immediate and outright losses to shareholders and wound up underperforming their industry peers over the long haul.
The trend is almost identical to one found in a similar study Mr. Sirower did in the 1980's. Even during a bull market, mergers can undermine stock values. A recent study by Mitchell Madison, a consulting firm, found that between 1995 and 1998, a period of great gains for the market over all, stocks of merged banks underperformed their peers 82 percent of the time.
Such rates of failure are likely to increase in the future. Why? Expensive stocks make it even more difficult for executives running the huge combinations to succeed in their marriages.
"Today, acquisitions require more discipline than ever before because of the overall market value of the firms," Mr. Sirower said. "We're looking at companies now that are so highly valued on their own that they already have to run very hard just to stay in place."
Indeed, with price-earnings ratios on many big-capitalization stocks at dizzying heights, investors are clearly expecting great improvements from these companies in the future. Add a takeover premium to these prices and you get expectations that even the most brilliant manager could not hope to meet.
History also gives ominous news to shareholders in today's megamergers. In the past, the larger the target was, the lower the return to the buyer generally was.
"If you overpay for a company that is equal to 1 percent of your overall revenues, whether you overpaid is not going to have a big impact on shareholders," said Eli Ofek, professor of finance at N.Y.U.'s Stern School. "But if you overpay in an Exxon-Mobil case, it will have a huge impact."
Indeed, most acquisitions fail, academics say, because the post-merger business cannot support the price paid to forge the combination.
Consider two cases from 1994. One was Novell's $1.4 billion purchase of a rival software producer, Wordperfect. Less than two years later, Novell sold the company for $200 million to another software maker. Also in 1994, Quaker Oats bought Snapple, a beverage manufacturer, for $1.7 billion. Three years later, Quaker sold its acquisition for $300 million.
One reason that stocks of the acquirer may underperform is that investors realize sheer size by no means translates into higher profits. Take the drug industry, one that America dominates. Three of the biggest drug sellers -- Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Johnson & Johnson -- have generated earnings below the 16 percent average growth for the group. The two hottest players at the moment are smaller: Schering-Plough, with earnings growth of 22 percent so far this year, and Warner-Lambert, with 41 percent growth.
Bigness also has a habit of thwarting innovation. Consider the great innovation that has transformed the telecommunications industry since the breakup of AT&T in 1982.
Despite the potential burdens of pricey acquisitions, they do, at first, provide another way for executives to keep their stock prices high -- through aggressive accounting tactics that make their financial statements appear to be stronger than they actually are.
"Mergers give companies an opportunity to take very sizable write-offs, creating a camouflage to clean up a lot of things on the balance sheet," said Howard Schilit, president of the Center for Financial Research and Analysis in Rockville, Md. "Does that drive the acquisition? Probably not, but it doesn't hurt."
Taking sizable write-offs today can make earnings look rosier tomorrow. And some companies use huge restructuring charges that typically accompany mergers as a place to dump regular business expenses, increasing earnings in the process. Since earnings drive stock prices, big write-offs and expense reduction tricks can be mighty valuable in the short term.
Companies sometimes use acquisitions to pick up a new source of revenue. For instance, FPA Medical Management Inc., once the country's third-largest physician management company, agreed in July 1996 to buy some operations of Foundation Health Systems for $220 million. As part of the deal, Foundation Health agreed to pay FPA $26 million a year in so-called guaranteed access payments.
"Rather than adjusting the purchase price, FPA picks it up as a source of revenue," Mr. Schilit said. "Those are the kind of interesting tricks that can happen when companies bundle things with an acquisition. Mergers make it easier for companies to create these smoke screens. As a result, it's more difficult for investors to see write-offs or one-time infusions to revenue."
The tactic used by FPA Medical helped the company for only so long. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July.
Acquisition of another company's revenues can bolster a stock another way, at least temporarily. The bigger a company's market value is -- the stock price multiplied by the number of shares outstanding -- the more likely that it will attract institutional investors. The huge and growing pools of capital -- pension funds, mutual funds and hedge funds -- need places they can go to generate returns.
If a company has billions of dollars in market value, it means getting in and out of the investment is relatively easy for large investors. And ease of entry and exit is increasingly crucial to these investors.
So the flood of money in gives the stock a boost. But big institutional investors can be fickle and such money can flee the merged company when earnings growth appears to slow.
For the executives in a company being acquired, a merger can mean enormous, instant wealth. For example, Lucio A. Noto, the chairman of Mobil, stands to collect at least $6 million just by leaving if a sale to Exxon goes through and the board approves his "golden parachute" pay package. A company spokesman has said that Mr. Noto's deal to sell Mobil to Exxon was "in the best interests of the company."
But chief executives of the merged companies can also reap a rich reward from an acquisition because their compensation is typically tied to earnings or revenue growth or the performance of the stock.
And a study of 152 companies in 1995, James K. Seward, now a professor at Dartmouth, and James P. Walsh, a professor at the University of Michigan, found that a company was much more likely to be acquired if the chief executive of the concern held a big stock option package.
Graef Crystal, an executive compensation expert, notes that the chiefs of companies being acquired get a nice premium on the shares they hold, plus all their stock options and restricted shares automatically vest and become free to trade. Frosting on the cake: a bonus is typically given that may be the highest ever.
"In the old days, you had hostile takeovers with C.E.O.'s fighting them," Mr. Crystal said. "Now C.E.O.'s are walking around in front of their buildings with sandwich boards that read 'Company for sale, Inquire within.' "

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: By Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: FINANCIAL WOES PERSIST
The arrival of a World Bank team for more talks about loans did little to assuage fears that Russia will be left without foreign aid and may begin printing large sums of money to pay off a total foreign currency debt of $158.8 billion by January. (AP)
 
BRITAIN: TORY BACKS DOWN ON KEY PLAN
William Hague, the leader of Britain's Conservatives, has abandoned plans to press for a new regional Parliament to represent England. The proposal, a centerpiece of his program at the annual party convention two months ago, was aimed at being a counterweight to the new Parliaments that the Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair has created in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
GERMANY: CALL FOR EAST GERMAN AMNESTY
Leaders of the Party of Democratic Socialism, successor to the Communists who governed the former East Germany, have called for an amnesty on crimes committed under Communist rule. The party's leader, Lothar Bisby, questioned whether people carrying out the law of East Germany, from border guards upward, should be liable to prosecution. Nearly 1,000 people were killed trying to flee to the West. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: KHATAMI SPEAKS OUT ON REFORMS
President Mohammad Khatami, who was elected last year on promises of ushering in political reforms, accused conservative and traditionalist forces of blocking reforms in Iran. "We are facing the three currents of counter-revolution, traditionalists hostile to progressive religion and revisionists," he told an assembly hall packed with 10,000 student supporters at Sharif University, Teheran. (Agence France-Presse)
 
EGYPT: MOVE ON MINI-MOSQUES
The Ministry of Religious Endowments said it began putting into action a plan to control 6,000 "zawya," or mini-mosques, in an attempt to put an end to Muslim fundamentalism. The ministry will appoint prayer leaders to the mosques, a spokesman said. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
INDIA: STANDING FIRM ON KASHMIR
On his first visit to Kashmir since becoming Prime Minister of India in March, Atal Behari Vajpayee said India would never relinquish any of it to Pakistan. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
CHINA: ACID RAIN DAMAGE GROWS
China's rapid economic growth and reliance on coal have spread acid rain damage to 40 percent of the country, The China Daily reported. According to a new report by Chinese scientists, China emitted 23.5 million tons of sulfur dioxide last year, up 30 percent from 1993, and coal use doubled to comprise 75 percent of total energy consumption. (AP)
 
NORTH KOREA: TALKS WITH U.S. CONTINUE
The United States and North Korea resumed talks in Washington on an American demand for access to an underground building site that could be connected with a revived nuclear program in North Korea. The negotiators met in New York on Friday and Saturday, with their agenda restricted to Washington's insistence that North Korea allow inspections of the site at the village of Kumchang-ri. (Reuters)
 
JAPAN: ECONOMY IN 'SEVERE STATE'
The head of the Bank of Japan said Japan's economy remains in "an extremely severe state." The central bank governor, Masaru Hayami, told Parliament that corporate earnings had slipped and industrial production had fallen. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: ELECTION PLAN CHALLENGED
The opposition National Party said it would ask the High Court to rule on the constitutionality of requiring citizens to have new "bar-coded" identity documents before they can register to vote in national elections next year. The ruling African National Congress is insisting on the documents, but that could result in fewer white voters getting to the polls because many have not applied for the new documents. Suzanne Daley (NYT)
 
UGANDA: PRESIDENT'S BROTHER QUITS
The brother of Uganda's President resigned as the nation's security adviser after admitting his involvement in a secret deal to buy a 49 percent interest in the Uganda Commercial Bank. Maj. Gen. Salim Saleh, a military adviser to his brother, President Yoweri Museveni, has been criticized for corruption and the military's support of the rebellion in Congo. Ian Fisher (NYT)
 
ANGOLA: REBELS TELL OF ATTACKS
The rebel movement Unita said Government forces bombed its strongholds in the towns of Andulo and Bailundo in breach of a four-year peace treaty. Paulo Lukamba Gato, Unita's secretary general, told a Portuguese radio station that the attacks could signal a return to all-out fighting in Angola. (Reuters)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
ST. VINCENT AND THE GRENADINES: MARIJUANA WAR
Caribbean troops backed by six United States Marine Corps helicopters are beginning a two-week campaign to eradicate an estimated 12,000 acres of marijuana on St. Vincent, BBC News reported. It said the island's marijuana growers' association, warning that the destruction of the crop would drive up the island's 40 percent unemployment rate, has written to President Clinton demanding compensation.
 
UNITED STATES: GORE'S GLOBAL CONFERENCE
Vice President Gore is inviting law enforcement and other officials from more than 60 countries to what his office calls the world's first conference on fighting corruption and safeguarding integrity among justice and security officials. The conference is scheduled from Feb. 24 to 26 at the State Department. (NYT)

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Swings His Ax (Then Retreats to His Hospital Bed)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 7

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin came to his Kremlin office today just long enough to dismiss four top aides and proclaim that he is retaking control of his Government's skidding tax-collection and crime-fighting agencies.
Then he returned to a Moscow hospital, continuing a recovery from pneumonia that has stretched to 15 days and seemingly rendered him an asterisk in the Kremlin power structure -- at least until now. 
 Oleg N. Sysuyev, a senior aide who often channels Mr. Yeltsin's view of things to reporters and television viewers, told the Itar-Tass news agency later that his boss had other moves in mind, but gave no specifics.
Mr. Yeltsin's official spokesman, Dmitri Yakushkin, said the President gave his staff a blunt explanation for the shake-up. "Things are not going too well," he quoted Mr. Yeltsin as saying.
The highest-ranking aide dismissed was Valentin Yumashev, the head of presidential administration, whose job is roughly equivalent to chief of staff in the Washington White House. He was replaced by Nikolai Bordyuzha, a onetime chief of the federal border guards who most recently was secretary of Mr. Yeltsin's top advisory body, the security council.
Mr. Bordyuzha will keep his security council job, an apparent attempt to insure that the defense and security officials on the security council work in lockstep with the rest of the administration.
Mr. Yeltsin, 67, also said that the heads of the federal Justice Ministry and tax-collection agency will now report directly to him instead of to Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov. Mr. Yakushkin said the shift was coordinated with Mr. Primakov and does not signal any unhappiness on Mr. Yeltsin's part with his latest second-in-command.
Mr. Yeltsin changes underlings more often than many people change their motor oil, having announced three prime ministers and dismissed countless lesser aides since last spring. Outsiders were reluctant to attach any special importance to the latest dismissals, which were limited to Mr. Yeltsin's inner circle.
The moves nevertheless addressed a rising perception that influence over events here -- social, political and economic -- is slowly slipping from the grasp of the pro-democracy forces that Mr. Yeltsin long represented. In response, Mr. Yeltsin appears to be trying to stanch the bleeding away of his political authority.
The economy continues to work against Mr. Yeltsin. Tax revenues have been slipping since August, forcing the Government to print more rubles, which are worth less.
Officials said today that the central bank pumped 10.5 billion new rubles, or more than $525 million, into the economy last month, triple the rate in October. The ruble traded at 6.3 to the dollar four months ago but dipped below the 20-per-dollar mark today.
Once content just to mock him, the President's many critics in the Communist Party and among nationalist movements have begun testing their own strength lately, to some effect.
Members of both factions have refused to condemn attacks by one Communist in the Parliament on Russian Jews, many of them rich businessmen who have supported the current Government. Some legislators have openly endorsed the attacks, drawing a rebuke from Mr. Yeltsin but little else.
Last week the Communists stunned many Muscovites by proposing to restore to downtown Moscow a statue of Felix Dzerzhinsky, the first head of the despised Cheka secret police, which later became the K.G.B. The Cheka and its successors oversaw the arrest or execution of millions of innocent Russians during Stalin's purges in the 1930's.
The agency also created a forced-labor program that sent Russians to build huge dams and canals, mine gold and perform other state tasks, often under horrific conditions and with high mortality rates. Finally, the agencies created and ran the now-famous gulags in which political opponents and dissidents were imprisoned and forced to work.
The Dzerzhinsky statue, which stood in Lubyanka Square outside K.G.B. headquarters near Red Square, was toppled from its pedestal by celebrants after Moscow's Mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, ordered it removed in 1991. A Communist legislator proposed restoring the statue as an anti-crime symbol, saying it memorialized a man with "cold hands" and a "warm heart."
The resolution eventually passed, and while the statue's future remains uncertain, the vote is widely viewed as evidence of the Yeltsin Government's fading authority.
The country's powerful criminal bands are increasingly brazen, too. The recent assassination of a leading advocate of democracy in the Parliament, Galina Starovoitova, has underscored their efforts to muscle their way from control of business into politics.
Mr. Yeltsin reportedly held a consultation with his daughter and adviser Tatyana Dyachenko, 38, and with Mr. Yumashev before spending three hours at the Kremlin today.
Mr. Yakushkin quoted Mr. Yeltsin as saying that his aides' conduct of the battle against corruption and political extremism "undermines trust in presidential authority in general, and that is inadmissible."
"In the present conditions," Mr. Yeltsin was quoted as saying, "power should be concentrated in one hand."

HEADLINE: Amerada Hess Plans Wide Cutbacks

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Amerada Hess Corporation said yesterday that it planned to cut back sharply on capital expenditures, curtail oil exploration and production spending and reduce its work force by 20 percent in this division, resulting in a $150 million quarterly after-tax charge. The New York City-based independent oil and gas company said it would be cutting 400 jobs, or 20 percent of the total work force of about 2,000, in its United States and British exploration and production division.
Hess said the cuts, driven by the sharp decline in oil prices in the last year, would mean a 40 percent drop in planned 1999 exploration and production spending, to $250 million. 
 Hess also said the $150 million after-tax charge was in addition to a $150 million charge announced at the end of October, bringing to $300 million the total charges for the year. Accounting for the rest of the new $150 million charge, Hess said it would take a $77 million charge to reflect the value of fixed-price contracts for oil rigs, which are now worth much less; $35 million to write off a North Sea oilfield that will not now be developed, and $23 million to write off other exploration and production assets.
 Hess also said it would put up for sale oil storage terminals along the coast of the Gulf of Mexico and along the Colonial Pipeline in the Southeastern United States.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Rises 37.48 Points as Technology Shares Surge

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index set a record yesterday as stocks rose for a second consecutive session, led by software, computer and telecommunications equipment companies such as Microsoft, Compaq Computer and Lucent Technologies on expectations they will have the fastest earnings growth in the coming months.
"You're seeing a return to leadership among large technology firms," said Eric Wiegand, a money manager in Philadelphia who helps manage $50 billion for the First Union Corporation. Particularly where computers are concerned, he added, "There is good consumer demand out there, and there isn't a lot of inventory." 
 The Nasdaq climbed 37.48 points, or nearly 1.9 percent, to 2,040.64. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 54.33 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 9,070.47, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 10.96 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,187.70.
Bonds, meanwhile, gained for the eighth time in nine sessions as a rising dollar and expectations for quiescent inflation bolstered the appeal of Treasuries.
Compaq rose 3, to 41 11/16, and was the session's most active stock, with more than 30 million shares changing hands. Analysts expect Compaq's earnings to almost quadruple next year, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. A glut of personal computers pushed prices down this year and depressed Compaq's earnings, easing the way for it to post big percentage gains in profit next year.
Michael Kwatinetz, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, said that PC sales were strong during Thanksgiving week and continued to look bright for next year. He raised his 1999 earnings forecast on Compaq yesterday to $1.75 a share, from $1.70. "Worldwide PC industry demand appears healthy, with strength in Europe and in the U.S.," he said in a report to clients.
I.B.M. shares rose 2 15/16, to 167 3/16, accounting for almost a quarter of the Dow's gain.
The rally extended to all segments of the computer business. Microsoft surged 6 3/16 a share, to 133 9/16, after South Carolina dropped out of the antitrust case against the software giant. William H. Gates, the company's chairman, said yesterday that the Government was trying to destroy his company and bolster its rivals with its case.
Shares of Intel, the world's biggest computer-chip maker, rose 2 5/8, to 118 15/16.
The stock of producers of equipment that link computers into networks also surged. Cisco Systems gained 1 15/16 a share, to 80 3/16. Lucent rose 4 1/4, to 100, adding to the 8.4 percent surge on Friday. Lucent, the world's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, told some analysts and investors on Friday that demand for its products was strong and that all its major plants were running at capacity.
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing posted the biggest decline in the Dow, falling 3 3/16 a share, to 77 1/16, as the dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen. The company gets more than 50 percent of its revenue overseas, with a big chunk of that coming from Asia.
Warner-Lambert dropped 2 9/16, to 75 7/8, after Federal regulators reported that at least 33 people had died after taking the company's diabetes pill, Rezulin. The treatment is a key drug product for the company.
Oxford Health Plans rose 3 3/16, or 27 percent, to 14 7/8, as analysts said that the managed health care company's new management had been able to hold onto more members than expected while raising premiums. Oxford, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., is trying to turn itself around after problems with its billing system caused it to underestimate its medical costs, leading to more than $900 million in losses during the last five quarters.
Shares of other health maintenance organizations also rose. United Healthcare rose 1 3/16, to 47 15/16; Humana rose 1 5/16, to 20 15/16, and Aetna gained 2 1/2, to 82 1/16.
In the bond market the price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 5/32, to 103 13/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.03 percent, from 5.04 percent on Friday.
Two-year notes declined, pushing yields up two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.46 percent, amid fading hopes for a Federal Reserve rate cut this month.
 Bonds received a lift as the dollar posted its biggest gain in four weeks against the yen. A rising dollar makes Treasuries more attractive to foreign investors that will eventually convert their holdings into their home currencies.
Also helping bonds are expectations that sagging prices of oil and other commodities will keep inflation from accelerating, allowing bonds to retain more of their value.
So far this year, 30-year bonds have provided investors returns of about 19.5 percent when price gains and interest are taken into account. That compares with a year-to-date rise of 14.7 percent in the Dow industrials.

HEADLINE: Schroder Tries For Consensus In Fight to Cut Jobless Rate

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BONN, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Consensus was long the backbone of Germany's postwar economic boom, and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder set out today to prove that it could form the basis of a fight against the country's cripplingly high unemployment.
With more than four million Germans jobless, or 10.6 percent of the work force, Mr. Schroder summoned labor unions, employers and several members of his Cabinet to a first meeting of a much-vaunted "alliance for jobs." But the alliance looked tentative at best, and its initial achievement little more than a list of good intentions. 
 As global competition has increased, while wage costs remained high here, the economy -- based on both the free market and a high level of social protection -- has frayed. The rich have grown richer, but unemployment has risen to levels not seen since 1945. Mr. Schroder, who took office in October, will be judged largely on his ability to get people back to work.
His chosen method -- elaborate negotiations among unions, employers and politicians -- amounts to an attempt to demonstrate that the German model that has had great difficulty responding to the challenges of the 1990's can be revived.
With the introduction of a common European currency, the euro, now imminent, Mr. Schroder also wants to show that Europe's largest economy can generate employment while preserving a high level of social benefits and avoiding the wholesale deregulation that has helped spur rapid job creation in America.
"The excellent atmosphere at the talks makes me optimistic," Mr. Schroder said after the meeting. "This alliance is necessary to meeting the challenges of an increasingly globalized economy and will prove anything but a flash in the pan."
A statement said the parties, who will meet again next Feb. 25, had agreed to strive to lower labor costs, to reform the broad but costly social welfare system, to create more workplace flexibility, to provide better access to venture capital for small companies and possibly to lower the retirement age, now 65.
All these measures have already been talked about for several years in Germany -- former Chancellor Helmut Kohl started a similar round of meetings in 1996 that led nowhere -- and it was not immediately clear why there should be more success this time. In practice, reform of the pension, health and unemployment systems, the cost of which add more than 40 percent to wage bills, has met strong resistance from unions.
The only concrete steps agreed upon today were to move up tax reforms for small and medium-sized companies to 2000 from 2002 and to create 100,000 training positions for young people. How those positions would be found, and how they would be paid for, was not specified.
A real test of the will to compromise is likely to come in the next few weeks as employers and unions confront each other over wages. IG Metall, the union that has more than 2.7 million members in the auto and engineering industries, has called for a 6.5 percent pay increase.

HEADLINE: 2 Utility Deals Could Speed Consolidation

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Two precedent-setting merger deals were announced yesterday in the American electric power industry that could greatly accelerate the consolidation among utilities. The deals are certain to receive careful regulatory scrutiny.
The proposed takeover of Pacificorp, a major utility in the Northwest, by Scottish Power P.L.C., one of the largest utilities in Britain, would mark the first purchase of a major United States utility by a foreign company. Scottish Power has slashed thousands of jobs at its own operations and analysts expect it to make cuts at Pacificorp. 
 The proposed merger of BEC Energy, the parent of Boston Edison, which serves the Boston area, and Commonwealth Energy System, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., would be the first between adjacent utilities that only transmit and distribute power.
How the combinations would affect consumers is unclear. Some analysts, economists and leaders of consumers groups said yesterday, however, that the combinations could lead to strong new competitors that would become more efficient and eventually be able to pass more savings on to consumers and higher returns to shareholders.
Scottish Power said yesterday that it was acquiring Pacificorp in a stock swap worth $7.9 billion based on Scottish Power's closing price Friday, when its shares cost 675 pence in London. The company said it would pay 2.32 Scottish Power shares for each Pacificorp share, worth about $20.75 at Friday's closing price. Scottish Power's shares fell 66 pence yesterday, to 609 pence, and Pacificorp shares ended down 18.75 cents at $20.5625.
Under the proposed merger of BEC Energy and Commonwealth Energy System, the companies will form a new holding company in a transaction valued at $950 million.
BEC shareholders can choose to get one share of Commonwealth Energy stock, or $44.10 in cash, for each share that they own. Commonwealth shareholders can choose between $44.10 in cash or 1.05 shares of the new company for each share they now own.
BEC stock closed yesterday at $41, down $1, and shares of Commonwealth Energy closed at $39.875, up $2.0625.
Robert Rubin, an analyst with Bear, Stearns, said the Scottish Power acquisition of Pacificorp would face "an arduous regulatory process." If it goes through, he said, other large European utilities such as Powergen P.L.C. of Britain and Tractebel of Belgium would likely pursue acquisitions here.
"The difficult part is that it would be precedent setting," said Robert K. Johnson, the executive director of the Electric Consumers Alliance, an umbrella group representing 260 consumer groups around the country. "Who owns essential infrastructure in the United States is an acute issue."
Both transactions will lead to reductions in duplicate staff and offices.
Ian Robinson , the chief executive of Scottish Power, which has cut its staff in the last four years to 5,000, from 10,000, said that reductions in the staff of Pacificorp, based in Portland, Ore., would be a key component of improving efficiency.
Pacificorp, with 1.4 million customers in Oregon, Utah, Wyoming, Washington, Idaho and California, has one of the largest transmission systems in the nation and owns coal-fired and geothermal plants that can produce 8,300 megawatts of power. It is one of the biggest sellers of wholesale power in the nation. Earnings have been reduced recently because of losses in trading in the wholesale market, where prices have been very volatile.
Scottish Power was advised by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Pacificorp was advised by Salomon Smith Barney International.
Under a deregulation plan carried out by Massachusetts, BEC Energy and Commonwealth Energy have had to sell their generating plants and become companies that only transmit power and service their customers.
Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, said that while the merger would lead to further cost savings and a more efficient system, the benefit to customers would depend on how regulators oversaw the utilities.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Scottish Power announced its bid to acquire Pacificorp yesterday in London with Richard T. O'Brien, second from left, of Pacificorp, and Ian Russell, Murray Stuart and Ian Robinson, all of Scottish Power. (Associated Press)(pg. C8)

HEADLINE: Castro Criticizes an Old Friend, Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Fidel Castro has long kept a special place in his heart for Mexico.
In the 1960's, Mexico stood alone among Latin American countries, defying Washington's entreaties to break relations with Communist Cuba. 
 In the first two decades of Mr. Castro's revolution, Mexico was the only major Latin country whose guerrillas he refused to train. Mr. Castro even held his tongue in recent years, as Mexico has mostly abandoned its "anti-Yankee" foreign policy in favor of closer economic integration with the United States.
But last week Mr. Castro suddenly abandoned his discretion.
Addressing an economic conference in Havana, he derided contemporary Mexican policies, criticizing the North American Free Trade Agreement, accusing the Mexican Government of turning its back on the third world and of letting American culture overwhelm Mexican traditions.
"When they ask Mexican children," Mr. Castro said, " 'Who is the father of your country?' it's possible that many don't know."
"But they sure know Mickey Mouse," he added, to the nervous titters of diplomats and economists.
Foreign Minister Rosario Green, who recently made a cordial visit to Havana, called in the Cuban Ambassador, Curbelo Padron, to express "deep puzzlement" over the outburst and called the Mexican envoy in Cuba back here for consultations.
A Congressman from President Ernesto Zedillo's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, Francisco Javier Santillan Oceguera, called Mr. Castro's remarks an intervention in Mexico's internal affairs.
The president of the Foreign Affairs Committee in Congress, Julio Faesler, urged Mr. Castro to "keep in mind that we Mexicans feel sorry about the lack of success he's had with his own economic development."
Some analysts suggested that Mr. Castro had aimed his remarks at former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who engineered the Nafta accord. But there was little evidence of that, because Mr. Salinas visited Havana recently and seems to enjoy excellent relations with Mr. Castro.
Other experts suggested that Mr. Castro, sensing the PRI's potential defeat in presidential elections in 2000, was currying favor with opposition parties.
Edelmiro Castellanos, a Cuban journalist here, saw a wider motive, that Mr. Castro was seeking to rebuild bridges to leftists all over Latin America, many of whom have grown disenchanted with him. "His image with the left is in tatters," Mr. Castellanos said.
A Brazilian Socialist, Luiz Inacio da Silva, whose movement has included some of Mr. Castro's most enthusiastic supporters, criticized Mr. Castro this fall because the Cuban has forged cozy relations with the Brazilian Government, which Mr. da Silva views as conservative.
Mr. Castro's backing among prominent Mexican intellectuals has cooled in recent years. A political scientist, Sergio Aguayo, traced leftists' irritation from 1988, when Mr. Castro was one of the few world leaders who supported PRI claims that Mr. Salinas had legitimately won presidential elections.
When Mr. Castro attended Mr. Salinas's inauguration, Mr. Aguayo and other intellectuals were invited to meet him at dinner. Mr. Castro launched into a long monologue about the time that he spent in Mexico in 1956, preparing his insurgency.
"It was an offensive situation," Mr. Aguayo said.

HEADLINE: Social Security Nudges Onstage

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Even as his legal team heads to Capitol Hill to present his defense against impeachment, President Clinton will open a two-day conference on Tuesday morning with an appeal for bipartisanship in shoring up Social Security, a goal that would be a stretch in the most tranquil of political climates.
That this of all weeks is the one bringing together Republicans and Democrats to deal with so highly charged an issue is just one of the complications facing the effort to strengthen Social Security, which will otherwise run short of money as the baby-boom generation retires in coming decades. 
 Democrats are fighting with Democrats over whether they would be repudiating their most deeply held values if they supported a revamped system under which individuals would save and invest for their own retirement. Mr. Clinton, who is hinting that he might support individual-account plans, has to keep an eye both on his own political survival and on how the outcome of the Social Security debate could affect Vice President Al Gore's ambitions for the Presidency.
Then there is the deeply ingrained and well-justified fear among Republicans, nearly all of whom favor individual accounts, that Democrats will find a way to bludgeon them with the issue, as they have so often in the past.
The Administration was advised over the past year by Speaker Newt Gingrich not to make a specific proposal, saying that to do so would draw so much partisan fire that the effort to find a compromise would founder. But with Mr. Gingrich stepping down, Republican leaders are ratcheting up the pressure on Mr. Clinton to put forward his own detailed plan, saying it is up to him to lead on an issue that will almost certainly require politically painful benefit cuts and tax increases.
"He's going to have to show some courage," the Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said in an appearance on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" on Sunday.
Mr. Clinton has managed to reach compromises with the Republican-controlled Congress on big ideological issues like balancing the budget. In this case, though, his own party could be a problem. Some prominent Democrats are bucking the party's orthodoxy to argue that individual accounts would allow even low-income workers the opportunity to build wealth in the financial markets.
"There is no more Democratic idea than building a generation of wealthy Americans who participate in our economy rather than feeling isolated from it," Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, one of the Democrats supporting private accounts, said in a speech last week.
Mr. Kerrey warned, though, that those who advocated changing the current system would draw considerable fire from the left. Two days later the Rev. Jesse Jackson, one of many liberal leaders who have banded together to oppose individual accounts, suggested that he would mobilize against fellow Democrats as quickly as he would take on Republicans over the issue.
Some Democrats "argue that we must dare to privatize Social Security, that it takes courage to choose moneyed interests over the common good," Mr. Jackson said, maintaining that the real winner in privatization would be Wall Street. "There are adjectives for that choice, but courage is not one of them."
For Mr. Clinton, Social Security is probably a last chance to leave a lasting legacy on domestic policy. Yet Democrats think they can recapture the House in 2000, and some liberals would like to keep Social Security alive as an issue to use against the Republicans. Many of the groups that helped Mr. Clinton and the Democrats in the Congressional elections this year, including organized labor and liberal black groups, are dead set against private accounts.
Should Mr. Clinton endorse private accounts -- and Republicans say he must if he hopes to get legislation through Congress -- then he might give Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, an ideal opportunity to rally support from the left with which to challenge Mr. Gore for the Presidential nomination.
Republicans have their own reasons for wanting to get a deal done. They would like to neutralize the issue before the 2000 election, and to move on to their tax-cutting agenda, which Mr. Clinton has thwarted for the last year by declaring a need to preserve projected Federal budget surpluses until Social Security's problems are addressed.
But Republicans have yet to agree among themselves on the best way to finance individual accounts. Some of them argue that painful steps can be avoided through use of the budget surplus, but others say tax increases and benefit cuts will be necessary to keep the system solvent in the long run.
Both sides understand the limits of bipartisanship.
"I want to see this happen," Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, told a news conference today, repeating his desire to work closely with Mr. Clinton as both of their careers in elected office draw to a close. "This is my last two years in Congress; it is his last two years as President. I would like both of us to be able to leave Washington having saved Social Security."
A reporter quickly asked Mr. Archer if that meant Mr. Clinton should not be impeached until Social Security is saved.
"That," Mr. Archer said, "is another issue."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton yesterday at a White House event where he announced legislative proposals to fight Medicare fraud and waste. Today the spotlight shifts to efforts to shore up the Social Security system. (Justine Lane for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: Possible Solutions for Social Security"
Here are the major options to shore up Social Security, with their pros and cons:
 
Individual Investment Accounts
 
PROS -- An opportunity for nearly all workers to build wealth by investing in stocks and bonds. Higher expected rates of return than from the current system. Still receive a guaranteed benefit payment but lower than under the current system.
 
CONS -- Individuals face the risks of financial markets. Unequal benefits depending on investing skill or luck. Costs of administering 140 million accounts would be steep. Would require deep cuts in guaranteed benefits or large tax increases.
 
Government Investment in Stocks
 
PROS -- Much lower administrative costs than individual accounts. Market risks would be spread across income levels and generations. Returns could close a substantial portion of the financial gap facing the system.
 
CONS -- Makes Government a major force in stock market, raising the possibility of Washington's meddling in corporate decisions.
 
Raising the Retirement Age
 
PROS -- Would reflect increased life expectancies. Further increases would keep constant the portion of adult life spent in retirement. Could eliminate some long-term problems.
 
CONS -- Already scheduled to rise gradually over the next two decades, to 67. People who do physical work cannot be expected to continue working longer than they do now. Raising the age would hurt older workers who lose jobs.
 
Raising the Cap on Taxable Earnings
 
PROS -- Raising the amount of income taxed, from the current limit of $68,400, would put much of the burden for fixing Social Security on those who can afford it most. The current cap leaves a greater portion of total earnings untaxed than in the past.
 
CONS -- Amounts to a substantial tax increase. Social Security is already a relatively bad deal for upper-income people, and raising the cap would make it worse.
 
Cutting Cost-of-Living Adjustments
 
PROS -- Many economists think the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation and gives Social Security recipients a bigger increase than is justified.
 
CONS -- Some economists think the Consumer Price Index understates the cost of living for the elderly.
 
Cutting Benefits for the Wealthy
 
PROS -- Places the burden on those who can most afford it, either through tax increases or benefit reductions. Cutting benefits by 30 percent for people with retirement income above $60,000 a year and by 85 percent for people with retirement income over $110,000 a year would eliminate three-quarters of the program's long-term problems.
 
CONS -- A big tax increase. Taxing benefits might unduly hurt people who get high levels of benefits but have little or no other income.

HEADLINE: Dollars Are Weapon of Choice in the War on Bacteria Peril

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER with WILLIAM J. BROAD 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
In Russia's scientific despair, the United States has sensed great danger and opportunity.
American officials have been worried about Russia's weapons programs from the moment the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991. Initially, the focus was on improving security for nuclear weapons and scientists. The germ warfare program was hardly considered. 
 That changed after several top Soviet germ warriors defected to the West and told intelligence officials that Moscow's germ program was far more lethal and ambititious than had been suspected during the cold war.
At the Pentagon's request and with its money, the National Academy of Sciences began a program in 1995 to expand cooperation between Russian and American biologists. Eager to stem the brain drain, discover more about the Soviet germ arsenal, and learn from the Russian strides in germ defenses, the Clinton Administration has now greatly intensified the effort.
In addition, Washington is paying $1.5 million now and plans to spend up to $6 million to upgrade security at Vector, which is Russia's germ bank for all strains of smallpox, which has been eradicated from humans.
While fewer than 120 of the more than 15,000 strains in Vector's virus collection are highly lethal, scientists say any theft or diversion of the most dangerous ones could be catastrophic.
Washington has also persuaded Europe and Japan to join the United States in financing the International Science and Technology Center, based in Moscow, which tries to find peaceful work for former weapons scientists.
Randall L. Beatty, the center's deputy director, said about 1,055 of the 17,800 scientists receiving payments of $300 to $500 a month for joint research are biologists. That proportion has grown sharply from less than 1 percent of the center's payments to about 15 percent this year, and Mr. Beatty said it "will inevitably grow further."
While less than what the Iranians are said to be offering, American officials say the stipends are attractive because they allow Russian scientists, who earn an average of less than $100 a month, to stay in Russia with friends and family and to collaborate with respected Western researchers on peaceful work.
American officials said such contacts and exchanges are providing valuable information about both the Soviet Union's germ activities and the current situation in Russia. "There has been a quantum leap in their openness in the past 18 months," Mr. Beatty said.
The Clinton Administration is spending millions of dollars on more than a dozen programs essentially intended to make former Soviet scientists and research institutes "a better offer" than Iran or other rogue nations, official say.
"It's up to them to chose," said Anne M. Harrington, the State Department's coordinator for threat reduction programs, "and many of them are deciding they want to work with us."
 American officials say the rudimentary programs have already achieved some successes.
*The scientific institute at Obolensk, the heart of the program to produce deadly germs, has had no contact with Teheran since last year when the United States greatly expanded its financial support.
 
 *In the last 10 months close to a hundred Russian scientists from the former Soviet germ warfare program have visited American labs and institutes, and more than a hundred American scientists and officials have visited, many of them regularly, once-closed Russian germ institutes.
 *The Department of Agriculture, at the Pentagon's request, succeeded in buying samples of Uzbekistan's entire collection of plant germs, helping to track strains and create antidotes.
 American officials say that the threat remains significant, and that they are learning every day about new efforts by rogue states to capitalize on Russia's economic crisis and scientific brain drain.
"I'm like the little Dutch boy running around with my fingers in the dike," said a Pentagon official during a recent field trip. "Every time we visit a new Russian institute, we find another Iranian business card."

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 83 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
LIZ CLAIBORNE PLANS TO DOWNSIZE AND CLOSE STORES

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Faced with sagging sales and profits, Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that it would eliminate about 400 jobs, close 30 retail stores and try to improve its ailing business at department stores. The company, the New York-based women's clothing maker, said the restructuring would cost $13 million to $17 million and would reduce the company's fourth-quarter earnings by 20 cents to 26 cents a share. The shares rose $1.3125, to $32.125. The price has slumped from more than $50 this summer.
